Adolescent sleep quality mediates family chaos and adolescent mental health: A daily diary-based study., Journal of Family Psychology, 33(3), 259-269. https://doi.org/10.1037/fam0000491; permission conveyed through Copyright Clearance Center,  Inc.

1: The p-value is a measure of statistical significance. A p-value less than 0.05 indicates that the difference between the means of the two groups is more likely due to the independent variable from the study than to chance.↩

q.s: Psychologists have found that the rates of depression in the countries of the world vary greatly. Which of the following statements best explains the difficulty in determining how common a disorder may be globally?

o.l: Because other countries never allow studies conducted on people, this type of research is difficult to conduct.
Because human genetics vary widely it is difficult to accurately measure how common a disorder may be in a specific culture.
Because psychologists from different cultures are competitive, they often do not share research results, which makes it difficult to measure diagnostic differences across cultures.
Because cultures deviate widely in their social norms, making consistent and reliable diagnoses across cultures is difficult.

q.s: Which of the following ethical guidelines did the therapist violate by disregarding Ezra’s right to privacy?

o.l: Respect for people’s rights and dignity

f.c: Ezra’s therapist recommended some techniques to help Ezra cope with his anxiety. Ezra observed a positive change in his symptoms following the treatment. While waiting for his appointment in the waiting room he notices an article his therapist had authored referencing Ezra’s case and using his name.

q.s:
Mr. Berndt is teaching his AP Psychology class about the nervous system. 

Which of the following statements would best help students accurately differentiate between the primary roles of glial cells and neurons?

o.l: Glial cells release chemicals known as neurotransmitters into the synapses, while neurons provide structural support.
Glial cells provide support, insulation, and waste removal functions for neurons, while neurons create and transmit electrical impulses between cells.
Glial cells and neurons are both involved in processing sensory information, while primarily glial cells receive and process sensory input from the external environment.
Glial cells are found in both the peripheral and central nervous systems, while neurons are only found in the central nervous system.

q.s: Which of the following concepts most likely accounts for this change in memory?

f.c: Diedre took a yearlong psychology course in which brain structures were discussed in multiple units. At first, she had a hard time remembering the various functions of each brain structure. After learning about them and reviewing them in several different contexts, she can quickly and easily retrieve the function of each brain structure even months later.

q.s: Which of the following can be predicted about his performance as a caretaker based on the concept of stereotype threat?

o.l: The father will ignore the news reports because they do not apply to him.
The father will experience increased resentment toward childcare.
The father will experience increased anxiety and make mistakes as a caretaker.
The father will develop an insecure attachment with his child.

f.c: A devoted young father reads a news report that claims many people believe men are not as intelligent in how to properly care for their children. The young father has plans to care for his child that day.

q.s: Which of the following best represents Nayanika’s current stage of psychosocial development?

f.c: Nayanika is 50 years old and finds her career meaningful and impactful. She enjoys mentoring new employees, which gives her a sense of purpose.

q.s: Which of the following psychological phenomena best explains her experience?

f.c: Maria wakes up in the middle of the night to get a drink of water. As she enters the kitchen, she sees a bowl of red strawberries that appear brown in the dim light, but she still perceives them to be red.

q.s: Which of the following statements is true about this scenario?

o.l: Her fear of the test is the conditioned response (CR).
The tapping of the pen is the unconditioned stimulus (UCS).
Her fear when she hears the tapping when there is no test is the conditioned response (CR).
A test in this class is the conditioned stimulus (CS).

f.c: Clara has test anxiety. Her teacher taps his pen while students are taking a test. After several test days, Clara experiences anxiety when she hears this tapping, even on days when there is no test.

q.s: Based on the table, what is the range of the caregivers’ scores?

f.c:
Ten primary caregivers of children completed an assessment to determine the degree to which they practice authoritative parenting. The table shows the participants’ scores on this assessment. The lowest possible score is 1, meaning the degree of authoritative parenting is low. The highest possible score is 15, meaning the degree of authoritative parenting is high. 

Authoritative Parenting Style Assessment Scores

7
6
4
9
11
8
9
12
5
9

q.s: As part of the selection process for program placement and apprenticeship opportunities, a college requires that applicants take a standardized intelligence test. Which of the following actions must the college take for this practice to be ethical?

o.l: Ensure the confidentiality of the applicants
Assign half of the applicants to take a math test to serve as a control group
Explain to the applicants that the test has predictive validity
Refrain from explaining to the applicants why they are taking the standardized intelligence test

q.s: Vanessa contracted a virus during her pregnancy that caused abnormalities in her developing fetus. Which of the following best describes this virus?
Which of the following research methods was used in the university study?

f.c:
A study was conducted with first-year students in a high-stress honors program at a university. At the beginning of the semester, two hundred students in the program were selected at random and asked to complete two surveys. 

The first survey measured their stress levels related to school, and the second was a health questionnaire measuring recent illnesses. Participants again completed both surveys during exam week at the end of the semester. 

The results of the study showed that as school-related stress levels increased, the number of illnesses also increased. The researchers concluded that school stress causes students to experience more illness.

q.s: Which of the following best explains why the research method in the scenario was chosen?

o.l: Studies involving students can interfere with academic performance and should only be done at specific universities.
It is unethical to intentionally cause stress to people that might result in illness, and thus surveys and questionnaires are more ethical.
Asking health questions on a survey would invade people’s privacy to the point where it is unethical.
The researchers must not interact with participants so they do not influence their behaviors.

f.c:
A study was conducted with first-year students in a high-stress honors program at a university. At the beginning of the semester, two hundred students in the program were selected at random and asked to complete two surveys. 

The first survey measured their stress levels related to school, and the second was a health questionnaire measuring recent illnesses. Participants again completed both surveys during exam week at the end of the semester. 

The results of the study showed that as school-related stress levels increased, the number of illnesses also increased. The researchers concluded that school stress causes students to experience more illness.

q.s: If the researchers graphed the results of the stress survey, which of the following statements would be the best prediction about the distribution of scores?

o.l: The distribution of scores would likely appear as a normal distribution.
The distribution of scores would likely be skewed toward high stress.
The distribution of scores would be skewed toward low levels of stress.
The distribution of scores would be negative.

f.c:
A study was conducted with first-year students in a high-stress honors program at a university. At the beginning of the semester, two hundred students in the program were selected at random and asked to complete two surveys. 

The first survey measured their stress levels related to school, and the second was a health questionnaire measuring recent illnesses. Participants again completed both surveys during exam week at the end of the semester. 

The results of the study showed that as school-related stress levels increased, the number of illnesses also increased. The researchers concluded that school stress causes students to experience more illness.

q.s: What was the dependent variable in this research project?

f.c: Dr. Trenton conducted a study to determine whether massed practice or distributed practice produced better academic outcomes. He recruited volunteers from a high school Spanish class and randomly assigned students to learn a list of 100 new vocabulary words for which they were later given a word recall test. Students prepared for the word recall test using either distributed practice by studying for 30 minutes a day the week before the test, or massed practice by intensively studying the night before the test.

q.s: At six months of age, Byrne underwent the surgical removal of the entire left hemisphere of her brain. Which of the following concepts explains the recovery of her primary functions following such surgery?

When 90-year-old Mrs. Glass socializes at her senior activity center, she gravitates toward activities that she can still perform well, which also demonstrates that her crystallized intelligence is functioning. Which of the following activities will most likely appeal to Mrs. Glass?

o.l: A “name that song” game featuring songs from her childhood
A trivia game featuring current movies
A new video game in which aliens fly a spaceship
A class teaching her how to use the latest computer technology

q.s:
Oksana experiences pleasurable feelings when she hugs her mother. Recently, her mother started wearing a new perfume, which Oksana can smell when she hugs her mother. When Oksana is shopping, she smells that new perfume near the counter where it is sold. She immediately feels the same pleasurable feelings as she does when she hugs her mother.

In terms of classical conditioning, which of the following is the smell of the new perfume?
Carolyn’s explanation for her competitor’s behavior is most consistent with which of the following concepts?

f.c: Carolyn is favored to win a long-distance foot race in the state finals. Shortly before reaching the finish line of the race, the competitor in front of Carolyn trips on accident, causing Carolyn to fall and no longer be in contention to win the race. Carolyn is convinced the competitor who caused her fall is untrustworthy and will do anything to win.

q.s: Researchers examined infants’ depth perception in what is known as the visual cliff experiment. Which of the following statements might be an ethical concern related to using a visual cliff with infants?

o.l: Infants could have experienced distress when they looked at the visual drop or were encouraged by their mothers to cross it.
The researchers did not obtain informed consent from the infants participating in the study.
Infants’ depth perception could have been fundamentally altered by the study, putting the children at risk.
It is always unethical to study how children develop fears, such as a fear of heights.

q.s: Which of the following likely accounts for Nadine’s belief?

f.c: After a couple months of dating, Nadine was very surprised to learn that Noah did not like cats. She had always been a cat lover and could not understand why other people would dislike them.

q.s: Which psychological perspective best supports the view that stress is related to how people believe the stressor impacts their daily life?

f.c: Stressful situations are often explained differently by different individuals. An impending deadline at work may motivate one employee, while that same deadline would create debilitating stress for another employee.

q.s:
Your response to the question should be provided in six parts: A, B, C, D, E, and F. Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology in your response. 
 

 A. Identify the research method used in the study.

f.c:
Using the source provided, respond to all parts of the question.

Introduction

Few large-scale, long-term studies have been conducted to test whether taking a multivitamin makes a difference in improving memory ability as one ages. In this study, researchers examined whether taking a multivitamin slows cognitive decline in later life. 

Participants

An earlier study, which was conducted in 2017 and included over 21,000 people, examined the effects of taking a multivitamin on health outcomes. From that study’s sample, over 7,000 people received a mailed invitation to participate in this study. Of those who received the invitation, almost 4,000 participants agreed to participate and were accepted. To be accepted, participants had to be over 65 years of age if women and over 60 years of age if men. In addition, they could not participate if they had ever had a stroke, if they had received a cancer diagnosis in the two years before the study, or if they had a history of any other serious illnesses. Participants had to be able to communicate in English and had to have access to an Internet-connected computer.

A computer randomly assigned participants to two groups. Participants in Group 1 received a pack of multivitamins each month by mail and were instructed to take one pill twice a day. Participants in Group 2 received a pack of placebo pills in the same type of packaging as Group 1 and with the same instructions. The sample size of Group 1 was 1,758 people, and the sample size of Group 2 was 1,804 people. The demographics of each group are listed in the table:

 

Demographics of Group 1 and Group 2

Demographic Group 1-Multivitamin Group 2-Placebo
  Percent or Mean 
(Standard Deviation in parenthesis when reported)		 Percent or Mean
(Standard Deviation in parenthesis when reported)
Age 70.9 (4.5) 71.0 (4.6)
Gender    
Men 32.9% 33.4%
Women 67.1% 66.6%
Race/Ethnicity    
White or European American 93.1% 93.5%
Black or African American 2.3% 2.6%
Hispanic or Latino/a 1.5% 1.4%
Other race or Multiple races 1.8% 1.2%
Asian American or Native Hawaiian 0.2% 0.1%
American Indian or Alaska Native 1.1% 1.2%

Method

Once a year for 3 years, participants were asked to complete an online test to evaluate episodic memory and executive functioning. Researchers ensured that the individual participants could not be identified from the data collected. Instructions on how to access the test materials were emailed to participants, and participants who responded to the email indicated that they agreed to be in the study and knew they could withdraw from participation at any time. The participants received a $15 gift card for each annual assessment, regardless of completion. 

The multivitamin used in this study is widely available in the United States. Researchers considered factors that might impose difficulty for participants. Side effects of taking the multivitamin include low rates of stomach pain, diarrhea, skin rash, bruising, and an increased rate of gastrointestinal bleeding, which are considered normal side effects for those taking a multivitamin in the general population. 

Two different tasks were used to measure episodic memory and executive functioning in this study:

  • To measure episodic memory, participants completed a recall task in which they were first shown a set of words, presented one at a time for three seconds each. They were then asked to recall the set of words, once immediately after the word list was presented and again after 15 minutes had passed. Participants who recalled more words correctly earned higher scores on this test. 
  • To measure executive functioning, participants were first shown one set of items and were then shown a second set of items. They were asked to identify whether items in the second set of items were the same as or different from the first set of items they were shown. Participants earned higher scores the more quickly they correctly identified whether the items from the second set of items were the same as or different from those in the original set.

 

Results and Discussion

Compared with participants taking a placebo, participants receiving the multivitamin had significantly greater improvement in the recall task at the end of the first year. Performance on the immediate recall task in Group 1 improved from a mean of 7.10 words at baseline to 7.81 words after 1 year of taking the multivitamin, an improvement mean of 0.71. In Group 2, which received the placebo pills, performance on the immediate recall task improved from a mean of 7.21 words at baseline to 7.65 words after 1 year, an improvement mean of 0.44. When comparing the multivitamin group with the placebo group, averaged across all 3 years of intervention, findings suggest that the memory improvement is sustained over time, as shown in the graph. 

 

Comparison of Memory Improvement Between 2 Groups

 

 

Researchers estimate that the effect of the multivitamin intervention improved memory performance in participants in the multivitamin group by the equivalent of 3.1 years of age-related memory change as compared to participants in the placebo group. Researchers also found that executive functioning was not significantly impacted by taking a multivitamin.
The findings suggest that the greatest benefit of taking a multivitamin is found in immediate memory recall, something especially vulnerable in aging adults. 

Reprinted from The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, 118, Yeung, L-K., Alschuler, D. M., Wall, M., Luttman-Gibson, H., Copeland, T., Hale, C., Sloan, R. P., Sesso, H. D., Manson, J. E., Brickman, A. M. Multivitamin supplementation improves memory in older adults: A randomized clinical trial, pages 273–282, Copyright 2023, with permission from Elsevier. 

Adapted from The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition.

The participants received a $15 gift card for each annual assessment, regardless of completion. 

The multivitamin used in this study is widely available in the United States. Researchers considered factors that might impose difficulty for participants. Side effects of taking the multivitamin include low rates of stomach pain, diarrhea, skin rash, bruising, and an increased rate of gastrointestinal bleeding, which are considered normal side effects for those taking a multivitamin in the general population. 

Two different tasks were used to measure episodic memory and executive functioning in this study:

  • To measure episodic memory, participants completed a recall task in which they were first shown a set of words, presented one at a time for three seconds each. They were then asked to recall the set of words, once immediately after the word list was presented and again after 15 minutes had passed. Participants who recalled more words correctly earned higher scores on this test. 
  • To measure executive functioning, participants were first shown one set of items and were then shown a second set of items. They were asked to identify whether items in the second set of items were the same as or different from the first set of items they were shown. Participants earned higher scores the more quickly they correctly identified whether the items from the second set of items were the same as or different from those in the original set.

 

Results and Discussion

Compared with participants taking a placebo, participants receiving the multivitamin had significantly greater improvement in the recall task at the end of the first year. Performance on the immediate recall task in Group 1 improved from a mean of 7.10 words at baseline to 7.81 words after 1 year of taking the multivitamin, an improvement mean of 0.71. In Group 2, which received the placebo pills, performance on the immediate recall task improved from a mean of 7.21 words at baseline to 7.65 words after 1 year, an improvement mean of 0.44. When comparing the multivitamin group with the placebo group, averaged across all 3 years of intervention, findings suggest that the memory improvement is sustained over time, as shown in the graph. 

 

Comparison of Memory Improvement Between 2 Groups

 

 

Researchers estimate that the effect of the multivitamin intervention improved memory performance in participants in the multivitamin group by the equivalent of 3.1 years of age-related memory change as compared to participants in the placebo group. Researchers also found that executive functioning was not significantly impacted by taking a multivitamin.
The findings suggest that the greatest benefit of taking a multivitamin is found in immediate memory recall, something especially vulnerable in aging adults.

q.s: Which of the following statements is best supported by the graph?

o.l: People in their 20s have more difficulty hearing higher frequency sounds than people in their 60s.
People who are 90 years old show no difficulty hearing frequencies at the 2,000 level when played at the 40 decibel level.
As people get older, their ability to hear higher frequency sounds decreases.
In general, a sixty-year-old person cannot hear higher decibel levels at higher frequencies.

f.c:
The amount of hearing loss a person experiences is based on hearing sensitivity. Hearing sensitivity is determined by measuring the absolute threshold for hearing. The graph shows the hearing thresholds for individuals in different age groups, measured in decibels.1

Hearing Thresholds at Different Frequencies by Age Group

  • The following hearing ranges are indicated:
    • 0 to 20 decibels: Normal Hearing Range
    • 20 to 40 decibels: Mild Hearing Loss Range
    • 40 to 70 decibels: Moderate Hearing Loss Range
    • 70 to 90 decibels: Severe Hearing Loss Range
    • 90 to 100 decibels: Profound Hearing Loss Range
  • The following 4 lines representing ages are shown:
    • 20 years
    • 40 years
    • 60 years
    • 90 years
  • All values are approximate.
  • The 20 years line:
    • Begins at frequency 125, 0 decibels
    • Remains level to frequency 1,000, 0 decibels
    • Falls gradually to frequency 8,000, 10 decibels
  • The 40 years line:
    • Begins at frequency 125, 7 decibels
    • Falls gradually to frequency 1,000, 8 decibels
    • Falls gradually to frequency 8,000, 31 decibels
  • The 60 years line:
    • Begins at frequency 125, 15 decibels
    • Remains level to frequency 1,000, 15 decibels
    • Falls gradually to frequency 2,000, 25 decibels
    • Falls sharply to frequency 8,000, 72 decibels
  • The 90 years line:
    • Begins at frequency 125, 22 decibels
    • Falls gradually to frequency 1,000, 23 decibels
    • Falls gradually to frequency 2,000, 36 decibels
    • Falls sharply to frequency 8,000, 100 decibels
  • A note indicates the figure is not drawn to scale.
1: A sound’s amplitude is measured on the decibel scale. The more intense, or louder the sound is, the higher the decibel level. The human threshold for hearing is 0 decibels.↩

q.s: As part of her review for a test, Adley is labeling a diagram that illustrates how neurons communicate. Which of the following labels should she apply just before the generation of an action potential?
Which of the following is an example of habituation for a dog?

o.l: The dog only responded after his owner repeatedly called his name.
Although the dog responded the first time his owner called his name, the dog stopped responding when his owner called his name multiple times.
After his owner first gave him food, the dog continued to beg for food at the table.
The dog stopped begging for food at the table after his owner did not respond with food multiple times.

q.s: Danny is most likely to be diagnosed with which of the following anxiety disorders?

f.c: Danny has an intense fear of snakes. At the sight of a snake, he experiences a powerful fight-flight-freeze response. He avoids all places where he thinks snakes might be.

q.s: Marcia is experiencing which of the following?

f.c: Marcia avoids crowds because she is afraid that she will not be able to escape. She avoids going to movie theaters, riding in elevators, and using public transportation. Sometimes her fear is so overwhelming Marcia doesn’t leave her house.

q.s: Which of the following descriptions best represents the developmental perspective regarding these milestones in physical development?

o.l: The age at which each grasping technique develops is dependent on the frequency of practice and modeling.
The exact age at which each grasping technique develops varies from infant to infant, but the order in which these physical stages occur is the same.
Most infants learn the finger-to-palm grasp more quickly than the thumb-to-index-finger grasp because of early bottle feeding.
Grasping an object between the index finger and thumb requires a level of adrenaline in the prefrontal cortex not present at age six months.

f.c: Wyatt can hold a bottle between his fingers and palm at age six months, yet he is unable to grasp a piece of cereal between his thumb and index finger until age nine months.

q.s: Which of the following is most likely developing to cause these changes in Derek’s voice and appearance?

f.c: Derek is in seventh grade. Derek’s friends and family have noticed that Derek’s voice is getting deeper, and he has more facial hair.

q.s: Which of the following concepts illustrates Dr. Smith’s outlook?

f.c: Dr. Smith, who is a proponent of operant conditioning to improve behavior, attends a conference where he hears researchers present findings from their research on various reinforcement schedules. Whenever the results are not what he expects, Dr. Smith views the study designs as flawed and maintains his current beliefs about operant conditioning.

q.s: Which of the following is a correct interpretation of the results given in the graph?

o.l: The students’ belief in luck and its effect on GPA regresses towards the mean, and is thus important for students to understand.
If students believe that luck makes a difference in their grades, it causes them to earn lower GPAs.
The less students believe that luck plays a significant role in their GPA, the lower their GPAs are.
The more students believe that luck plays a significant role in their GPA, the lower their GPAs are.

f.c:
A recent study aimed to investigate the relationship between attribution and high school grade point average (GPA). As part of this study, high school students were asked to complete an attribution inventory that assessed their beliefs about the factors that determine their high school GPA. These factors included whether students believed their GPA was due to their intelligence and determination or luck.

The researchers focused on students who attributed their high school GPA to luck and compared their attribution inventory score with their actual high school GPA, which is shown in the graph. Higher scores indicate a more external attribution for GPA.

q.s: Dr. Rickman is a mental health professional who believes that the diathesis-stress model best explains how psychological disorders develop. Which of the following statements best describes Dr. Rickman’s beliefs about the causes of psychological disorders?

o.l: Dr. Rickman assumes that psychological disorders derive primarily from genetic factors.
Dr. Rickman emphasizes the importance of cultural practices as the dominant cause of psychological disorders.
Dr. Rickman believes that disorders develop from genetic vulnerability aggravated by adverse life experiences.
Dr. Rickman would argue that the environment is the only important contributor to psychological disorders.

q.s: Lily believes all young men are reckless drivers. Which of the following concepts best represents Lily’s belief?
Which of the following statements best describes this medication?

f.c: Holly was injured in a car accident. Her doctor prescribed a medication that increases the action of endorphins to decrease pain.

q.s: Which of the following implicit attitudes may have influenced how the participants rated each item?

o.l: A participant being aware that they need one item more than the other
A participant seeing the cost of each item and knowing that one is more expensive than the other
A participant attributing a greater value to one item over the other without knowing why
A participant seeing that the toaster is their favorite color

f.c:
In a study, researchers recruited 10 graduate students at their university to complete a series of tasks in a lab. Participants were asked to rate how desirable they found each item, both a toaster and a microwave, on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being not desirable and 10 being very desirable. After completing several complex math problems, participants were told that they could choose either a toaster or a microwave as a prize for participating in the study. After selecting their prize, participants were asked to rate the desirability of both items again. The researchers then compared the participants’ ratings of the items at the beginning of the study and the ratings that the participants provided after choosing their prize. q.s: Craig walks from outside on a bright sunny day into a dark movie theater. Which of the following types of cells are initially responsible for his adaptation to the darker space?

o.l: Glial cells, which are responsible for the process of light adaptation
Ganglion cells, which are responsible for processing visual information and transmitting it to the brain
Rods, which are responsible for adaptation to different light levels
Interneurons, which are responsible for processing perceptual information in the brain

q.s: A researcher from which of the following psychological perspectives would most likely be interested in examining this relationship?

f.c: A researcher conducted a study to investigate whether women in the first trimester of pregnancy score higher on levels of disgust than women who are in a later stage of pregnancy. The researcher believes that being more selective about food choices helps pregnant women avoid diseases that could harm their fetuses.

q.s: Which of the following pathways most directly contributes to his ability to calm down after this startle response?

f.c: Darrin is watching a horror movie. When the evil main character makes a surprise appearance, Darrin jumps out of his seat, his heart rate accelerates, and he screams.

q.s: As more participants provide their ratings, which of the following results could the psychologist expect to find?

o.l: The mean ratings for Group A will decrease and the mean ratings for Group B will increase.
Group A participants will become less susceptible to social desirability effects.
The participants will become less representative of the larger population.

f.c:
A social psychologist conducted a study to examine the effect of the availability heuristic on judgment. The psychologist recruited 20 participants for the study and assigned them to one of two groups. 

The participants completed a survey. One survey question asked participants to rate the likelihood that they would become the victim of a crime. Participants in Group A read a series of news reports about crime-related incidents and then completed the survey. The participants in Group B completed the survey without exposure to the news reports.

The table presents the mean ratings by participants of how likely they thought they would be to become the victim of a crime, divided by group.

q.s: At 45 years old, Harris noticed a decrease in his ability to solve new problems quickly, but also felt that he continued to gain valuable knowledge consistently. Which of the following statements best describes Harris’s experience?

o.l: Harris is transitioning between the concrete stage of cognitive development and the formal operational stage of cognitive development.
Harris’s experience illustrates the differences between fluid and crystallized intelligence.
Harris’s experience illustrates how one’s level of g declines with age.
Harris’s experience illustrates the conflict of integrity and despair.

q.s: Which of the following psychological perspectives is each doctor using to explain Nellie’s symptoms?

o.l: Dr. Nelson is using a psychodynamic perspective, while Dr. Khan is using a biological perspective.
Dr. Nelson is using a cognitive perspective, while Dr. Khan is using an evolutionary perspective.
Dr. Nelson is using a behavioral perspective, while Dr. Khan is using a sociocultural perspective.
Dr. Nelson is using a humanistic perspective, while Dr. Khan is using a psychodynamic perspective.

f.c: Dr. Nelson believes that the symptoms of Nellie’s schizophrenia stem from childhood trauma. However, Dr. Khan believes that excess dopamine is causing many of Nellie’s symptoms.

q.s: Which of the following concepts best applies to the behavior of the class?

f.c: Hannah, a first grade student, got out of her classroom seat many times without permission. Her teacher raised her eyebrows before taking Hannah to the principal’s office. The next day another student, Sarah, started to get out of her seat without permission. As soon as the teacher raised her eyebrows, Sarah quickly returned to her seat and the rest of the class sat quietly.

q.s: Which of the following concepts best explains Lisa’s perception?

f.c: Lisa admires a musician that she has not met but believes is physically attractive. Because of the musician’s appearance, Lisa assumes they must also be intelligent and kind.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios is an example of instinctive drift?

o.l: Rats more easily learn to pair pain in the form of shocks with bitter tastes than sweet tastes. This may result from an innate predisposition to avoid poisonous substances, which are often bitter.
In a study, chimpanzees stacked crates to grab a banana that was out of reach, demonstrating problem-solving through a sudden realization of a solution rather than through trial and error.
Several types of birds can learn to copy the calls of other types of birds and other animals such as frogs or dogs.

A dog learns to return a ball while playing fetch for the reward of praise. Eventually, the dog starts to chew and play with the ball, which is an innate tendency, instead of returning it, which is learned.

q.s: Which of the following concepts best explains why Tim was not able to maintain fasting as a part of his diet strategy?

f.c: Tim decided he needed to lose some weight. He started dieting, but he was experiencing uncomfortable feelings of hunger when he fasted for several hours. He then began eating several small meals over the course of a day and stopped experiencing feelings of hunger.

q.s: A research team plans to study the correlation between genetic predisposition to and incidence of schizophrenia. Which of the following variables would be of most direct interest to this research team as they study this correlation?

o.l: Environmental exposure to biological relatives and the number of symptoms of schizophrenia displayed
The number of siblings a person has
The severity of the illness and the number of environmental stressors
Similarity rates of diagnosis in family members and how much genetic material they share

q.s: Which of the following concepts best explains the difference in Donovan’s experiences?

o.l: The experience of pain is solely a chemical process.
Genetic factors determine the experience of pain.
The kinesthetic sense determines the experience of pain.
The experience of pain involves cognitive factors as well as physical factors.

f.c: Donovan was riding his bike with his family when he fell. The whole family stopped and attended to his injury while he cried for several minutes. Later in the week, Donovan fell off his bike while riding with his friends in the neighborhood. This time he jumped back on his bicycle and tried to catch up with his friends.

q.s: Which of the following concepts provides the most likely explanation for this finding?

f.c: Researchers have found that women in the United States are twice as likely to develop clinical depression as men. One possible explanation for this difference is that women may be more likely to be encouraged to express their feelings and seek help from a mental health professional than are men.

q.s: Which of the following concepts does Lori’s behavior illustrate?

f.c: Lori reads a dozen research studies, each with sample populations of more than 5000 participants, which suggest that REM sleep is critically important in memory consolidation. However, she does not believe that REM sleep is important to help her own memory, so she stays up all night studying for a test the next day.

q.s: Which of the following statements best explains a common criticism of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM)?

o.l: The DSM recommends pharmaceutical treatments for psychological disorders that may not be appropriate for all people.
The DSM organizes symptoms of different disorders so they can be diagnosed effectively.
The DSM features only the cognitive perspective and ignores other important psychological viewpoints.
The DSM uses labels that can create lasting stigma for the person diagnosed.

q.s: Which of the following concepts best explains why Kiara has such a talent for generating multiple potential solutions for her clients?

f.c: Kiara is a skilled interior designer who can visualize multiple design options for a given room. She can present her clients with different versions of what the space could look like and is highly regarded for her creativity and expertise. Her clients almost always choose one of her designs.

q.s: A researcher gave a group of college students a driving test and then collected data about their household income. Using the information in the graph, which of the following statements is most accurate?

o.l: Having a higher driving test score causes students to have a higher family income.
There is a positive correlation between family income and driving test scores.
Having a higher family income causes students to have higher driving test scores.
There is a negative correlation between family income and driving test scores.

f.c:

    • More than $200,000: Test score 180

q.s: Dr. Stonington argues that children’s cognitive abilities develop in clear, distinct stages that are universal. Which of the following views is most consistent with Dr. Stonington’s beliefs?
Which of the following concepts is most likely to explain Gordon’s thinking?

f.c: Gordon notices that his bathroom faucet leaks. He has no experience with plumbing repairs, but he has watched videos online. Therefore, Gordon thinks he can fix the faucet himself.

q.s: Throughout January and the beginning of February, the first two months of a calendar year, Allison writes the previous year as the date on all her assignments instead of the current year. Allison’s tendency to write the wrong year on her assignments is most likely due to which of the following?
Which of the following statements is most representative of the principles of the Law of Effect?

o.l: A person is able to notice a change in a stimulus if it is a large enough proportion of change from the original stimulus.
A person is more likely to engage in a behavior if they feel personal satisfaction from doing it rather than receiving external rewards for doing it.
A person is more likely to engage in a behavior more frequently when the behavior is followed by a positive result.
Identical twins raised in separate households are more similar in IQ and personality than fraternal twins raised in the same household.

f.c: Nafi did not study for his algebra test because he had basketball practice. After he took the test, he was not sure if he had done well. Nafi was surprised to learn that he had received a high score on the test, but then told a friend that he had expected a high score because of his superior intellect.

q.s: Which of the following concepts best explains why Raymond lost his enjoyment for drinking tea during his cold?

f.c: Each night before bed, Raymond enjoys drinking a cup of tea. He enjoys the scent of fragrant teas because the scent enhances the flavor of the tea. During a recent bad cold, Raymond lost his enjoyment for drinking tea.

q.s: Which of the following concepts is consistent with these findings?

f.c:
A memory researcher conducted a study to determine whether words are easier or harder to recall based on when they are presented in a sequence of words. She read a list of words to participants for 60 seconds at a constant rate. Each word was read once, and no words were repeated. The participants were tested on their recall of the words. q.s: Which of the following disorders is most consistent with Grace's symptoms?

f.c: Grace is continually worried about her safety and overthinks solutions to all possible worst-case scenarios for events that haven’t happened. Grace expresses concern to her family about whether they have enough emergency rations, smoke detectors, and batteries in the house just in case they need them. Grace is unable to set aside her worries and always feels restless and on edge.

q.s: Which of the following types of therapy is Natalia's psychologist practicing?

f.c: Natalia regularly visits a psychologist. During one of her visits, the psychologist asked her some questions about the dreams she has been having. Based on this information, the psychologist provided some details about what might be in Natalia's unconscious mind.

q.s: The interaction of social norms and cultural beliefs are best categorized as which of the following systems?

f.c: Campbell and a friend are sharing strategies for parenting their teenaged children as the children transition from middle school to high school. Both parents are struck by how much the social norms and cultural beliefs that influence children have shifted since they were in high school 20 years ago.

q.s: Which of the following is the best example of a behavior reinforced on a variable-interval schedule?

o.l: Tae sends an important text message to her boss to ask if she can miss work to attend a game. She keeps checking her phone to see if her boss has responded because she does not know how long it will take for them to respond.

Ximena responds to surveys on a website because the site offers occasional cash rewards for completing surveys. She responds to a large number of surveys on the site because she does not know how many she must complete to earn the cash rewards.
Cody sells cell phones and monthly home internet subscriptions, earning $50 for every three phones sold and $100 for every five subscriptions sold.
Alexander arrives at the train station at 7:00 a.m. every day because his train arrives at 7:05 a.m.

q.s: As a teacher, Mr. Walter strongly believes that collaboration with strong teachers and mentors can significantly enhance how much a child learns. Mr. Walter’s belief most closely aligns with which of the following?

o.l: The idea that intelligence comprises multiple abilities

q.s: Which of the following factors would best explain Justina’s current belief about smoking?

o.l: Her highly authoritative parents likely contributed to her current belief.
Her growth mindset has led to a change in her beliefs about smoking.
Cognitive dissonance led to her current belief.
The sunk-cost fallacy influenced her current belief.

f.c: Justina believed that she would never become addicted to smoking cigarettes because her parents taught her that it was wrong. Six months ago, she started smoking with her friends on weekends. Now she smokes throughout the week and believes that smoking is no worse than drinking coffee.

q.s: In an experiment examining the effects of a new anti-anxiety medication, which of the following is most important to ensure the study follows appropriate ethical procedures?
According to the levels of processing model, in which scenario would the person have the most accurate recall of new information due to deep processing?

o.l: Natalie, who repeats the information to herself over and over
Janelle, who relates the information to her own experiences
Joy, who reviews the information in the same order every time
Elizabeth, who writes down all the relevant information in her notebook

q.s:
Abby and Jordan are doing a presentation for their AP Psychology class about the role oxytocin plays in the body. 

Which of the following statements would be best to include in their description of oxytocin?

o.l: It regulates appetite by signaling fullness and by helping to control food intake.
It increases mental alertness, concentration, and focus.
It promotes parent and infant bonding.
It influences the sleep/wake cycle by managing the body’s internal clock.

q.s: Which of the following strategies best reflects Melissa’s approach?

f.c: Melissa is a math teacher who teaches her students to solve certain types of problems by applying a formula in a systematic, step-by-step process. If a student skips steps in the process, they are more likely to solve the problem incorrectly.

q.s: A psychologist is writing a textbook chapter on the interaction of nature and nurture on human behavior. Which of the following examples should she include to emphasize the role that nurture plays on behavior?

o.l: Pari’s parents read to her in infancy, so she easily and quickly learns to read when she starts school at age five.
Sammi is six inches taller than his parents and siblings in his adoptive family.
Linda is a supertaster and intensely experiences the bitterness in certain foods.
Rosie has dichromatism and has difficulty distinguishing between red and green.

q.s: Dr. Jones is most likely to employ which of the following techniques in her treatment?

f.c: Dr. Jones, who was trained in the behavioral approach to therapy, is working with a client who has an irrational fear of dogs. The client’s fear has gotten so debilitating that she will not visit a park where she might encounter a dog.

q.s: Which of the following statements is true about the role research ethics play when exploring how the evolutionary perspective explains human behavior?

o.l: A lack of random assignment to conditions makes research in the evolutionary perspective unethical.
Psychological theorists have misapplied principles of the evolutionary perspective in harmful ways.
Human behavior is evolving at a rate that makes it improper to study in an ethical or fair manner.
It is inappropriate to equate the development of human behavior to that of other animals.

q.s: Using the intelligence quotient formula to determine IQ, which of the following individuals would have the highest IQ?

o.l: Sam, who has a mental age of 5 and a chronological age of 5
Dianne, who has a mental age of 5 and a chronological age of 6
Woody, who has a mental age of 6 and a chronological age of 5
Carla, who has a mental age of 7 and a chronological age of 5

q.s: Dr. Lawrence asked participants to identify their gender by using their own words instead of using a multiple-choice question. Which of the following describes the type of data Dr. Lawrence is collecting with this question?

In the 1960s, a psychologist placed dogs in a box and then exposed them to five trials in which they received an electric shock that they could not avoid. In the sixth trial, the psychologist placed the dogs in a different box. In this trial, the dogs could avoid the shocks by jumping over a small obstacle. None of the dogs jumped over the obstacle. 

Which of the following concepts explains why the dogs did not jump over the obstacle to escape the shocks in the sixth trial?
When examining case studies of individuals diagnosed with dissociative disorders, which of the following have researchers found to be true?

o.l: Excessive amounts of dopamine in the brain lead to symptoms associated with dissociative disorders.
Dissociative disorders develop as a way for individuals to cope with trauma.
Personality traits appear to be unrelated to the development of dissociative disorders.
Individuals diagnosed with dissociative disorders have more vivid episodic memories than those not diagnosed with dissociative disorders.

q.s: Which of the following disorders is classified as an anxiety disorder?
What was the independent variable in this experiment?

o.l: The number of words participants could remember
The random assignment of participants to groups
The five-minute break between encoding the words and recalling the words

f.c: Dr. Hains conducted a memory experiment. Participants were randomly assigned to one of two groups. Group 1 was given a list of words that were not related to one another. Group 2 was given a list of words that were related to one another. In both lists, each word was listed once. Both groups were given one minute to memorize the list. After a five-minute pause, participants were asked to write down as many words as they could recall.

q.s: Which of the following factors makes his conclusion faulty?

o.l: Dr. Patel did not debrief his survey participants after the study was completed.
Dr. Patel used a case study method instead of an experiment to investigate the relationship.
Dr. Patel assumed a causal relationship using data from a nonexperimental method.
Dr. Patel did not use naturalistic observation to verify the survey results.

f.c: Dr. Patel conducts a survey of his local community and finds that people who regularly attend a religious service are happier than those who do not. Dr. Patel concludes that attending religious services regularly causes happiness.
