q.s: Dr. Nunez finds that the differences between groups in her research on the use of heuristics in problem-solving was statistically significant. If the outcome of a study is statistically significant, it means which of the following?

o.l: The manipulation of the dependent variable likely had no effect.
The dependent variable likely affected the outcome.
Regression to the mean most likely occurred.
The results are unlikely to be obtained if there is no difference between the control group and the experimental group.

q.s: Tom believes he performed poorly on his last three history exams because of bad luck. As a result, he believes he is due for a good score on the next exam and does not study because he is sure he will perform well. The error in his thinking is most likely attributable to
Which of the following descriptions accurately represents area 2 of the graph?

o.l: The threshold, in which signals have reached critical intensity and allow the neuron to fire
Hyperpolarization, in which positive ions have exited the axon
Repolarization, in which potassium ions exit the axon
Depolarization, in which sodium ions enter the axon

q.s: Katie wants a new phone but is worried that her parents might not buy the one she wants. She asks her parents to purchase the most expensive phone in the store. When they refuse, she asks for the less expensive phone she wanted to begin with. Katie’s strategy is an example of

Which of the following is the most useful study strategy to help a student retain the words in a vocabulary list?

o.l: Focusing on the pronunciation of the words
Putting the words in alphabetical order
Using each word in a sentence

q.s: Benjamin is five years old. While his mother is making his lunch, he explains to her that he is very hungry and would like a lot to eat. His mother cuts his sandwich into four pieces, and he is very pleased. Benjamin’s pleasure at having four small pieces instead of one large piece is due to the fact that he lacks
Psychodynamic theorists believe that the development of personality is largely influenced by unconscious motivations. The theories are most often criticized because they do which of the following?

o.l: Do not take into account the importance of rationalization.
Focus too little on the role of repression.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios illustrates the principle of social facilitation?

o.l: Performing better when in the presence of others than when alone
Changing an opinion about a coworker after working with him or her
Becoming more obedient to authority when in a group
Following social norms to promote group cohesion

The psychosocial theory of development assumes which of the following principles underlies development at all stages?

o.l: Principles of classical and operant conditioning shape personality throughout the life span.
Each stage in the life span presents the task of resolving a different conflict.
Maturation is the primary force that drives movement through stages.
Advancement within each stage is independent of experience in the prior stage.

q.s: In a distribution of a class’s scores on a test about gender identity, a large number of students received high scores while fewer students received low scores. The distribution of the test scores is best described as being which of the following?

Emmit wants to examine whether there is a difference in the number of students with an internal locus of control and the number with an external locus of control based on class year (e.g., freshmen versus sophomores). Which of the following is the most appropriate research method for Emmit to use to determine whether there is a difference?
Which of the following research techniques would be the best way to demonstrate that getting eight or more hours of sleep produces higher exam scores the following day?
Which of the following is an example of using positive reinforcement to get a toddler to repeat the response of washing his hands after eating?

o.l: Explaining that washing his hands promotes cleanliness
Taking away toys when he forgets to wash his hands
Giving him a treat for washing his hands
Allowing him to have dessert if he finishes his meal

q.s: On Diane’s first day of work she was offered a cookie. When she bit into the cookie, it tasted horrible, but because she wanted to make a good impression, Diane concealed her disgust and smiled instead. Diane’s reaction best illustrates

He worries constantly about school, and because of the time he must devote to studying, he also worries about his relationship with his girlfriend. He is often restless, and his family thinks he gets irritated more than he used to. Even though he feels academic pressure, he often struggles to stay focused on his schoolwork, and his grades are suffering. Jamal’s problems are most consistent with which of the following disorders?

Claude, a waiter at a popular restaurant, gives extra appetizers to his return customers because they often tip him more when he does. Claude’s technique relies on which of the following?

becomes less likely to produce an action potential

q.s: A researcher interested in cooperative play in young children unobtrusively places several video cameras at a public playground and counts how many children engage in cooperative play behaviors. Which type of research method is the researcher using?

A one-year-old child learns that the furry animals with bushy tails she sees outside her window are squirrels. Later she sees chipmunks outside the window and believes those are also squirrels. Which Piagetian concept is the child demonstrating?

Four-year-old Maria knows that she has eaten all her peanuts, but she also realizes that Robbie, who cannot see inside her bag, may not know the peanuts are gone. Her awareness demonstrates that Maria has
Evidence for the opponent-process theory of color vision is provided by the fact that

o.l: it takes several minutes for the eyes to fully adapt to darkness
there are three different types of cones in the retinas
the eyes perceive visual illusions, such as the Müller-Lyer illusion
the eyes see negative afterimages after staring at saturated colors for several minutes

q.s: Kelly sees her acquaintance Carly help another student who dropped her books in the hallway. When asked about Carly later, Kelly says that she is not only helpful, but she is also generous, smart, and attractive. Which of the following best explains why Kelly describes Carly with additional positive qualities?

Assessments that ask participants to complete sentences, identify pictures in inkblots, or tell the story behind a photograph are all examples of which of the following types of tests?
A researcher finds that participants work hardest and are most engaged in tasks when their behavior allows them to receive awards. The researcher’s finding exemplifies
The graphs depict the distribution of intelligence test scores for two groups of students at a middle school. Which of the following statements is true of the graphs?

o.l: The mean and standard deviation are identical for both distributions.
The mean is identical for both distributions; the standard deviation is larger for distribution B.
The mean is identical for both distributions; the standard deviation is larger for distribution A.
The standard deviation is identical for both distributions; the mean is larger for distribution B.

q.s: Dr. Mummer believes that his patient experiences nervousness and aggression because of a problem with the amygdala and prescribes a treatment that targets how the amygdala functions. Dr. Mummer’s treatment is most in line with which of the following psychological perspectives?

Ed quit his job because he began to fear that his supervisor was spying on him. Ed frequently hears voices criticizing him, but in reality nobody is there. Ed’s problems are most consistent with which of the following disorders?

Andy is softhearted, good-natured, trusting, helpful, forgiving, gullible, and straightforward. Based on these characteristics, he is most likely to score high on which of the Big Five trait measures?

Every day Haiying tells her parents something new she would like to be when she grows up. Haiying’s parents listen carefully and provide encouraging words. Even if Haiying’s ideas are fanciful and impractical, her parents never pass judgment or suggest that she is being irrational. Haiying’s parents’ responses to their daughter demonstrate which concept?
Studying by focusing on the facts and not the meaning of information that has to be remembered involves

Brian was having difficulty solving a riddle, but after sleeping, he suddenly understood the answer. Brian’s newfound knowledge was probably the result of
Consider the relationship between various body parts and the size of their corresponding somatosensory cortex areas in the brain. How does a body part relate to the devoted cortical area?

o.l: The larger the body part, the larger the area of the somatosensory cortex.
The closer the body part is to the brain, the smaller the area of the somatosensory cortex.
The closer the body part is to the trunk, the larger the area of the somatosensory cortex.
The more sensitive the body part, the larger the area of the somatosensory cortex.

q.s: Which of the following most clearly demonstrates social learning theory?

o.l: Mavis learns a line dance by watching her friends perform it.
Neville becomes dependent on alcohol because he finds that after drinking it he temporarily forgets his problems.
After writing his paper at the last minute, Raul gets a bad grade and never procrastinates again.
Xanthe deletes his social media accounts after experiencing harsh bullying from others online.

q.s: Rudy has chronic trouble staying awake in class. What part of the brain is most likely responsible for Rudy’s drowsiness?
Dizziness is most closely associated with which of the following senses?
A teacher has to learn 170 new student names every year and finds it difficult to remember the names of former students. The teacher’s memory problem most likely results from
Which of the following approaches to treating psychological disorders includes free association and dream analysis?

A basketball player deliberately tried to injure opposing players during the game. Near the end of the game, he falls and is injured. A fan comments that the player deserved the injury. The fan’s sentiments best represent what social psychological phenomenon?

Ten-month-old Jacqueline is seated on a couch. A researcher takes a toy from her hands and hides it under a blanket. Jacqueline reaches for the toy under the blanket. Which of the following concepts is being tested in this study?
In what important way does research on taste aversion conducted by John Garcia and Robert Koelling demonstrate how biology can strongly influence classical conditioning?

o.l: By showing that some associations between unconditioned and conditioned stimuli are more easily learned than others
By showing that pairing the conditioned stimulus with the unconditioned stimulus is not required
By showing that the unconditioned stimulus and the conditioned stimulus must be presented together

q.s: The sociocultural perspective is best reflected in which of the following research findings?

o.l: Shortly after young children were exposed to a bacterial streptococcal infection they began displaying symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder.
Brain imaging studies show higher levels of activity in the limbic system of individuals with depression when responding to negative emotional information.

In the United States individuals diagnosed with dissociative identity disorder switch identities upon suggestion, while in India individuals diagnosed with the same disorder switch personalities only upon awakening.
Individuals diagnosed with antisocial personality disorder show weaker startle responses when shown unpleasant stimuli.

q.s: The above graph of conditioning shows which of the following concepts?

o.l: Generalization, discrimination, and higher order conditioning

If the shortest person were taller
If everyone in the class were one inch taller
If the tallest and shortest person were removed from the data set

Diego’s new puppy Agatha has developed the annoying habit of begging for food when people are eating. Using operant conditioning, which of the following would be the most effective technique for Diego to use to get Agatha to stop begging for food?

Diego should never feed Agatha when she begs, but instead should pet her.

q.s: A goal of cognitive therapists is to help their clients

o.l: understand the symbolism in their dreams

In the psychosocial theory of development, which of the following best illustrates his notion of the struggle between intimacy and isolation?

q.s: Which of the following concepts is depicted in the graph?

Based on the data, what is the most appropriate conclusion?

o.l: Distributed practice is more effective at enhancing longer-term retention of material relative to massed practice.
Distributed practice is more effective than massed practice for short-term memory.
Massed practice is more effective than distributed practice is for enhancing sensory memory.
Massed practice is more effective for longer-term retention than distributed practice is.

q.s: Kaori is traveling on an airplane for the first time. As the plane takes off, she watches the automobiles driving on the freeway below. Which perceptual principle best describes this phenomenon?

o.l: The tendency to affiliate with others in order to enhance the likelihood of survival
The need to sleep after a period of sleep deprivation

q.s: Which of the following illustrates an application of behavioral principles in the treatment of an anxiety disorder?

o.l: Using light-exposure therapy to treat major depressive disorder
Using systematic desensitization to treat a specific phobia

q.s: Tim can no longer create new memories as a result of an accident. Tim is experiencing which of the following types of amnesia?

When Kaylee’s friends discovered she was going to have her tonsils removed, they told her she was going to be in a great deal of pain. Given this scenario, which of the following best explains Kaylee’s reporting of pain?

Which of the following is the most likely reason many of the observers do not notice the person in the gorilla costume?

Jeremy recorded his school’s level of well-being and the mean outside temperature each day for a month. His analysis showed that as the temperature decreased his school well being increased. Which of the following terms best characterizes the association between these two variables?

Researchers examined injury reports for 480 professional football games and determined there was an association between outdoor temperature and number of concussions reported. Which of the following best describes the type of research method used in this study?
While he is at soccer practice, Erwin reminds himself that he has to stop at the grocery store on the way home to pick up milk and cereal for tomorrow’s breakfast. What sort of memory is Erwin using?

A developmental psychologist who is using a visual cliff is most likely studying which of the following?

Four-year-old Sawyer’s mother is helping him put together a puzzle that he cannot put together alone. When his mother tries to help, she realizes that Sawyer is ready to learn this skill on his own. Cognitive psychologists such as Lev Vygotsky would label this as what psychological process for child learning?
Michelle has just learned that she failed a test. Which of the following of Michelle's possible explanations for failing the test would most likely indicate that Michelle is experiencing depression?

o.l: “I’m not very good at school and probably never will be.”
“Probably none of the students in the class did well on this test.”
“The professor in this class is the worst teacher I’ve ever had.”
“I’m not concerned about classes that aren’t in my major.”

q.s: A research team wanted to measure how smart Chris was. The researchers measured how many math questions Chris got correct on his final exam. This measurement constituted which of the following?
Mahir is experiencing life-threatening seizures. A neurosurgeon is planning to remove a section of his brain to stop the seizures. Mahir is most likely to have the fewest long-term problems if

o.l: he is under the age of six

q.s: Cory has a small role in the school’s upcoming theater production. Cory has memorized his lines and knows his role well. On the first night of performances, Cory notices that the auditorium is full and the audience is enthusiastic. How is social facilitation likely to affect Cory’s performance in front of the audience?

o.l: Cory will probably do better during the performance than he did during rehearsal.
Cory will probably do worse during the performance than he did during rehearsal.
Cory will probably put forth less effort during the performance than he does during rehearsal and will rely on other cast members to work harder.
Cory will be likely to attribute a bad performance to aspects of the situation rather than to his own preparation.

Dave feels guilty after eating three slices of chocolate cake. However, he tells himself not to worry because he ate a very light lunch earlier in the day. What defense mechanism is Dave relying on?
Uma is able to remember a list of items she must buy by creating visual images of the items in various spots in her dorm room. The technique Uma is using is called

In a study, rats were randomly assigned to two groups, group A or group B. Group A received no food reward for completing a maze initially, but was allowed to explore the maze. Group B was given food rewards for completing the maze during the exploration phase. Later, when given food rewards for completing the maze, the rats from group A completed the maze as quickly as the rats from group B. Which of the following terms best explains the performance of the rats in group A?
Joe is having difficulty solving a math problem. He decides to systematically try every possible answer in an effort to find a solution to the problem. Which of the following approaches is Joe using?

At the beginning of the school year, Juan had trouble paying attention in class because he was distracted by posters in the classroom. Margaret is beginning to plan a research project for her psychology class. She wants to examine whether there is a difference between boys and girls in terms of the frequency with which they throw away their trash in the school cafeteria after they have finished eating lunch. Which of the following methodologies would most accurately measure the behavior of interest in Margaret’s study?

A psychologist looking at a graph of IQ scores around the world notices that the data form a normal distribution. Which of the following statements describes the mean, median, and mode of a test whose scores are normally distributed?

o.l: The mean and the median will be the same value, but the mode will be lower.
The mean will be the highest value, followed by the median, followed by the mode.
The mode will be the highest value, followed by the median, followed by the mean.

Emma has lost the ability to understand language. She has most likely suffered damage to the

o.l: Earning good grades in college causes higher incomes in adulthood.
Good grades in college and high incomes are related.

o.l: most of the traits show little validity across cultures
people show fairly high levels of stability in the traits from year to year

q.s: Bob is concerned because his children have been eating too much of an expensive breakfast cereal, so he brings home a less expensive version that looks and tastes exactly the same to him. The primary difference between the central route and the peripheral route to persuasion is whether the persuasion focuses on

Sammi and Trina are both on the volleyball team. After a loss, Sammi shows up early to the next practice and works extra hard, whereas Trina skips that practice to go to the movies. Based on these observations, Sammi and Trina most likely differ in which of the following concepts?
Twenty-five-year-old Aaron worries about various issues throughout the day. Aaron is distressed by his worrying. Aaron’s problems are most consistent with which of the following?
Which of the following concepts is depicted by the graph?

Mica is often called an extravert because they easily engage with peers in social situations and have many hobbies that require speaking in front of people. Mica remembers that throughout their life, whenever they tried to make friends or speak in front of people, they were praised for it. o.l: Mica is seeking personal growth through self-actualization.
Mica received positive reinforcement for exhibiting outgoing behavior.
Mica has an unconscious drive toward interacting with other people.

q.s: Which of the following students is likely experiencing symptoms of anorexia nervosa?

o.l: Michale, who is fasting during the day as a religious observance but then feasts each night with his family
Amaya, who experiences nausea and sometimes even vomits when she thinks about going back to school, where she is bullied
Amare, who exercises for at least three hours per day and eats only a quarter of the calories they need per day, never any more than that
Niko, who tries to limit their calories to that required to maintain body weight, but has frequent episodes of eating sugary foods that make them far exceed the amount of calories they need per day

q.s: The graph depicts the stages of sleep, including REM sleep and NREM sleep (Stages 1, 2, and 3). The data in the graph would most likely be obtained with which of the following instruments?

f.c: STAGES OF THE SLEEP CYCLE

q.s: The graph depicts the stages of sleep, including REM and NREM (Stages 1, 2, and 3). For the person with the results shown in the graph, progressing across the x-axis, there is most likely to be an increase in which of the following?

f.c: STAGES OF THE SLEEP CYCLE

q.s: Which of the following phenomena describes the finding that intelligence scores increased over several decades?

Four-year-old Mikal avoids eye contact with strangers and family members alike. He has difficulty functioning outside of a very rigid routine and will exhibit extreme distress if his routine is disrupted even slightly. Which of the following is Mikal’s behavior most consistent with?

One theory of hearing suggests that a neuron may fire and then stop firing when a second neuron fires. The first neuron then fires again, while the second one does not. This type of sequence is then repeated in response to auditory stimuli. Which of the following describes this pattern?
The fact that most infants sit before they stand and stand before they walk is most indicative of
Nicole tells her psychiatrist that she is upset because she believes her neighbors have cast a magic spell on her, even though they have not. Which of the following is Nicole experiencing?

Previously, when Ezekiel’s puppy would go into the other room, Ezekiel would forget that the puppy was ever there. Now, he tries to see where the puppy went. According to Jean Piaget, Ezekiel seems to have achieved

Jeremy is a doctoral student who wants to investigate the effectiveness of a new mnemonic device with third graders. His plan includes asking the children to complete an informed consent form. Which of the following reasons would cause his research project to be denied by an Institutional Review Board?

o.l: New teaching techniques are not researched.
Jeremy is not considered a legitimate researcher.
Children can express approval but only parents or legal guardians can provide consent.
Confidentiality cannot be assured in this scenario.

q.s: Special headsets can make objects on the left appear to be on the right and vice versa. At first, people have a hard time walking in these headsets and bump into things, but they eventually adjust and navigate through the environment appropriately. What explains this improvement in function?
Haruto’s eyes have only two types of cones. Which of the following of Haruto’s perceptual abilities is most likely to be affected by this?

o.l: Choosing clothing of a particular color
Determining distances between objects as he reaches for them
Focusing on objects that are close

q.s: Hailey is fishing on a small boat. The water is choppy, causing Hailey to lose their balance and fall onto the deck. Which of the following senses most likely contributed to Hailey’s fall?

Dr. Grant is a developmental researcher at a large university who studies the effect of macrosystem variables on individual behavior. She insists that her students use clear operational definitions of the variables they are investigating. Why would Dr. Grant insist that her students do this?

o.l: To collect an adequate sample size
To control for the effects of the dependent variable
To ensure that the study can be accurately replicated
To ensure that their studies are double-blind

q.s: Professor Saito is investigating whether online teaching compared to the standard classroom lectures affect intelligence scores. After selecting student participants and assigning half to an online course and half to a standard lecture course, he administers an exam to both groups. What is the independent variable in this research?
Victoria notices that when she believes she will be successful at a new task, she is often correct. Victoria’s beliefs reflect which of the following concepts?
Carlos finds a correlation of −.76 between outside temperature and degree of depression in a sample of 450 American citizens. Which of the following can be concluded from the research finding?

o.l: Cold temperatures cause people to become depressed.
As outside temperature increases, people’s depression levels decrease.
No conclusions can be drawn because the sample was limited to only American citizens.
Depression can be alleviated with exposure to warm outside temperatures.

q.s: In a memory study, participants were given different things to focus on as they tried to remember words presented. For some of the words, they were asked whether the word was in capital letters (case); for others, whether the word rhymed with a target word (rhyme); and for still others, whether the word belonged in a given sentence (sentence). Which of the following statements is supported by the graph?

o.l: Participants in the rhyme condition relied mostly on semantic encoding.
Participants in the case condition remembered fewer words because of shallow processing.
Participants in the sentence condition remembered more owing to context-dependent memory.
Participants in the sentence condition remembered more than those in the rhyme condition because they utilized distributed rehearsal.

q.s: Bill mistakenly believes that his coworker Natalia dislikes him. As a result, Bill avoids Natalia and is not friendly toward her. Natalia notices this and then begins to dislike Bill. This scenario is an example of which of the following?

Researchers studying stereotype threat are concerned that approximately 80 percent of study participants are drawn from Western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic societies that comprise only 12 percent of the world’s population. Of the following explanations, which best represents why this finding leads to such uneasiness among psychologists?

o.l: Without a representative sample, it is difficult to identify the independent variable in a study.
Unrepresentative samples have lower test-retest reliability.
A study cannot be considered ethical unless it is representative of the general population.
A representative sample is essential if researchers are to generalize the results to the entire population.

q.s: Michelle and Jill went to lunch. Michelle paid for the lunch, and as a result, Jill feels that she should do something for Michelle. Jill’s feeling that she should do something for Michelle in return can be explained best by which concept?

Dr. Crump is developing a new personality test that he hopes will measure personality factors similar to those measured by a Big Five personality inventory. His participants take the new personality test and the main Big Five inventory used in clinical settings. The next week the participants take the new personality test again. Dr. Crump finds that the participants in the study had similar scores each time they took the new personality test and that there is a weak positive correlation between the scores on the new personality test and the Big Five inventory. Dr. Crump is most likely to conclude that the new personality test has which of the following qualities?
Which of the following examples best represents a behavioral approach to treatment?

o.l: Marco’s psychologist helps him focus on identifying unhelpful patterns of thinking.
Annaleise’s psychologist has her identify a fear hierarchy of spider-related experiences to work through systematically as she practices relaxation techniques.
Dina’s psychologist has her think about what her ideal life would be like.
Lucy’s psychologist helps her relive past childhood experiences to uncover the hidden source of her anxiety.

q.s: Saloni is a track athlete. She races best when she is at a track meet with other people watching her. She does not run as fast when she is training by herself. This difference is an example of whch of the following concepts?

Dr. Faber administers a large number of test questions and identifies different types of intelligence based on items that group together. Dr. Faber is most clearly employing which statistical technique?
Which of the following statements is best supported by research on human intelligence?

o.l: Fluid intelligence increases across the adult lifespan.
Crystallized intelligence continues to increase through adulthood.
Average IQ scores have remained stable across generations for the last century.
Fluid intelligence and crystallized intelligence remain stable throughout adulthood.

q.s: The graph depicts which of the following phenomena?
Cassidy can only remember the titles of the first few books her teacher told her to get from the library. Which of the following concepts would best explain Cassidy’s experience?

Neema is training to be a research assistant at a nature preserve. Part of the training involves identifying the color of migrating butterflies’ wings. However, Neema has recently sustained damage to her fovea. Which of the following would predict that she will likely struggle with the training?

Leilani prefers to maintain an exciting life with lots of people around and lots of activities all the time. She went on a retreat where she encountered a much quieter environment than she is used to. When she returned home, she immediately sought out friends and went to a concert. Which of the following theories best explains her behavior when she returned home?
As a child, Annie experienced a serious fall that damaged her cerebellum. Which of the following memory systems would be most affected by this?
Although his parents repeatedly warn him about the dangers of texting while driving, seventeen-year-old Marco continues to do so. Which of the following most likely explains Marco’s persistence?

o.l: High level of the Big Five trait of neuroticism

q.s: Corey has a list of things he needs from the grocery store but forgets his list at home. At the store, Corey struggles to remember the items on his list, but when he sees a display of oranges, he remembers that oranges were on his list. This is an example of
Randy and Nina have four daughters and believe they are more likely to have a son than a daughter when they have another child. This is an example of which of the following concepts?
If a patient is diagnosed with depression, a cognitive psychologist would likely emphasize which of the following in the patient’s course of treatment?

o.l: Restructuring the patient’s maladaptive and self-defeating thought processes
Uncovering early childhood events that may have been repressed and are now contributing to the depression
Using exposure therapy to gradually direct the patient to more positive behaviors
Using reflective listening techniques to ensure that the patient feels they are being heard

q.s: Ms. Troyna compares how often the students in her class plagiarize to how often they think other students in their class plagiarize. She finds that students who plagiarize the most overestimate how often other students plagiarize. What principle of psychology did she find in her class?
Which of the following demonstrates semantic memory?

o.l: Esteban remembers the correct way to swing a golf club.
Jane needs to remember that she has a dental appointment next Tuesday.
Elizabeth knows the formula to calculate the area of a square.
Elliott has a vivid memory of their wedding day.

q.s: Dr. Dell read about a study completed nearly twenty years ago suggesting that attitudes toward online dating were generally negative. He hypothesized that those attitudes have changed. In order to show how attitudes might have evolved, Dr. Dell should do which of the following?

o.l: Identify the probability of a type II error

q.s: A professor conducts an experiment in which she asks college students to watch an hour-long educational video. The professor randomly assigns half of the students to receive ten points of extra credit for watching the video, while the other half of the students receive only one point. After watching the video, each student rates how interesting the video was on a scale of 1 to 100. The professor finds that the students who received one point rate the video as more interesting than those who received ten points. Which theory best explains these results?
Dhyana is tasked with designing a political campaign that utilizes the peripheral route to persuasion as part of their strategy. Which of the following strategies exemplifies this?

o.l: Hosting a six-hour town hall meeting
Hosting one-on-one meetings between the candidate and potential voters
Hiring a well-known actress to stand next to the candidate at a rally
Visiting political science classes at local colleges

q.s: Samantha thinks her teddy bear cries when it is left alone. According to Jean Piaget’s theory of cognitive development, Samantha is most likely in which of the following stages?
Which of the following scenarios best describes schema assimilation?

o.l: A child assumes she will not like broccoli because its shape is similar to that of cauliflower, which she does not like.
A woman sees a building on fire but does not call the fire department because she believes someone else will.
A salesperson persuades a buyer to purchase a small set of knives, hoping the buyer will upgrade to a larger set.
A father is able to remember only the last two items on a grocery list because they were added most recently.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios best describes the psychodynamic approach to treatment of psychological disorders?

o.l: When Riley has anxious thoughts, they snap a rubber band they keep around their wrist.
With the help of a therapist, Angela works to reframe her dysfunctional thoughts and behaviors.
Because of consistently positive feedback from a counselor, Wole’s self-esteem is raised.
With the help of a therapist, Carla deals with her persistent anxiety by discussing the relationship she had with her parents.

q.s: Based on the graph, what type of association is there between introversion and time spent online?

Gloria has been watching news coverage about a recent plane crash for long periods of time every day. She was supposed to fly next week but decided not to because she thinks that airplanes are too dangerous. Gloria’s thinking demonstrates which of the following?

Eleanor is interested in measuring how personalities differ. She statistically analyzes responses to personality surveys to determine what aspects of personality can best explain how people differ. Which of the following is the best theory of personality to explain Eleanor’s work?

A team of investigators discovered that taxi drivers who had memorized all the streets in their city had a larger hippocampus than bus drivers who did not have the streets memorized. This type of difference between these two groups most likely reflects
Which of the following examples represents the concept of the mere-exposure effect?

o.l: Ritu fell in love with her favorite movie the first time she saw it, and she never gets tired of watching it.
Alexei believes everything that her favorite singer says on social media about a new remedy for sleepless nights.
Douglas prefers to watch movies only once, as he hates repeated information and finds it frustrating.
Ryan grows to like a commercial for a local diner the more he watches that commercial.

q.s: Sawyer is talking to her friend Maya about how nervous she is for an upcoming test. Maya tells Sawyer that it is good to be nervous for the test. She explains that as long as her nervousness is not debilitating, it will help her perform well. Maya’s explanation is most consistent with which of the following concepts?

Ken fell off a float during a parade and was knocked unconscious. At first, observers were hesitant to help and looked around at each other until one of the parade workers called for help. Then, people came forward to help Ken. This scenario reflects which of the following concepts?
Which of the following is a measure of central tendency that best represents the type of distribution represented in the graph?

f.c: The graph represents scores on an exam about the influence of groups on individual behaviors.

q.s: What type of distribution is best represented in the graph?

f.c: The graph represents scores on an exam about the influence of groups on individual behaviors.

q.s: A research team lesioned the lateral hypothalamus of a rat and then monitored the rat’s activity when it recovered from the surgery. Their hypothesis is likely to be that the rat would do which of the following?

o.l: Experience impaired short-term memory in learning a maze
Form extreme fear responses to nonthreatening stimuli
Display increased sociability toward other rats

q.s: Jane often walked with her baby, Chloe, past a construction site. Near the site, a bright light followed by a loud sound would occur that would frighten Chloe, and she would cry. Soon Chloe would cry even if the light was not followed by the loud noise. Eventually Chloe began to cry when she saw flashing lights at the supermarket as well. This pattern of behavior reflects

Gloria is a therapist who believes in humanistic psychology and uses the principles of person-centered therapy. When a client comes to see Gloria with personal issues, which of the following techniques is Gloria most likely to use?

Dr. Ramsey is studying the effectiveness of different operant conditioning methods to encourage studying behavior in students. The data are presented in the graph. According to the data, which of the following is true of motivating students to study more?

o.l: Positive reinforcement is the most successful.
Negative reinforcement is the most successful.
Positive punishment is the most successful.
Negative punishment is the most successful.

q.s: Michael is walking in the woods when he is suddenly startled by a dangerous-looking snake directly in his path. Which of the following brain structures is responsible for triggering his fear?

Students in Ms. Hollingsworth’s classroom could earn a coupon for every ten minutes they spent working on a project. When they accumulated five coupons, they could pick out a favorite book and read it for fifteen minutes during free time. Ms. Hollingsworth’s approach to getting students to complete their projects involves what application of operant conditioning?

Hector makes over half of the free throws he attempts in basketball games. During games, he taps his foot three times before attempting each free throw because he thinks it brings him good luck and that he would miss the shot without it. According to a behaviorist, this behavior is an example of which of the following?

o.l: Avoidance learning associated with previous attempts
A conditioned response after making free throws in the past
A superstitious behavior accidentally associated with successfully shooting free throws

q.s: Dr. Amie conducts an experiment in which participants are asked to observe a recorded lecture and either take notes as they watch in real time or take notes when they pause the lecture every minute. She then gives them a test to evaluate their knowledge about the information presented. To reduce the likelihood of confounding variables influencing the experiment, Dr. Amie should do which of the following?

o.l: Ensure that all participants watch the same recorded lecture
Be sure that participants are placed into the group they believe will be most beneficial based on their approach to learning
Receive informed consent from each participant prior to starting the study
Ensure that participants are drawn randomly from the population

q.s: John had tantrums when his father would not let him play video games. His father decided to take away some of John’s television time each time he had a tantrum, which effectively reduced John’s tantrums. Which of the following approaches did John’s father use?
Which of the following is most likely to occur in the third stage of the general adaptation syndrome?

o.l: A positive appraisal of the stressor
A mobilization of the body’s resources
An increased vulnerability to stress-related illnesses

q.s: Marissa lives in a major city where she is much more likely to be hit by a car than she is to be bitten by a snake. However, Marissa has a phobia of snakes, not a phobia of cars. This is most likely due to the influence of

Garrett is rejected by members of his friend group when they realize that he often takes advantage of them to enhance his own standing. He considers himself superior, and he overstates his abilities and his contributions to the group. Garrett is displaying behaviors most consistent with which of the following disorders?

One morning, Lila was running late and was unable to find time to eat breakfast. She had planned to go on a five-mile hike before lunch that afternoon. However, only one mile into the hike, Lila turned back and went home early. Which of the following most likely explains the motivation for her behavior?

o.l: Lila is hungry and is motivated by an internal drive to reduce her hunger by ending her hike early.
Lila is not intrinsically motivated by hiking and needs to begin again.
Lila is not motivated to meet her commitment without a peer joining her for the hike.
Lila has reduced her need for self-actualization by starting the hike and therefore does not need to finish it.

q.s: A problem-solving strategy that is thorough but often inefficient when it is used by humans is an example of which of the following concepts?

Jeremiah hears voices when no one is present and believes that there is a secret government plot to harm him. Jeremiah’s speech is often disorganized, and he has difficulty maintaining coherent thought. Jeremiah’s behaviors are most consistent with which of the following?

As Olivia leaves her dorm room to go to class, she thinks she may not have turned off her coffee maker. After returning to check the coffee maker and seeing that it is off, she leaves again. However, Olivia continues to believe the coffee maker may still be on. She repeats the action of going back to her room to check it several times. Olivia’s behavior is likely an example of which of the following concepts?
When Alexus traveled to another country, she experienced jet lag and had trouble adjusting to the new time zone. Alexus’ experience is most likely linked to which of the following concepts?
Which of the following circumstances would most likely lead to a person experiencing an increased feeling of love?

o.l: A sudden increase in levels of norepinephrine
A sudden increase in levels of oxytocin

q.s: Which of the following research methodologies would present the most ethical problems for studying the causes of anterograde amnesia in humans?

The figure shows the distribution of scores on an intelligence test in the general population. As shown in the figure, the mean of the distribution is 100 and the standard deviation is 15. What percentage of the population has an IQ score above 145?

Thirty-five-year-old Tuong awakens briefly many times each night gasping for breath. Although she does not remember these awakenings the next day, they keep her from getting a restful night’s sleep. Tuong is most likely experiencing which of the following disorders?
According to the psychosocial theory of development, which of the following represents a question that might be asked by someone who is experiencing the stage of industry versus inferiority?

o.l: Have I done a good job raising my children?
Am I fundamentally an introvert with an interest in a quiet life?
Have I lived a productive life?
Will I be able to learn to skate?

q.s: Sam and his therapist are constructing an anxiety hierarchy. Sam most likely has which psychological disorder?

A group of fans with painted faces attend a crowded football game where they feel anonymous and begin a chant using offensive words that they do not typically use. Which of the following concepts best explains their behavior?

In the Strange Situation setting, a toddler named George engages in very little exploration and spends almost all of his time with his caregiver when the caregiver is present. George’s attachment style is best described as which of the following?
Which of the following statements is most consistent with a behaviorist's ideas?

o.l: Personality is primarily a function of one’s genes.
People obtain their personality from watching other people.
Personality is based on factors predominantly in one’s unconscious.
Personality is a function of the reinforcements and punishments people get for their behavior.

q.s: Which schedule of reinforcement produces behavior that is extinguished with the fewest trials?
According to evolutionary theorists, which of the following explains the tendency to quickly organize individuals into in-group and out-group categorizations?

o.l: The need to quickly assess the heritability of characteristics
The need to categorize and react to unfamiliar individuals
The need to negotiate within one’s own group
The need to communicate effectively with younger members of the group

q.s: Dr. Ofori is helping a client who reports feeling overly stressed due to a heavy workload. Dr. Ofori believes an important first step is to help reframe the situation so that the client will see the workload as a challenge to be overcome rather than as an obstacle. This is most consistent with which treatment orientation?
Which of the follow scenarios is the best example of natural selection?

o.l: During a drought, the foliage in a region turns brown. More brownish moths than whitish moths from a particular breed survive predation and produce more offspring. Subsequent generations of moths have a higher percentage of brownish moths than the generation before.
During a hurricane, both brownish and whitish moths are killed in approximately equal numbers by the storm. The population of moths is substantially reduced.
Just before the moth breeding season, the weather conditions result in an unusual abundance of food. With so much food, the moth population increases dramatically, regardless of color.
An increase in predation substantially reduces the population of adult brownish and whitish moths. Relatively few moths survive to breed, and the population is reduced in the next generation.

q.s: Ruth and Debbie are identical twins who were raised by the same family. Vince and Frankie are identical twins who were separated at birth and raised by different families. According to research on the heritability of personality traits, Ruth's and Debbie's personalities are statistically

o.l: more likely to be similar to one another than are Vince’s and Frankie’s personalities
likely to be as similar and dissimilar to one another as are Vince’s and Frankie’s personalities
more likely to be dissimilar to one another than are Vince’s and Frankie’s personalities
less likely to match on the personality dimensions of agreeableness and extraversion than are Vince and Frankie but not on other personality dimensions

q.s: Johnny often hits his brother even though his brother does not do anything to antagonize him. Johnny’s aggression is most likely due to a combination of which of the following factors?

o.l: his genetic makeup, the fact that aggression can be evolutionarily adaptive, and a lack of neuroplasticity
the environment he grew up in, developmental delays, and the fact that aggression can be evolutionarily adaptive
his genetic makeup, developmental delays, and a lack of neuroplasticity
his genetic makeup, the environment he grew up in, and the fact that aggression can be evolutionarily adaptive

q.s: Trinna and Suzanne are identical twins who were the same length at birth. They were adopted by different families at birth and then reconnected in their early thirties. Trinna is two inches shorter and was a severely selective eater as a child. A researcher was conducting an investigation about twins separated at birth. What research method and explanation best fit this scenario?

o.l: A longitudinal study, because heredity is much more important than environment in determining length and height.
A case study, because environment is much more important than heredity in determining length and height.
A case study, because both heredity and environment are important in determining length and height.
A longitudinal study, because environment is much less important than heredity in determining height in early childhood.

q.s: Professor Janeja is studying which brain regions are involved in learning to correctly navigate a maze task. She randomly assigns half of a group of mice to get a lesion in one area of the brain. The other half does not get a lesion. Based on the following graph, where in the brain is the most likely site of the lesion?
Getting a headache from not having a morning coffee after substantial daily coffee consumption for several months is most likely due to which of the following concepts?
Based on its effects on the central nervous system, alcohol can be classified as which of the following concepts?
The drugs that block the reabsorption of neurotransmitters in the synapse during neural transmission are best identified as which of the following concepts?
The explanation that holds that dreams are merely the brain’s attempt to make sense of meaningless patterns of brain activity during sleep is best identified as which of the following theories?
Which of the following activities most directly relies on the hippocampus?

o.l: Remembering events specific to one’s life
Memorizing the layout of a neighborhood
Using short-term memory to recreate a picture when drawing a copy of the picture
Rehearsing a fact to remember it for a short period of time

q.s: The parietal lobe is most involved in which of the following processes?
Which of the following best describes a major role of the thalamus?

o.l: It regulates the autonomic nervous system.
It relays most sensory signals to the cortex.

q.s: An adult with a healthy sleep cycle is most likely to enter REM sleep in which of the following ways?

o.l: after the dream stage is completed
after cycling through the NREM sleep stages
soon after falling asleep and then remain there for the majority of the night

q.s: Waking up frequently, loud snoring, silent pauses in breathing, and sleepiness during the day are symptoms of which of the following disorders?
Hyrum is at a concert when a flute player hits a very high note at the end of a song. Which of the following best explains why the pitch of the note sounds so high?

o.l: It has a long wavelength and high frequency.
It has a short wavelength and high frequency.
It has a long wavelength and low frequency.

q.s: Julia is practicing her trumpet and produces a loud sound. Which of the following is the best explanation for the loudness of the sound?

o.l: The sound has a long wavelength.
The sound has a short wavelength.
The sound has a high-amplitude sound wave.
The sound has a low-amplitude sound wave.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios most clearly describes the effects of a strong kinesthetic sense?

o.l: Developing a craving for a food after smelling it
Being able to tell exact bodily position without looking at the body
Being able to locate where a sound is coming from

q.s: Dr. Wilson, who teaches engineering classes, is interested in learning about how lack of sleep affects performance. What would be the best way to ensure that her findings are generalizable to all the students at her university?

o.l: Randomly assigning half the students in one of her classes she teaches at into a condition where they are told to sleep four hours a night and other half a condition in which they are told to sleep eight hours a night
Surveying every tenth student listed in the university directory about their sleep habits
Surveying all students in the classes she teaches
Studying 40 students over time, from their freshman year through their senior year, to see differences as the students mature

q.s: Samantha experienced a traumatic brain injury and afterward began to exhibit bizarre symptoms that no one had ever documented before. The best research method to study Samantha would be
tg: Practice:Practice 2: Research Methods and Design - Evaluate qualitative and quantitative research methods and study designs.
Skill:2.A: Determine the type of research design(s) used in a given study.
Learning Objective:1.4.A: Explain how the structures and functions of the brain apply to behavior and mental processes.

Essential Knowledge:1.4.A.6: Brain plasticity is the ability of the brain to rewire itself or modify or create new connections throughout development and generally allows for the function of a damaged part of the brain to be assumed by a different part of the brain.

q.s: Which study is a researcher who wants to draw correct cause-and-effect conclusions about the sense of smell likely to conduct?

o.l: A case study in which the researcher records a person’s facial expressions when the person encounters different smells and then determines that when a person smells a good smell, the person smiles.
A study in which 50 participants are asked to rate the degree to which different smells evoke happy memories. The researcher then determines which smells are associated with happy memories.

A study in which the researcher randomly selects two groups of 30 people and exposes one group to the smell of roses and the other group to the smell of gasoline to determine whether members of the group that smelled roses act nicer to one another afterward.

A study in which the researcher randomly assigns 50 people to a group that is exposed to a strong smell of roses and 50 people to a group that experiences an odor-free environment to see whether the group exposed to the strong smell of roses reports experiencing more memories.

tg: Practice:Practice 2: Research Methods and Design - Evaluate qualitative and quantitative research methods and study designs.
Skill:2.A: Determine the type of research design(s) used in a given study.
Learning Objective:1.6.D: Explain how the structures and functions of the chemical sensory systems relate to behavior and mental processes.

Essential Knowledge:1.6.D.1: Structures in the nose and brain process and/or transduce olfactory stimuli. Smell is the only sense not processed first in the thalamus of the brain. Pheromones produce chemical messages for the olfactory system.

q.s: Which of the following biological systems is most likely responsible for an increase in heart rate while experiencing anxiety?
tg: Practice:Practice 1: Concept Application - Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings.
Skill:1.A: Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings to a scenario.
Topic:1.2: Overview of the Nervous System
Learning Objective:1.2.A: Differentiate among the subsystems of the human nervous system and their functions.

Essential Knowledge:1.2.A.2: The peripheral nervous system relays messages from the central nervous system to the rest of the body and includes the autonomic and somatic nervous systems.<ol type="i" start="1"><li>The autonomic nervous system governs processes that are involu

q.s: Which of the following studies is from an evolutionary perspective?

o.l: A study to see if people who had a more congruent view of their real self and their ideal self were happier
A study to see if women were more attracted to men who liked children than men who did not like children
A study looking at how biological, psychological, and social factors affect development
A study looking at how quickly a variable-ratio schedule of reinforcement leads to extinction resistant behaviors

tg: Practice:Practice 1: Concept Application - Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings.
Skill:1.A: Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings to a scenario.
Topic:1.1: Interaction of Heredity and Environment
Learning Objective:1.1.A: Explain the relationship between heredity and environment in shaping behavior and mental processes.

Essential Knowledge:1.1.A.2: The evolutionary perspective explores how natural selection affects the expression of behavior and mental processes to increase survival and reproductive success. Some theorists have sought to apply principles of the evolutionary perspective in w

q.s:
Dr. Naum is studying the function of the temporal lobe of the brain by examining the case study of J.S., an individual who incurred damage in this area during a motor vehicle accident. Dr. Naum administers a battery of tasks multiple times over the course of several weeks to assess J.S.’s cognitive abilities. The graph below shows J.S.’s performance on three different tasks. The bar on the left shows his accuracy forming new memories in a lab context, the middle bar shows his accuracy on a driving course, and the bar on the right shows his accuracy on a third task.

Based on the scores on the three tasks, Task 3 most likely involves

o.l: recalling the names of all his cousins
matching photos of his aunts and uncles with their siblings
remembering events that occurred shortly before his accident
holding a random string of numbers in memory for several seconds

tg: Learning Objective:1.4.A: Explain how the structures and functions of the brain apply to behavior and mental processes.

Essential Knowledge:1.4.A.4: The cerebral cortex is divided into two hemispheres and includes the limbic system (thalamus, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, hippocampus, amygdala), corpus callosum, and the lobes of the cortex.<ol type="i" start="1"><li>The occipital lobes gener
Practice:Practice 3: Data Interpretation - Evaluate representations of psychological concepts in quantitative and qualitative research, including tables, graphs, charts, figures, and diagrams.
Skill:3.C: Interpret quantitative or qualitative inferential data from a given table, graph, chart, figure, or diagram.

q.s: Which of the following identifies the part of the nervous system the arrows are pointing toward?
Which psychological principle is represented in the area highlighted in the graph?

o.l: The refractory period of the neural transmission process.
Spontaneous recovery of a classically conditioned response

q.s: The figure shows the myelin sheath, a semipermeable membrane that provides support and helps speed up the action potential in neurons. What condition occurs when the immune system causes the deterioration of the myelin sheath?
The graph depicts which of the following?
A group of researchers collected the data displayed in the graph. Which of the following psychological concepts is most likely the focus of the research?

o.l: The role of the brain in personal success
The influence of psychoactive drugs on intelligence
The role of cultural bias on intelligence testing

tg: Practice:Practice 3: Data Interpretation - Evaluate representations of psychological concepts in quantitative and qualitative research, including tables, graphs, charts, figures, and diagrams.
Topic:1.1: Interaction of Heredity and Environment
Learning Objective:1.1.A: Explain the relationship between heredity and environment in shaping behavior and mental processes.
Skill:3.A: Identify psychology-related concepts in descriptions or representations of data.

Essential Knowledge:1.1.A.1: Heredity and environmental factors interact to shape behavior and mental processes.<ol type="i" start="1"><li>Heredity, or "nature," refers to genetic or predisposed characteristics that influence physical, behavioral, and mental traits and proce

q.s: Dr. Gomez conducts research looking at similarities in identical twins. In one study, she is interested in looking at athletic ability. What do the results in the graph indicate?

o.l: When one twin demonstrates high athletic ability, the other does not.
When one twin demonstrates high athletic ability, so does the other twin.
When one twin demonstrates high athletic ability, the other twin sometimes does and sometimes does not.
When one twin demonstrates high athletic ability, it causes the other twin to have high athletic ability as well.

tg: Practice:Practice 3: Data Interpretation - Evaluate representations of psychological concepts in quantitative and qualitative research, including tables, graphs, charts, figures, and diagrams.
Topic:1.1: Interaction of Heredity and Environment
Learning Objective:1.1.A: Explain the relationship between heredity and environment in shaping behavior and mental processes.
Skill:3.C: Interpret quantitative or qualitative inferential data from a given table, graph, chart, figure, or diagram.
Essential Knowledge:1.1.A.3: Research on the effects of genes on individual behavior and mental processes is often conducted using twin studies, family studies, and adoption studies.

q.s:
Taste and Smell

Volunteers were asked to rate the taste of foods during allergy season on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 meaning low intensity of flavor and 10 meaning high intensity of flavor. The researchers also asked participants to rate their level of nasal congestion on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 meaning no nasal congestion and 10 meaning complete blockage of airways with congestion. Which of the following is an appropriate conclusion to draw from the data presented in the scatterplot?

o.l: The experience of flavor is not related to the ability to smell.
The experience of flavor is negatively correlated with levels of nasal congestion.
The experience of flavor is positively correlated with levels of nasal congestion.
Nasal congestion causes our sense of taste to improve.

q.s:
The table shows players’ ratings of the level of pain they experienced while using their heads to make goals with a soccer ball. Measures were first taken during practice without an audience and later in front of a crowd during warmups prior to a game.

Level of Pain Experiencing Using the Head to Make Goals

  In Practice No Audience Warming Up for Game with Crowd
Player 1 7 3
Player 2 6 2
Player 3 7 5
Player 4 5 2
Player 5 4 3
Player 6 7 3

What is the average level of pain experienced by the players during practice without an audience?

Degree First Observed Movement Degree First Observed Color
23 degrees 51 degrees

Researchers were interested in whether the rods or the cones in the retina were more sensitive to detecting the movement and the color of objects in the environment. Research participants were asked to stare at a focus point while the researcher, starting at 0º, moved a red-colored object slowly around the edge of the arc apparatus. The degree of the angle when the participants first observed movement and color were documented. The mean degrees for each are presented in the table. Which of the following conclusions is best supported by this data?

o.l: The average angle the participant first notices movement will be larger than the average angle for first noticing the color.
The average angle the participant first notices the color will be larger than the average angle for first noticing movement.
The average angle the participant first notices the color will be the same as the average angle for first noticing movement.
There is not enough evidence to predict how each person will perceive based on the photoreceptors of the retina.

q.s: Which of the following is true about Dr. Copeland’s study?

o.l: Dr. Copeland is conducting an experiment.
Dr. Copeland is conducting a case study.
Dr. Copeland is using meta-analysis to test her hypothesis.
Dr. Copeland is using a correlational method.

f.c: Dr. Copeland is interested in studying how diet impacts the nervous system activity of professional dancers. She randomly assigns a group of professional ballet dancers to either a protein-rich diet or a carbohydrate-rich diet. After three weeks on each food plan, she measures the function of specific parts of the brain and nervous systems while they are dancing.

tg: Practice:Practice 2: Research Methods and Design - Evaluate qualitative and quantitative research methods and study designs.
Skill:2.A: Determine the type of research design(s) used in a given study.
Topic:1.2: Overview of the Nervous System
Learning Objective:1.2.A: Differentiate among the subsystems of the human nervous system and their functions.

Essential Knowledge:1.2.A.2: The peripheral nervous system relays messages from the central nervous system to the rest of the body and includes the autonomic and somatic nervous systems.<ol type="i" start="1"><li>The autonomic nervous system governs processes that are involu

q.s:
Dr. Handler conducted research to explore the extent to which hearing acuity changes with age. She tested the absolute threshold for hearing in 10 subjects of various ages. The results are presented in the table.

Subject Age Highest frequency of sound detected (Hz)
1 15 18,000
2 65 10,500
3 45 13,250
4 80 8,000
5 18 17,500
6 35 15,000
7 55 11,500
8 26 22,000
9 63 9,400
10 41 16,300

Which of the following is an appropriate conclusion based on the data presented in the table?

o.l: There is no relationship between age and pitch perception.
There is a causal relationship between age and pitch perception.
As age increases, the ability to detect higher pitched sounds tends to decrease.
No conclusions can be drawn because the subjects were not randomly assigned.

q.s: Dr. Copeland found that ballet dancers on a carbohydrate-rich diet had greater activity levels in the somatic nervous system. Which is a prediction that can be made from these findings?

o.l: The nervous system activation of untrained dancers on carbohydrate-rich diets would be similar.
The nervous system activation for any other type of dancers on carbohydrate-rich diets would be similar.
The dancers will make fewer mistakes on the carbohydrate-rich diet.
The dancers will make fewer mistakes on the protein-rich diet.

f.c: Dr. Copeland is interested in studying how diet impacts the nervous system activity of professional dancers. She randomly assigns a group of professional ballet dancers to either a protein-rich diet or a carbohydrate-rich diet. After three weeks on each food plan, she measures the function of specific parts of the brain and nervous systems while they are dancing.

tg: Practice:Practice 2: Research Methods and Design - Evaluate qualitative and quantitative research methods and study designs.
Skill:2.B: Evaluate the appropriate use of research design elements in experimental methodology.

q.s:
In an experiment, participants sat at a computer and were told to focus on an X on the screen for 50 milliseconds. After this, a horizontal or vertical line was presented for 100 milliseconds. Participants were instructed to press a button every time a horizontal line appeared. Participants in the Reward condition received ten cents for each time they correctly pressed the button when the horizontal line appeared, while participants in the Punishment condition started the experiment with $10 and lost ten cents every time they incorrectly pressed the button when there was no horizontal line. The results are given in the table.

  Reward Condition Punishment Condition
Hits 54 42
Misses 10 40
False Positives 36 18

Which of the following is the best conclusion based the data in the table?

o.l: Participants in the Reward condition are more likely to report seeing a horizontal line even when there isn’t one.
Participants in the Punishment condition do not report seeing the target stimulus on the majority of trials.
Participants are more likely miss the target stimulus than to report seeing it when it isn’t there.
Participants in the Reward condition are less likely to report seeing a horizontal line even when there isn’t one.

q.s: Which of the following is most relevant to digesting carbohydrate-rich meals and resting after dance practice?

f.c: Dr. Copeland is interested in studying how diet impacts the nervous system activity of professional dancers. She randomly assigns a group of professional ballet dancers to either a protein-rich diet or a carbohydrate-rich diet. After three weeks on each food plan, she measures the function of specific parts of the brain and nervous systems while they are dancing.

Neurologists trying to find a treatment for Alzheimer’s disease selected 100 individuals with moderate to severe symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease. Fifty participants were randomly placed into either an experimental condition that received a new medication that acted as an agonist for acetylcholine or the control condition which continued to receive same care as before. The study lasted for ten weeks at which time members of both groups took a cognitive assessment to determine their level of functioning. Which of the following best explains the operational definition of the dependent variable in this study?

o.l: The group that received the new medication.
The group that continues with their treatment as before.
How the participants were placed into their respective groups.
The score on the cognitive assessment.

q.s: A researcher is interested in measuring adrenaline levels in male subjects and then comparing those levels to each participant’s corresponding level of aggression. The researcher takes blood samples from each male participant to identify their adrenaline levels, and then gives each participant a survey that measures aggression. The results of the study indicate that higher levels of adrenaline were associated with higher rates of aggression. Which of the following best describes why the researcher cannot report a causal relationship in this study?

o.l: There was no manipulation of an independent variable.
The sample was not large enough to be representative.
There is no operational definition of aggression.
There is no reliable way to measure testosterone in the subjects.

q.s: Dr. Jones conducted a study in which he surveyed participants and compared their reported levels of physical activity to their measures of brain plasticity. Dr. Jones concludes that higher levels of physical activity cause a greater degree of neuroplastic changes in the brain. He plans to publish his findings. What mistake is Dr. Jones making in his research conclusion?

o.l: Dr. Jones’s study was correlational, so it cannot generate a causal conclusion.
Dr. Jones did not fully debrief participants of his findings at the conclusion of the study.
Dr. Jones plans to publish his research findings without peer review.
Dr. Jones did not operationally define how he measured levels of physical activity.

q.s: Dr. Popoca studied the characteristics of individuals experiencing red-green and yellow-blue color vision deficiency. They recruited one individual with each type of color vision deficiency and assessed each person three times per week for a period of three months. They found that all of the participants in their study were left-handed. Following their research, Dr. Popoca concludes that all individuals who experience dichromatism are left-handed. Why is their conclusion inappropriate based on their research strategy?

o.l: Dr. Popoca has assumed that correlation implies causation.
Dr. Popoca’s study did not include the use of random assignment, therefore they cannot draw a conclusion about the differences between their subjects.
Dr. Popoca has conducted a case study, which cannot be generalized to the population.
Dr. Popoca has not operationally defined their variables.

When they found each other through DNA tracking, they were surprised to see how different they were. Which research method would a psychologist most likely use to document their behavioral differences?

Mark and Matt are twins. A psychologist studies Mark and Matt from birth until their 25th birthday. The psychologist gathers data about their likes and dislikes, extracurricular activities, school success, and doctor visits. The psychologist is interested in the interaction of nature and nurture on their development. Which of the following research methods is the psychologist using to study Mark and Matt?
Much of the research regarding the function of brain areas has been gathered from case studies of individuals with brain injury or disease. Which of the following identifies a reason for this?

o.l: Quantitative research studies cannot demonstrate cause and effect between variables.
The independent variable in an experiment would inflict brain injury, which is unethical.
There would be no relationship between an injured area of the brain and the functioning of that respective area.
It is not possible to find enough participants to conduct a proper qualitative research study.

q.s: An institutional review board (IRB) rejected a proposal for research where participants requesting to lesion Wernicke’s Area in otherwise healthy individuals to study the resulting speech comprehension issues. Which of the following is the most likely ethical consideration for rejecting the study?
Which of the following parts of the brain was severed to address Arjun’s epileptic seizures?

f.c:
Below is a transcript of a case study about an individual named Arjun.

Arjun was diagnosed with epilepsy and struggled with seizures regularly. After trying multiple unsuccessful treatments, his neurologist recommended surgery that severed the connections between the two hemispheres of the brain. Arjun agreed to the surgery.

After surgery, Arjun experienced changes that were noticed during special testing in a laboratory setting by a researcher. In the laboratory, psychologists flashed different images or words to his left and right visual fields. Arjun could easily speak the names of items that were flashed to his right visual field. He could not easily speak the names of items that were flashed to this left visual field. Arjun was studied by a researcher for many years, and his experiences went unchanged. The researcher published the research with Arjun where he shared Arjun’s experience and his first and last name.
