The physiological changes in the table most clearly represent activation of which of the following?

A researcher studied rats to determine the effectiveness of a new drug on acetylcholine receptor sites. First, the rats were trained to find a reward at the end of a maze. Next, the rats were randomly assigned to two groups. One group of rats were injected with the new acetylcholine-like drug. The second group of rats were injected with a saline solution. Finally, researchers measured how many mistakes the rats made as they navigated the maze. Which of the following research methods was used by the researchers?

A small sample of living neural tissue is being studied under a powerful microscope. The researcher notices that some of the neural cells have connections to capillaries and seem to nourish and support the other neural cells. What type of research is being conducted?

A researcher discovered a chemical compound that seems to slow down the heart rate of monkeys by targeting an area of the medulla. The researcher believes that the compound could help reduce the symptoms associated with panic disorder. Which of the following is the appropriate next step for the researcher to take after developing the compound into a new drug?

o.l: Immediately begin giving the drug to humans to test its effects.
Publish the findings in an appropriate journal and see if the results can be replicated.
Report the findings to a reputable pharmaceutical company to apply for a patent.
Apply to an institutional review board (IRB) to begin animal trials for the drug.

q.s: Researchers conducted an experiment on baboons by inserting a wire into the reticular activating system (RAS) that produced a mild electrical current. The researchers stimulated the RAS while the baboons were performing different tasks. Which of the following operational definitions would be most easily replicated by other researchers trying to duplicate the experiment?

o.l: The baboons were observed to see if they were more awake after they had the RAS stimulated.
The baboons’ heart rates were measured by a monitor attached to their chest before and after the RAS was stimulated.
The baboons enjoyed a food reward after the mild electrical current was experienced.
The baboons were observed to see if they were more aggressive after having the RAS stimulated.

q.s: Which of the following is a testable hypothesis using operational definitions about people who have undergone split-brain surgery to help control severe epilepsy?

o.l: Split-brain patients will not be able to name an object placed in their left visual field.
Split-brain patients will no longer appreciate art following the surgery.
Split-brain patients will have very vivid dreams following the surgery.
Split-brain patients will be more amused by jokes following the surgery.

q.s: Respond to all parts of the question.

f.c:
Question Instructions:

Your response to the question should be provided in four parts: A, B, C, and D. Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology in your response.

Using the source provided, respond to the following questions. 

  1. Identify the research method used in the study.

  2. State the operational definition of addiction.

  3. Describe the meaning of the percentages presented in the “hourly wage of those who are employed” category of demographic data.

  4. Identify one ethical guideline described in the study. Describe one way the researchers in the study applied this ethical guideline.

Source

Introduction

The purpose of this study is to identify factors that make a substance abuse recovery program successful. Researchers identified a long-term program that provided housing, life-skills training, and several types of counseling for women with a history of trauma for this study.

Participants

Thirty-nine women who were previous residents of the long-term recovery program participated in group interviews about their experiences in and perceptions of the program. All participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could withdraw from participation at any time. The research was approved by a committee of professionals to ensure the appropriateness of the study. Demographic information about the participants is given in the table.

Variable Number of Participants Percent of Participants
Age    
  29 or less 10 26.3%
  30 to 49 12 31.6%
  50 or older 16 42.1%
Race/ethnicity    
  African American 35 89.7%
  Mixed Race 3 7.7%
  White 1 2.6%
Employment: “Are you currently employed?”    
  Yes 28 71.8%
  No 11 28.2%
Hourly wage of those who are employed    
  $10.00-$12.99/hour 12 54.5%
  $13.00-$15.99/hour 6 27.3%
  $16.00 and higher/hour 4 18.2%
Number of children    
  1 to 3 23 69.9%
  4 to 8 11 30.6%

Method

The recovery program viewed “recovery” as focusing on reducing the harm caused to an individual’s health and well-being by the misuse of substances. This view of recovery focuses on social causes of substance use and abuse, such as poverty, physical or emotional abuse in one’s home, or homelessness, and teaching people how to deal with those stressors through more healthful ways of thinking and behaving. The women participated in four group interviews over a six-month period that were recorded and transcribed word-for-word. Researchers ensured that the individual participants could not be identified from the data collected. A team of three researchers analyzed the recordings and transcripts. Researchers developed a code manual that “organized the data for accurate interpretation” across all three researchers. Researchers first developed a list of codes that corresponded to common aspects of successful recovery programs. Then, as the responses were read, the researchers would categorize each response with an existing code. Researchers would add a new code for each new topic the participants brought up in their responses.

Results and Discussion

Four major themes for successful recovery programs emerged from the participants’ responses based on the most frequently occurring codes:

Knowledge of addiction as a disease – Participants shared that they did not often realize that their substance use could be classified as an addiction. The researchers coded participant responses that referenced overuse or “abusive” use of substances as indications of addiction.

Importance of social support and support groups – Participants shared the importance of three main kinds of social support: 1) family and friend support; 2) organized support groups, and 3) support from other participants in the recovery program. Attending support groups while living in the recovery program helped women develop positive support and broke down barriers to recovery like lack of transportation, childcare, or accountability.

Peace of mind that comes from a new lifestyle – Participants shared that while their lives were not stress-free, they felt a sense of peace by not using substances. The participants reported that being in the program taught them ways to reconsider their responses to stress more effectively, leading to a sense of peace instead of turmoil.

Desire to maintain recovery – Many participants reported that they wanted to maintain their new substance-free lifestyles. One participant reported that “I’m going to do whatever it is I have to do to make sure that we [she and her child] don’t ever have to go back to that [being homeless and abusing substances].”

After categorizing the responses from the participants into these four categories, the researchers believe that the participants’ responses show that the program had a positive impact on the participants’ recovery. The researchers recommend that programs follow a similar model of recovery to improve outcomes for women experiencing substance use disorders.

Adapted from Experimental and Clinical Psychopharmacology.Krueger, E., Deal, E., Lopez. A.A., Dressel, A.E., Del Carmen Graf, M., Schmitt, M., Hawkins, M., Pittman, B., Kako, P., & Mkandawire-Valhmu, L. (2022). Successful substance use disorder recovery in transitional housing: Perspectives from African American women. Experimental and Clinical Psychopharmacology, 30(5). 714-724.

tg: Practice:Practice 2: Research Methods and Design - Evaluate qualitative and quantitative research methods and study designs.
Skill:2.A: Determine the type of research design(s) used in a given study.
Skill:2.C: Evaluate the appropriate use of research design elements in non-experimental methodologies.
Practice:Practice 3: Data Interpretation - Evaluate representations of psychological concepts in quantitative and qualitative research, including tables, graphs, charts, figures, and diagrams.
Skill:3.B: Calculate and interpret measures of central tendency, variation, and percentile rank in a given data set.
Topic:1.3: The Neuron and Neural Firing
Learning Objective:1.3.C: Explain how psychoactive drugs affect behavior and mental processes.
Essential Knowledge:1.3.C.3: Psychoactive drug use can lead to tolerance and/or addiction. Addiction can create significant withdrawal symptoms if the psychoactive drugs are no longer consumed.

q.s: Researchers conducted a correlational study during the winter season, which has shorter days and longer nights. The researcher asked about people’s experiences with depression-like symptoms, including feelings of tiredness and reduction in energy output. The researcher found that there was a positive correlation between the amount of daylight and depression-like symptoms. Which of the following statements best reflects how to interpret this correlational finding?

o.l: There is a cause-and-effect relationship between the length of daytime and depression-like symptoms.
The variables used in correlational research such as daylight and depressive symptoms are not measurable.
The relationship between daylight and depressive symptoms may also be linked to a third variable.
Correlation studies about mental health offer little in the way of scientific knowledge.

q.s: Ms. Harrison asks students in her psychology class to record how many hours of sleep they get every night and what they eat for breakfast. When the class looks at the data, they find that the fewer hours of sleep they get, the more they eat for breakfast. Which of the following is a limitation of self-report research?

o.l: Self-report results are generalizable to a large group
Careful control of the self-report variables means the data are unusable
Self-report data is subject to the social desirability bias
The artificial constraints of self-report mean the data aren’t meaningful.

q.s: A researcher wants to examine how much information from waking life ends up in dreams. The researcher recruits 40 volunteers from a local community college to record the details of their daily activities. The participants will be given a sleep monitor that gently wakes them each time they end an REM cycle, after which they will complete a detailed dream diary. The study is planned to last for two weeks. Why would an institutional review board be hesitant to approve this study?

o.l: This type of research should be done with animal subjects.
The researchers are disrupting sleep for an extended period, which may cause harm.
The researchers would not be able to hide the identities of the participants.
The researchers would be using deception without debriefing.

q.s: What type of research study did Dr. Schmidt conduct?

f.c: Dr. Schmidt was interested in the relationship between sensation of a stimulus and the sensation of change in a stimulus. She tested this using sensation of weight. Participants were blindfolded and given two equal weights to hold one in each hand. With each trial, she added a slightly heavier weight to one hand than the other. The participant was asked to notify her if or when one felt heavier. She found that it was more difficult for the participants to determine the difference in the weights when the equal weights from the first trial were heavy.

q.s: What was the independent variable in this research study?

o.l: Comparison of the weights in both hands

f.c: Dr. Schmidt was interested in the relationship between sensation of a stimulus and the sensation of change in a stimulus. She tested this using sensation of weight. Participants were blindfolded and given two equal weights to hold one in each hand. With each trial, she added a slightly heavier weight to one hand than the other. The participant was asked to notify her if or when one felt heavier. She found that it was more difficult for the participants to determine the difference in the weights when the equal weights from the first trial were heavy.

q.s: Dr. Schmidt’s findings best support which of the following psychological concepts?

f.c: Dr. Schmidt was interested in the relationship between sensation of a stimulus and the sensation of change in a stimulus. She tested this using sensation of weight. Participants were blindfolded and given two equal weights to hold one in each hand. With each trial, she added a slightly heavier weight to one hand than the other. The participant was asked to notify her if or when one felt heavier. She found that it was more difficult for the participants to determine the difference in the weights when the equal weights from the first trial were heavy.

q.s: Dr. Ravi wants to conduct a study to investigate the effect of sleep deprivation on problem-solving abilities. Her procedure involves randomly assigning participants to groups and depriving one group of sleep for a period of five consecutive days. She then had each of them take a test that measures their ability to solve various problems. Which of the following is most problematic about Dr. Ravi’s research design?

o.l: There is no dependent variable in this study.
The study raises ethical concerns because the amount of sleep deprivation could be harmful to participants in the study.
There would be no way to create a control group for comparison.
The results would be invalid because everyone has different problem-solving abilities.

q.s: A psychological study to determine the harmful effects of sleep disruption asked a company to start an overnight shift without notice. Many of the employees began to have accidents while on the job. The researchers conclude that a sudden change in circadian rhythm causes an effect on job performance. What ethical concern may be present in this study?

o.l: There are some people that are “night owls,” and they would bias the study.
The researchers did not have a clear independent variable in the study.
The researchers didn’t consider the normal number of accidents that already occurred in the factory.
The employees did not provide informed consent and were not given the option to withdraw from the study.

q.s: Dr. Felder is studying whether the color of a drink impacts how a person experiences the taste of the drink. She has an orange-flavored liquid that she dyes either orange, purple, or blue, and gives it to participants to drink. She then asks them to describe the taste. Which of the following would best help her evaluate the impact of vision on taste?

o.l: Have participants taste it as a group and take turns describing the taste out loud.
Obscure the purpose of the experiment until after participants have completed the study.
Create an additional control condition in which participants wear blindfolds while they taste the drink.
Use participants who have the same gender identity.

q.s: Researchers randomly assigned 50 elementary school children to place a plug on their nose to limit their sense of smell. The children were then presented with a series of different foods and asked to rate the taste, texture, and intensity on a scale from 1 to 5. Another 50 children were randomly placed in a group with no nose plug and asked to rate the same food using the same scale. Using random assignment in this study can help with which of the following?

o.l: Random assignment can eliminate the need for a control group.
Random assignment allows researchers to generalize the findings to the target population.
Random assignment to groups would allow researchers to understand if the differences between groups was due to the independent variable (the nose plug).
Random assignment will allow researchers to determine if the results are statistically significant.

q.s: Professor Belvedere wants to help her anatomy students memorize the names of different parts of the body. Which of the following techniques will best help her students?

o.l: Teaching them a rhyme for each word
Asking them questions about the meaning of each word
Writing the words in different colors and having the students think about the color that each word is printed in
Having them write sentences where each word of the sentence starts with the same letter as one of the parts of the body

tg: Learning Objective:2.3.A: Explain how the types, structures, and processes of memory work.

Essential Knowledge:2.3.A.5: The levels of processing model proposes that memory is encoded on three levels from shallowest to deepest: structural, phonemic, and semantic.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios is an example of retroactive interference?

o.l: After a car accident, Serena can no longer form new memories, though she can still remember things that happened before the accident.
Alexis believes that because she has played the lottery many times without winning, she is more likely to win than someone who has never played before.
Carl tries to remember the name of his first boss, but he cannot because he keeps thinking of the name of his current boss.
Raj just bought a new phone and keeps trying to turn it on by pushing the wrong button because the button is in the place where the on button was on his old phone.

tg: Practice:Practice 1: Concept Application - Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings.
Skill:1.A: Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings to a scenario.
Topic:2.7: Forgetting and Other Memory Challenges
Learning Objective:2.7.A: Explain possible reasons why memory failure or errors may occur.
Essential Knowledge:2.7.A.2: Many memories are difficult to retrieve due to encoding failure, interference (proactive or retroactive), or inadequate retrieval (i.e., tip-of-the-tongue phenomenon).

q.s: When Gustavo goes through lists of inventory items and thinks about whether each one is a fruit or not, he remembers more of the items on those lists later than when he goes through lists of inventory items and does not think about what each item is. Which of the following concepts best explains Gustavo’s performance?

o.l: Sensory memory, because he is activating information about his sensory experiences of fruit.
The spacing effect, because he is going through the list multiple times.
Elaborative encoding, because engaging in deeper processing improves memory.
Highly superior autobiographical memory, because Gustavo can remember vivid details for any day of his life.

tg: Practice:Practice 1: Concept Application - Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings.
Skill:1.A: Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings to a scenario.
Learning Objective:2.5.A: Explain how memory storage processes retain information in memory.

Essential Knowledge:2.5.A.2: Storage may be prolonged by rehearsing information over time (maintenance rehearsal). Rehearsing information over time in ways that promote meaning (elaborative rehearsal) helps with memory retention.

q.s: Mary has an IQ score within one standard deviation above the mean score. This indicates her score is best described as having which of the following qualities?

o.l: high enough for Mary to be considered a genius
higher than at least 75% of people who took the test
within the middle 68% of people who took the test
higher than exactly 93% of people who took the test

q.s: Audra is working on a puzzle book and comes across the following figure. Which of the following Gestalt laws would best explain Audra’s perception of the image?

To help himself remember the name of his new colleague, Hope, Jose thinks about the meaning of her name—the feeling of hopefulness. Which of the following concepts best corresponds to Jose’s strategy?

When studying for a vocabulary test, Catherine read one of her vocabulary words and its definition aloud several times. About twenty seconds later, she still remembered the word’s meaning, but then she moved on to the next word in the list without engaging in any further strategies to enhance her memory. The next day, she tested herself on the same vocabulary word at the same time, in the same mood, and in the same location as when she had first studied the word, but she could not remember its definition. It is most likely that Catherine could not remember the word because she failed to engage which of the following memory functions?

o.l: Sensory memory, because Catherine did not pair the word with one of her senses to remember it the next day.
Long-term memory, because Catherine failed to encode the word; therefore, the word did not become a part of her long-term memory.
Retrieval, because though Catherine probably stored the memory, it was difficult for her to retrieve it.
Context-dependent memory, because Catherine did not study the word in a variety of locations.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios is best explained by long-term potentiation?

o.l: Erik and Harry don’t like each other when they are first assigned to the same a room during a class trip, but after spending a great deal of time together, they begin to like each other more.
When Sruthi first enters a dark room after coming in from outside, she can’t see anything, but her eyes adjust after a few minutes.
At first, Benjamin needs to drink only a small amount of a caffeinated beverage to feel its effects, but after drinking it regularly for a while, he needs more to feel the same effects.
The first time Colleen tries to remember Leo’s name it takes her a long time, but over time she remembers it more quickly.

q.s: Which of the following best describes the primacy effect?

o.l: When people have better recall of things that occur at the beginning of a sequence
When people have better recall of things that occur at the end of a sequence

When people who know very little about a subject tend to be overly confident about how much they know about that subject, while people who know a great deal about the subject tend to downplay their knowledge about that subject
When people tend to rely too heavily on the first piece of information they get when making decisions

q.s: To remember a list of words, Jerry tries walking through his bedroom and making associations between words on the list and various areas he visits in his bedroom. Jerry is trying to improve his memory encoding by using which of the following memory concepts?

A teacher asks Yvonne to go to another classroom to get a student whom Yvonne has never met. As she walks, she repeats the student’s name to herself over and over to help her remember. Yvonne is boosting her memory by using which of the following memory concepts?
Short-term memory is best described in which of the following ways?

o.l: memory of how to perform an activity, such as riding a bike
memory of facts and general knowledge
memory that can hold only a small amount of information

q.s: David was studying some important historical dates for a test. He noticed that the day and month of one of the dates was the same as his own birthday, and he tried to use that fact to help him remember the date for his test. What is David using to enhance his memory?
Dr. Rudolph’s class has a big test coming up next week. Which of the following students is using a studying strategy that is most likely to lead to memory consolidation?

o.l: Marcus does not study until the night before the test, when he studies for eight hours straight.
Elizabeth studies for a half hour before she goes to bed each night the week before the exam.
Sharon does not study for the test, but she pays close attention, asks lots of questions, and takes good notes during class.
Mario studies by repeating his class notes to himself multiple times.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios involves using cued recall?

o.l: Letitia uses a mnemonic device to help her remember the names of all the lobes of the brain.
Steven studies a list of word pairs and is later given the first word of each pair and asked to recall the second word in the pair.
To help her remember what she needs from the grocery store, Marjorie imagines walking through her kitchen and visualizing what is missing.
Kumail scores well on a multiple-choice quiz because he recognizes all of the correct answers when he sees them.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios best demonstrates the role of context effects in memory?

o.l: Jonah tutored his classmate on a difficult concept, and now he understands the concept better than he did before tutoring his classmate.

Amy studied for a vocabulary test in the same classroom and at the same time of day as the normal class, and she performed better on the test than students who studied in different classrooms under different conditions.
Mateo studied for an anatomy exam while taking pain medication, which he did not take before the exam. He forgot many of the concepts that he learned when he was studying.
Dina could not remember the name of her second-grade teacher, but after she thought about the names of her classmates, the teacher’s name suddenly came to her.

q.s: After Doug witnessed two cars involved in a car accident, a police officer asked Doug how fast the cars were going when the accident happened. According to research by Elizabeth Loftus, which of the following questions could the officer ask that would make Doug most susceptible to the misinformation effect?

o.l: How fast were the cars going when the accident occurred?
How fast were the cars going when they smashed into each other?
What can you tell me about what you saw?
Were there other people around who witnessed the accident?

q.s: Which of the following is an example of the tip-of-the-tongue effect?

o.l: Marcus used to use words he knew were bad because his parents would pay attention to him whenever he did. When his parents learned to stop giving him attention in response to the bad words, he stopped using them for a few months. A few months later, though, he suddenly started using the bad words again.

Emma is telling her friend what she did over summer vacation when she discovers she cannot think of a specific word that she would like to say. She stops telling the story, because she has the distinct feeling that she is about to be able to think of the word if she waits just a moment.
After listening to a long list of words, Peter remembers the words that occurred near the end of the list more than the ones he heard earlier in the list.
When watching a video of a mouth saying the word “bag” while the word “gag” is played over speakers, Charlotte hears a word that sounds somewhere between the two words.

q.s:
Dr. Barry conducted a study in which participants were put into a driving simulator that mimicked the experience of driving a car on the highway. Participants were split into three groups:

  • The Silence condition, where participants drove in silence with no external distractions
  • The Radio condition, where participants listened to the radio while driving and were told they would be asked questions about what they heard after
  • The Cell Phone condition, where participants received text messages every 90 seconds and were told they would be asked questions about the messages after

At random intervals during the driving time, participants would see obstacles they needed to avoid, and the simulator would record how long it took the participants to hit the brake. The results of the study are given in the figure:

What conclusion could the researchers best draw from the results collected in the study?

o.l: Cell phones can lead to longer reaction times but having the radio on is equal to driving in silence.
Driving in silence impairs driving more than having some kind of background noise or activity.
Listening to the radio does impair a driver’s responsiveness, but not as much as paying attention to a cell phone.
Listening to the radio while driving doesn’t impact driving ability as long as the driver isn’t changing the station.

q.s:
Serial Position Effect

Dr. Darcy was interested in whether the primacy or recency effect leads to better memory recall. He conducted a study to test the difference using two randomly assigned groups of participants and the results are presented in the graph. Which of the following statements is true based on this information?

o.l: The recency effect leads to better memory recall than the primacy effect.
There is a negative correlation between the spacing effect and memory recall.
Participants recalled more items if the task required the primacy effect.
The data demonstrates the impact of the mnemonic devices on memory recall.

tg: Learning Objective:2.4.A: Explain how different encoding processes work to get information into memory.
Practice:Practice 3: Data Interpretation - Evaluate representations of psychological concepts in quantitative and qualitative research, including tables, graphs, charts, figures, and diagrams.

Essential Knowledge:2.4.A.4: The spacing effect is a process that can cause significant differences in encoding and memory consolidation depending on whether the information is encoded all at once (massed practice) or distributed over time (distributed practice).

q.s:
Number of Words Recalled Accurately

Dr. Storck randomly assigned a group of adults to two groups. Group A was asked to memorize a list of 20 words that are all names of food items. Group B was asked to memorize a list of 20 random words, none of which were names of food items. A week later, Dr. Storck asked the participants to memorize a new list of 20 words, all of which were the names of different food items. He recorded how many words each group recalled accurately. The data he collected are shown in the graph.

Which of the following best represents Dr. Storck’s likely hypothesis?

o.l: People are more likely to remember food words when they are hungry.
People are less likely to remember new food words after they have previously learned a list of food words.
People are likely to repress memories of words remembered more than a week prior to a recall test.
People are more likely to remember the source of information they learned when they are cued to remember the topic of what they learned.

In a study on visual perception, participants were presented with the figure depicted and asked to describe what they saw. Of the 100 participants in the study, 97 saw a cube. Which of the following Gestalt principles best describes the phenomenon that has impacted these results?

Prototype of a Mammal

Researchers repeatedly presented a picture of a goat along with other animals and asked participants to rank how closely the picture of the goat matched their prototype of a “mammal.” Participants used a scale of 1 to 5, with 1 meaning “not at all like my prototype of a mammal” to 5 meaning “exactly like my prototype of a mammal.” The graph depicts the rankings of each participant based on the number of exposures. What type of research has been conducted?
The graph is an illustration of which of the following?

Professor Jovan randomly assigns each student in her psychology class to one of three groups. Group X is required to post a journal entry each week in which they discuss some aspect of psychology in daily life. Group Y is required to take an online quiz about the material each week. Group Z was not instructed to do any additional activities. At the end of the class, Professor Jovan compares the final comprehensive exam scores for Groups X, Y, and Z. The results are shown in the figure. Which of the following psychological principles are best supported by the data in the figure?

o.l: Applying concepts to real-world situations improves learning.
Massed practice can be an effective study strategy in some situations.
Context-dependent memory is important for performing well in test situations.
Repeated testing can improve learning and memory.

q.s: At the end of each class period, Professor Dodgson asks each student to write on a notecard which concepts from the class period they understood, which ones they didn’t understand, and a plan for how they will approach learning any confusing concepts. This is not a required activity, but Professor Dodgson collects the cards and records which students complete them. The figure depicts student scores on the most recent test, along with how many notecards (out of 20) each student completed. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of the data depicted in the graph?

o.l: Students with high test scores did better because of the testing effect.
The difference in scores can be explained by the forgetting curve.
There is a negative correlation between writing note cards and class performance.
There is a positive relationship between the use of metacognitive practices and score on the test.

q.s: Alumni of a small high school where everyone knew each other were tracked down twenty years after their high school graduation. Next, they were asked if they knew the person’s name. Participants could only correctly name the person in the photograph 25% of the time. Which of the following is the dependent variable in the recall condition?

The number of “yes” responses to the recognition question.
How well they knew the individuals in the study.

q.s: Dr. Lofter is a professor of cognitive psychology at a university. He has been collecting data from student performances on tests throughout the school year. Every other test is formatted as either a fill-in-the-blank test, which relies on recall, or a multiple-choice test, which relies more on recognition. At the end of the year, Dr Lofter publishes the research findings in a journal on cognitive sciences showing how students perform better on recognition tests than recall tests. Which of the following ethical violations did Dr. Lofter commit?

o.l: Dr. Lofter’s students did not give informed consent to be a part of the research.
Dr. Lofter did not protect his students from harm.
Dr. Lofter did not give any other researchers an opportunity to replicate the study.
Dr. Lofter should never use their own students as research subjects.

Question Instructions:

Question 1:

Using the sources provided, develop and justify an argument about the impact of divided attention on performance of a task.

  1. Propose a specific and defensible claim based in psychological science that responds to the question.

  2. (i) Support your claim using at least one piece of specific and relevant evidence from one of the sources.

       (ii) Explain how the evidence from part B (i) supports your claim using a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology.

  3. (i) Support your claim using an additional piece of specific and relevant evidence from a different source than the one that was used in part B (i).

       (ii) Explain how the evidence from part C (i) supports your claim using a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology than the one that was used in part B (ii).

Source 1

Introduction

Psychologists have been interested in how human performance is affected by interference from stimuli in the environment. Researchers conducted two experiments to determine how much interference the color of the letters of the word affected people’s ability to identify either the word or the color of the letters (e.g., the Stroop task).

Participants

Experiment 1: 70 college undergraduates participated (14 men and 56 women).

Experiment 2: 100 students participated (88 undergraduates; 29 men and 59 women) and 12 graduate students (all women).

Experiment 1 tested how quickly participants could read the names of colors. The researcher used two sets of color-name stimuli in this study. The first set of color names (red, blue, green, brown, and purple) was printed in black ink.

The second set of color names (also red, blue, green, brown, and purple) was printed in a different color than the name of the color. No word in this set was printed in the color it named, but it was printed an equal number of times in each of the other four colors (e.g., the word “red” was printed in blue, green, brown, and purple inks; the word “blue” was printed in red, green, brown, and purple inks, etc.). Participants were to read the words in each list as fast as they could, ignoring the color of the ink in which the word was printed.

Experiment 2 tested how quickly participants could identify the color of the stimulus they were seeing. He used two sets of stimuli for this study. The first set of stimuli printed solid squares in each of the colors used in Experiment 1 (red, blue, green, brown, and purple). In the second set of stimuli, the words were again printed in a color that did not match the name of the color, as described in Experiment 1. Participants were to say the color of the square or of the letters in the word, ignoring the colors named by the words (e.g., where the word “red” was printed in blue ink, the correct response was “blue,” etc.).

For both experiments, participants were to read each item in the list without error. If they realized they made an error while reading an item, they were to correct their error as quickly as possible and move forward with the list. A researcher timed each participant using a stopwatch.

Results and Discussion

Experiment 1:

Fourteen participants (20%) left a total of 24 errors uncorrected for the Color Names – Different Ink task, with each participant making no more than 4 errors. Four subjects (5.7%) left one error each uncorrected on the Color Names – Black Ink task. The results are in the table.

Mean Time in Seconds for Reading 100 Names of Colors Printed in Colors Different from the Names of the Word and for 100 Names of Colors Printed in Black

Gender Number of Participants Color Names – Different Ink Color Names – Black Ink Difference
Men 14 43.20 40.81 2.41
Women 56 43.32 41.04 2.28
All participants 70 43.30 41.00 2.30

Experiment 2:

Fifty-nine participants (59%) left an average of 2.6 errors uncorrected for the Color of Word – Different Ink task. For the Color of Square task, 32 participants (32%) left an average of 1.2 errors uncorrected. The results are in the table.

Mean Time in Seconds for Naming 100 Colors Presented in Squares and 100 Colors Printed in Words which Name Other Colors

Gender Number of Participants Color of Word – Different Ink Color of Square Difference
Men 29 111.1 69.2 42.9
Women 71 107.5 61.0 46.5
All participants 100 110.3 63.3 47.0

The comparison of the results for Experiment 2 for naming the color of the squares vs naming the color of the letters making up the words (i.e., names of colors) indicates the strength of the interference of the habit of identifying words upon the requested activity of naming the colors of the letters instead.

Adapted from Stroop, J. R. (1935). Studies of interference in serial verbal reactions. Journal of Experimental Psychology, 18(6), 643–662. 

Source 2

Introduction

Prior research demonstrated that like other disruptive behaviors, such as arriving late or talking to classmates during lectures, in-class use of personal devices may negatively impact the classroom learning environment. This research examined associations between students’ attitudes toward in-class device use and learning outcomes.

Participants

Participants were 187 undergraduate students (63.1% women, 36.9% men; mean age = 20.7 years; standard deviation for age = 5.1; range of ages: 17 to 46) at a large urban public university in the northeastern United States.

Many students at the college are considered nontraditional based on age and other criteria (e.g., employment, financial independence). In line with the National Center for Education Statistics (2002, 2020), which uses age 24 years and older as an index of nontraditional undergraduate student status, we categorized students in our sample as traditional (ages 17–23 years; number of participants = 164; mode age of 18 years) or nontraditional (ages 24–46 years; number of participants = 23; mode age of 24 years).

Method

Over the course of the semester, students completed the following online assignments and surveys:

Attitudes toward in-class use of personal devices: This six-item survey was given only in Week 2 of the course at the beginning of the semester to assess student attitudes about in-class use of personal mobile devices in relation to learning (“I like to be able to use a personal mobile device during class time”) and whether instructors should permit such usage (“Students should be allowed to use personal mobile devices in the classroom to support their learning”). Participant responded using a 5-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 3 = neutral, 5 = strongly agree).

Concentrating and multitasking while completing schoolwork online: Also in Week 2, students were asked about their ability to concentrate online (“To what extent do you find it hard to concentrate and stay on task when completing course work online?”) and their multitasking behaviors (“To what extent do you multitask [e.g., watch TV or YouTube, check social media, etc.] while completing course work online?”). Participants responded using a 5-point scale (For the questions concerning concentration: “1 = very hard to concentrate, 3 = neither hard nor easy to concentrate, 5 = very easy to concentrate” For the questions concerning frequency of multitasking: “1 = very infrequently, 3 = neutral, 5 = very frequently”).

Multiple-choice quizzes: Multiple-choice quizzes were embedded in the online homework assignments administered during Weeks 4, 8, and 12. Each quiz contained 16 to 21 four-option multiple-choice questions on material from class lectures and used as review materials for upcoming tests. Quiz scores (% correct) were averaged across the three homework assignments and used as a measure of learning.

End-of-semester technology- and nontechnology-related distractibility: A three-item survey asked students to report the extent to which they were distracted by behaviors related to their own use of personal mobile devices (e.g., laptop, cell phone, tablet, etc.) in course-related contexts (“when completing online assignments, “when reading the textbook,” and “when attending the course”) and by nontechnology-related distractions (“people arriving late,” and “people around them chatting”). Participants responded using a 3-point scale for both contexts (“1 = not distracted, 2 = somewhat distracted, and 3 = very distracted”).

Results and Discussion

Students held neutral to positive views of in-class use of technology, and mostly agreed that instructors should permit their use. For the question “To what extent do you find it hard to concentrate and stay on task when completing course work online?”, most students held a neutral position but leaned toward saying it was somewhat easy to concentrate while studying online (mean = 3.42; standard deviation = 1.04).

In response to the question “To what extent do you multitask (e.g., watch TV or YouTube, check social media, etc.) while completing course work online?”, most students held a neutral view, indicating they multitasked neither frequently nor infrequently (mean = 3.14; standard deviation = 1.22). Researchers failed to find age-related differences in attitudes toward in-class technology use, although they found younger students reported higher rates of multitasking.

Age had a negative correlation with students’ self-reported multitasking and a positive correlation with quiz scores. Students’ multitasking tendencies were positively correlated with their attitudes about personal use of mobile devices in class. There was a strong positive correlation between attitudes about the amount of personal device use and how much mobile devices should be permitted in class.

Nontraditional students were less likely to report that they multitask online, and they also tended to perform better on the quizzes. However, these two variables (the extent to multitasking while online and quiz performance) were not significantly correlated with each other. Thus, researchers failed to find evidence that multitasking tendencies were on their own predictive of poor learning outcomes or associated with heightened distractibility.

There was a statistically significant relationship between better student performance on quizzes and lower self-reported level of distraction using personal mobile devices.

Adapted from Ober, T. M., Brodsky, J. E., Yannaco, F.D, and Brooks, P.J. (2023). College instructors’ and students’ views of the use (and misuse) of personal mobile devices. Scholarship of Teaching and Learning in Psychology, 9(1), 14-37. 

Source 3

Introduction

Students often attempt to perform many different tasks at once while attending class and while doing assigned homework. This practice impairs their academic achievement. This problem gets worse when students take online classes where they cannot be directly monitored by a teacher. Prior research has demonstrated that this tendency to do many things at once impairs our ability to recall information because it disrupts the process of getting new information into the memory system. This study investigated whether this negative impact could be reduced by having students use concepts stored in memory to practice what they have learned, instead of just rereading information they have already read in their textbook.

Participants

The participants were 60 Portuguese-speaking undergraduate students (15 men, 45 women; mean age = 20.75) from Brazil.

Method

The researchers used three, approximately 700-word-long texts, from a popular scientific journal written in Portuguese. From these seven passages were selected for students to read. While reading, students were interrupted by 3 cell phone messages. Immediately after reading the selected text, students completed a task that differed based on one of three groups to which they were randomly assigned.

Condition 1: Students read the selected passages while receiving 3 messages on their cell phone. After doing a 2-minute distraction task, students reread the 7 passages.

Condition 2: Students read the selected passages while receiving 3 messages on their cell phone. After doing a 2-minute distraction task, students answered 7 questions (short-answer recall) based on the passages.

Condition 3 (control): Students read the selected passages without distraction. After doing a 2-minute distraction task, students answered 7 questions (short-answer recall) based on the passages.

At the conclusion of this procedure, students in all groups were asked to report the extent to which they believed they would remember the content of the reading after one week. Researchers called this measurement the “judgment of learning,” or JOL. JOL was measured on a 10-point scale, ranging from 1 (I will remember 0% of the text) to 10 (I will remember 100% of the text).

After 7 days, students answered 21 questions drawn from the reading, including the practice items that Groups 2 and 3 had been exposed to previously.

Results and Discussion

The researchers found, as predicted, that the percentage of correctly recalled answers after one week was lower after multitasking. This indicated a slight negative short-term effect of media multitasking. The researchers found a positive effect 1 week later in the groups that were presented with the practice questions after reading the text.

Participants in Condition 1 recalled less information than those in Condition 2 and 3. However, against the researchers’ predictions, the latter two conditions led to equivalent success on the quiz given 7-days later. This suggests that the practice questions minimized the negative effects of media distractions.

Retrieving previously encountered information such as taking the quiz in this procedure, is a critical factor for promoting long-term recall of information compared to rereading text passages. This advantageous effect occurred even when to-be-recalled information was entered into the memory system for the first time while distracted by media. In fact, against the researcher’s hypothesis, practice led to equivalent beneficial effects whether information was learned with or without attempting to do multiple things simultaneously.

Adapted from Ekuni, R., Macacare, O.T., and Pompeia, S. (2022). Reducing the negative effects of multitasking on online or distance learning by using retrieval practice. Scholarship of Teaching and Learning in Psychology, 8(4). 269-278.

       For example: “According to Source 1, . . .”

Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Question 1:

Using the sources provided, develop and justify an argument about the relationship between being in an ordered or cluttered environment and creativity.

  1. Propose a specific and defensible claim based in psychological science that responds to the question.

  2. (i) Support your claim using at least one piece of specific and relevant evidence from one of the sources.

       (ii) Explain how the evidence from part B (i) supports your claim using a psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology.

  3. (i) Support your claim using an additional piece of specific and relevant evidence from a different source than the one that was used in part B (i).

       (ii) Explain how the evidence from part C (i) supports your claim using a different psychological perspective, theory, concept, or research finding learned in AP Psychology than the one that was used in part B (ii).

Source 1

Introduction

Researchers have investigated the effects of being in an orderly/tidy or disorderly/messy environment. In this study, researchers examined whether participants in a messy room would be more creative than participants in an orderly room. Researchers hypothesized that being in a disorderly room encourages people to break with a customary routine and frees them to be more creative.

Participants

Forty-eight American students participated.

Method

Participants were randomly assigned to complete a task in an orderly or disorderly room. Picture A shows the orderly condition and picture B shows the disorderly condition.

(A) Orderly/Tidy Condition

(B) Disorderly/Messy Condition

To measure creativity, participants completed an Alternative Uses Task. In this task participants listed up to 10 new uses for ping-pong balls.1Ping-pong balls are hollow, plastic spheres. Their diameter is about 1.6 inches/4 cm and weigh 0.09 ounce/2.7 grams.

Results and Discussion

Participants’ ideas were scored for their creativity. Two raters, unaware of the condition to which participants had been assigned, scored each idea on a 3-point scale (1 = not at all creative, 3 = very creative). If raters disagreed on a score, they resolved it through discussion. Creativity was measured both by averaging creativity scores for each participant and by counting the number of uses participants generated for ping-pong balls. The statistically significant findings are summarized in the table.

Condition: Average Creativity Scores: Mean Number of highly creative ideas
Messy room 1.80 1.0
Tidy room 1.41 0.21

Researchers believed that the results support their hypothesis that being in a messy room stimulates more creative ideas. In their opinion, being in a messy room disrupts a person’s customary routines resulting in more creative thinking. However, researchers acknowledge another explanation for their findings. It may be that being in a messy room violates participants’ expectations about what a room should look like and that might have increased participant creativity.

Adapted from Adapted from Vohs, K. D., Redden, J. P., & Rahinel, R. (2013). Physical Order Produces Healthy Choices, Generosity, and Conventionality, Whereas Disorder Produces Creativity. Psychological Science. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797613480186. 

Source 2

Introduction

In this study, researchers hypothesized that a messy environment influences the cognitive processes that allow individuals to experience critical thinking, thus enabling them to generate, organize, plan, and perform goal-directed behaviors more creatively. Evidence from prior studies suggests that being in a messy environment increases one’s ability to come up with more creative solutions with less reliance on preexisting ways of viewing the world. This study investigated the effect of messy work environments on creativity and these higher-level cognitive processes.

Participants

One hundred volunteers participated in the study (age: mean 22.89 years, standard deviation = 5.19, 69% women, 31% men, 81% right-handed, 19% left-handed).

Methods

The study was approved by an Institutional Review Board, and informed consent was obtained prior to participation.

Participants were randomly assigned to two adjacent classrooms; one classroom was tidy, and the other was messy. All participants first completed the Alternative Uses Task, in which they generated up to 10 unusual uses for an automobile tire in 5 minutes. Two raters measured the creativity of each participant on a 5-point scale (5 = higher creativity; 1 = lower creativity) by considering how commonplace, unusual, and clever the participant’s responses were. When the ratings of the independent raters were compared on their creativity scores, they were highly correlated.

To measure cognitive processing, participants completed additional tests. In one test, called a digit span task, participants were given a series of numbers and asked to repeat back what they had heard. In each subsequent trial a longer sequence of numbers was presented. The longest remembered sequence was the measure of the participant’s digit span. Researchers also included a letter fluency test, in which participants were given 1 minute to produce as many unique words as possible starting with a given letter, either “L” or “F.”

Participants were debriefed and compensated with either a $20.00 gift card or extra credit for their introductory psychology course at the completion of the study.

Results and Discussion

Researchers compared the creativity and cognitive processing measures between the tidy and messy conditions. Results indicated that working at a messy desk did not result in significant and reliable differences in creativity or in the performance of tasks related to higher level cognitive processing. The results from the described tests are summarized in the table.

Condition: Alternative Uses Task Creativity Mean Digit Span Mean Letter Fluency Mean Correct
Messy room 2.68 4.02 22.98
Tidy room 2.80 4.44 21.96

Researchers identified some possible limitations to their study that might explain the lack of statistically significant differences in the results obtained from the two conditions. One earlier study asked participants to develop alternative uses for a ping-pong ball using a 3-point creativity scale, while this study used an automobile tire, and a 5-point scale. However, this research used many different measures of creativity and of higher-level cognitive processing, and none showed the expected effect.

Adapted from Manzi, A., Durmysheva, Y., Pinegar, S. K., Rogers, A., & Ramos, J. (2019). Workspace Disorder Does Not Influence Creativity and Executive Functions. Frontiers in Psychology, 9(2662), 1-6. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2018.02662. 

Source 3

Introduction

An orderly environment can affect both an individual’s ability to control their behaviors and the amount of their creative thinking; however, little research has focused on the role personality factors may have in strengthening or weakening this effect. In this study, researchers investigated the effect of self-control as a stable personality trait which they believe influences both self-control behaviors and creative thinking.

Participants

Experiment 1: One hundred and sixty-three participants (127 women, 36 men, mean age 19.80 years, standard deviation = 1.7) volunteered to participate.

Experiment 2: One hundred and twenty-four participants (101 women, 23 men, mean age 20.38, standard deviation = 1.28) volunteered to participate in a follow-up experiment after being a part of Experiment 1. All participants were students at a university in China.

Method

The experiments were approved by the Institutional Review Board of the School of Psychology. Each participant signed an informed written consent form.

Experiment 1:

Participants completed a self-report survey to measure their typical level of self-control. Questions included statements such as, “I do certain things that are bad for me if they are fun,” and “I have self-discipline.” Each statement was evaluated from 1 “Not at all like me” to 5 “Very much like me.” Based on this survey, they were sorted into two levels of self-control, either “high trait self-control” or “low trait self-control.”

All participants were then asked to hold their breath “for as long as you are able or until you have to give up,” and the experimenter timed the duration with a stopwatch.

After establishing each participant’s breath-holding ability in a neutral space, participants were randomly assigned to either an orderly or a disorderly room. As pictured, in the orderly condition (A), books, pens, and other items were arranged in a structured and ordered way on a table. In the disorderly condition (B), the same quantity of items was scattered on the table or on the floor. Participants were asked to wait for one minute while the experimenter got materials ready, and then they were once again asked to hold their breath and data was collected.

(A) Orderly/Tidy Condition

(B) Disorderly/Messy Condition

Experiment 2:

The same participants from Experiment 1 were invited to take part in a follow-up experiment. They were randomly assigned to different conditions. As pictured, in the orderly condition (A), participants were shown a picture of a desk with well-organized items. In the disorderly condition (B), participants were shown a picture of a desk with the same items scattered on the table.

(A) Orderly/Tidy Condition

(B) Disorderly/Messy Condition

The participants imagined that they were in the scene. After 3 minutes, participants completed an Alternative Uses Task where they were asked to list as many “uncommon, creative, and unusual” uses of tires as possible within 3 minutes. Participants’ ideas were scored by five research assistants who were unaware of the different conditions to which each participant was assigned. Each response received a rating on a five-point scale (1 = low creativity, 5 = high creativity). Responses that scored more than 3 points, were labeled as “highly creative ideas.”

Results and Discussion

Experiment 1:

Researchers found that participants who scored low in trait self-control held their breath longer in the orderly room than in the disorderly room. There was no difference in breath-holding ability for participants who scored high in trait self-control when they were in either the orderly or disorderly room. These findings are represented in the graph.

Experiment 2:

For the participants with high trait self-control, those in the disorderly condition generated more creative ideas (mean = 1.62) than those in the orderly condition (mean = 1.00). This difference was statistically significant.

Researchers concluded that an orderly environment could have a positive influence on individuals’ self-control behaviors. However, this applied only to those with low trait self-control. In contrast, a disorderly environment can be beneficial to creative thinking, but this applied mostly for individuals with high trait self-control. The findings are represented in the graph.

Adapted from Li, Z., & Li, S. (2020). Environmental Orderliness Affects Self-Control and Creative Thinking: The Moderating Effects of Trait Self-Control. Frontiers in Psychology, 11, 1-13. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2020.01515.

tg: Practice:Practice 4: Argumentation - Develop and justify psychological arguments using evidence.
Practice:Practice 1: Concept Application - Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings.
Skill:1.A: Apply psychological perspectives, theories, concepts, and research findings to a scenario.
Topic:2.2: Thinking, Problem-Solving, Judgments, and Decision-Making
Learning Objective:2.2.A: Explain how psychological concepts and theories account for thinking, problem-solving, judgment, and decision-making.

Essential Knowledge:2.2.A.8: Creativity is a way of thinking that includes generating novel ideas and engaging in divergent (versus convergent) thinking. Creative thinking is hindered by functional fixedness.
Skill:4.B: Provide reasoning that is grounded in scientifically derived evidence to support, refute, or modify an established or provided claim, policy, or norm.

q.s: Respond to all parts of the question.

f.c:
Question Instructions:

Your response to the question should be provided in four parts: A, B, C, and D. Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology in your response.

Using the source provided, respond to the following questions. 

  1. Identify the research method used in the study.

  2. Describe the meaning of the difference in the means for the percent correct for the spoken syllable identification task and the timbre identification task.

  3. Propose a claim about the extent to which the research findings may or may not be generalizable.

  4. Propose a claim about how the research findings support or refute the concept of contralateral hemispheric organization.

Source

Introduction

In split-brain patients, sound presented in the left ear is processed by the right hemisphere while sound presented in the right ear is processed by the left hemisphere. Research with split-brain patients indicates that the processing of music is done more by the right hemisphere of the brain while language is processed more by the left hemisphere. Some research with split-brain patients also indicates that the processing of music can help with the processing of language, a phenomenon called the tonal function effect. This study explores whether this effect can be found in healthy listeners.

Participants

Right-handed college students with less than 3 years of music training were used for this study. None of the participants had any hearing impairments. The study included 48 participants (25 women; 23 men) with an average age of 21 years (standard deviation = 3.67).

Method

Researchers used a within-subjects design for this study. A within-subjects design means that each participant is observed in every condition of the study and therefore can be compared directly to themselves. This procedure serves the same purpose as random assignment. Participants were exposed to two different types of sounds at a safe decibel1Decibels measure how loud a sound is. range, one in each ear, and asked to correctly provide a specific detail about one of the sounds as they listened.

Spoken consonant-vowel syllables were the first type of sound. There were 12 sequences of 8 syllables, with the eighth syllable of each sequence being either /di/ or /du/. Musical chords were the second type of sound. There were 12 sequences of 8 chords, with the eighth chord of each sequence being called either Timbre A or Timbre B2Timbre, or the characteristic of a sound, allows the listener to distinguish different sounds from each other.. Participants were asked to identify either the last spoken syllable (/di/ or /du/) or the last chord (Timbre A or Timbre B). Timbre A was a chord that was “tonal,” meaning it was what a person would expect to come based on the previous chords in the sequence. Timbre B was a chord that was “subdominant,” meaning it would not be a chord a person would expect based on the previous chords in the sequence. The participants practiced identifying the syllables and chords prior to the start of the study. They had to identify the correct sound with 92% accuracy before moving on.

Participants completed 96 trials for the study. The breakdown of the ways the sounds were presented in each ear is presented in the table below.

  Timbre A Timbre B
/di/ 48 – left ear 48 – right ear
/du/ 48 – right ear 48 – left ear

The participants were told which sound to identify (syllable vs. chord) about halfway through the playing of the sounds in both ears.

Results and Discussion

Researchers hypothesized that “the tonal function effect would be stronger when musical sequences were presented to the left ear and speech sequences were presented to the right ear.”

Overall, participants were, on average, 97% accurate for spoken syllable identification and 86% accurate for timbre identification. Participants had significantly faster reaction times when identifying syllables presented to the right ear when the music presented in the left ear ended in a “tonal” chord instead of a “subdominant” chord, confirming the hypothesis.

Adapted from Neurophysiology.Hoch, L., & Tillmann, B. (2010). Laterality effects for musical structure processing: A dichotic listening study. Neurophysiology, 24(5). 661-666.
