q.s: What are the means for the dangerous, safe, and sports news story groups, respectively?

f.c:
A researcher wants to see if one’s worldview affects judgments of a crime victim. To do so, she randomly assigns participants to one of three groups. The first group reads a news story about how scientific advances, such as artificial intelligence, are making the world more dangerous. The second group reads a news story about how those same scientific advances are making the world safer. The third group reads a news story about a sports event the previous evening. After reading one of these stories, all participants then read another news story about a man who had been mugged on his way home from work. Participants evaluated the man who was the victim of this crime on a 1 meaning “The man is a really careful person” to 7 meaning “The man is a really careless person.” There were 4 participants in each group. The table below shows the ratings for each participant in each group.

Dangerous news storySafe news storySports news story
724

q.s:
Recognized Emotional Expression

Dr. Seymour wants to test her theory about the universality of emotional expressions. She shows her students various people’s faces and asks them to identify which of six emotional expressions is displayed. She records the accuracy of her students’ results in the graph. What of the following describes a theoretical perspective that best explains why there is a higher rate of accuracy for recognition of the emotional expressions of fear and anger?

o.l: The expressions for disgust, sadness, and happiness are similar, potentially leading to confusion among students.
The same facial muscles are used for all emotional expressions, so it was difficult for students to detect which emotional expression was displayed.
Because recognition of fear and anger may be related to survival mechanisms, we are more easily able to detect those emotional expressions.
The students are unfamiliar with the facial expressions associated with these various emotions, leaving them unable to recognize them with accuracy.

q.s:
In Dr. Hernandez’s study, participants read one of two versions of a story about a student who was preparing for a test. In the first version, the student studied for at least an hour each night for a week before the test. In the second version, the student crammed for an hour or two the night before. After reading the story, participants were given a list of vocabulary words and were told to study for as long as they needed to memorize at least 80% of them. They were then asked to rate on a scale of 1 to 10 how studious they were, with 1 meaning not studious at all and 10 meaning very studious. Dr. Hernandez tracked how long the participants took to study and their response to the questionnaire. The results are given in the table.

Story Read Avg. Amount of Time Studied (in mins) Avg. Rating of Studiousness
Study Each Night 40.3 3
Cramming 23.4 6.2

Assuming the results given in the table are statistically significant, what conclusion can Dr. Hernandez most accurately draw?

o.l: People who consider themselves to be studious think they need to prepare for tests less and so will spend less time preparing for them.
People identify with a character they read about, and their ratings of their studiousness will match the studiousness of the character in the story.
Participants who read study each night version learn good study habits from the story and that makes them study more and feel better about their studying.
Hearing about a student who studies a lot will lead people to think they study less and encourage them to study more.

q.s: Dr. Swan wants to learn if people’s emotional state is related to their ability to think of creative uses for common objects. To do so, she uses surveys to measure people’s current emotional state and then has those people list as many uses as they can think of for a pen, a coffee cup, and a sock. To increase the generalizability of these results, what should Dr. Swan do next?

o.l: Replicate the study by sampling a different population of people.
Use a double-blind rather than a single-blind procedure.
Debrief the participants after they complete her study materials.
Replicate the study using different common objects.

q.s:
Experts often debunk popular sleep myths such as, “Your brain and body can learn to function just as well with less sleep.” This is intended to help the public understand healthy habits related to sleep. Even with this evidence, some individuals dismiss the experts and continue with their unhealthy sleep habits thinking this is what works best.

Which of the following is demonstrated in this example?

One afternoon on a walk, Toni and his friend stopped to help a person lying on a cement sidewalk on a busy street. Just the day before, Toni walked right by a different stranger on the grass in a city park. Which of the following best explains Toni’s helping behavior for each of these scenarios?

o.l: Toni helped the person they perceived needed assistance.
Tony feels guilty when he doesn’t help others in need.
Tony did not know how to help the person on the grass, but he knew how to help the person on the sidewalk.
Tony felt less risk in helping the person on the sidewalk than he did the person on the grass.

q.s: Which of the following psychological concepts is demonstrated by the graph?

Helmut wants to see how membership in a criminal gang influences a new member’s behavior. He plans on observing the day-to-day behaviors of members of the criminal gang. Why might an Institutional Review Board (IRB) have ethical concerns about this study?

o.l: Helmut may observe illegal activities that force him to break confidentiality.
Gang members will not be able to provide informed consent.
If members provided consent, they would not have the right to withdraw from the study.
It would be difficult in the written report to keep the names of the participants anonymous.

q.s:
Researchers were interested in the effects of changing work schedules on a variety of behaviors. Employees from several companies who had recently changed from one work shift to another were surveyed. Some of the questions asked employees about day-to-day health-related behaviors such as calorie intake, bedtimes, and minutes spent exercising. Other questions asked the employees to write down what they were thinking about at specific times during the day.

Based on the questions asked, what types of data were the researchers collecting?

A psychologist develops a theory of how the personality develops by using case studies using his mostly female patients. What conclusion should be drawn from his reliance on case studies to develop his theory?

o.l: The psychologist discovered universal truths about human functioning.
The psychologist interviewed patients of all ages to insure broad applicability of his ideas.
The psychologist’s theories were likely biased because they were not based on a representative sample of people.
The small number of case studies he completed reduced the validity of the conclusions he drew.

q.s: Dr. Say reported that self-esteem in young girls appears to be related to time spent watching videos of women demonstrating makeup and hairstyling techniques. The correlation coefficient was -0.63. Which of the following describes the relationship between the variables?

o.l: The more viewing time, the lower the self esteem
The less viewing time, the lower the self esteem
The greater the difficulty of the techniques viewed, the lower the self esteem
The lower the difficulty of the techniques viewed, the higher the self esteem

q.s:
Participant Preferred $5 Today Preferred $15 Later
A Y N
B Y N
C Y N
D Y N
E N Y
F Y N
G Y N

After participants complete a survey, Dr. Wright examines people’s ability to delay gratification by paying them $5 today for their survey, or $15 a week later for completing the survey. The results are presented in the table. If Dr. Wright were a researcher working from the psychodynamic perspective, which of the following best describes how he would explain why the participants preferred $5 today?

o.l: The participants were projecting their feelings on the researcher.
The participants received instant reward, which is stronger than a delayed reward.
The participants were susceptible to the gambler’s fallacy, meaning they underestimated their chances of getting more money later.
The participants were driven by unconscious drives that were first acquired in childhood.

q.s: In a distribution of data comparing scores on the Big Five personality test, the mean, mode, and median of the distribution were the same. Which of the following best describes what the graph of this data would look like?

Mean Standard deviation
Freshmen 6 4.3
Sophomores 7 4.1
Juniors 8 3.6
Seniors 9 2.2

Each year Maslow High School administers a self-actualization scale to all their students. The table provides students’ scores on the scale. Based on the data, which of the following statements is true?

o.l: The range of the mean scores is 7.5.
The scores of the freshmen are more spread out than the seniors’ scores.
The mean score and the standard deviation score are positively correlated.
The data is qualitative, so it is difficult to establish significance.

q.s: A researcher is interested in studying extraversion. They plan to give students from a local college a questionnaire and observe them interacting with others in different classrooms for two weeks. Which of the following might be a possible confounding variable in this study?

o.l: The grade point averages of the participants

q.s: Maggie’s conclusion about Brayden’s intelligence best reflects which of the following concepts?

f.c:
Jose and Maggie are discussing the results of their recent chemistry exam.

Jose: I got a 97% on the test.

Maggie: Congratulations! I did well, too – I got a 95%! I wonder how Brayden did on the test.

Jose: I heard he got a 53% on it, but he had like three tests that day.

Maggie: Well, he’s not the smartest student in our grade. I’m not surprised he got a low score.

q.s: Given the information in this scenario, which of the following future behaviors from Brayden will Maggie be most likely to remember?

o.l: Brayden does well on his next chemistry test.
Brayden does well on an exam in a different class.
Brayden slips on the ice walking to class.
Brayden helps a classmate find a room on campus.

f.c:
Jose and Maggie are discussing the results of their recent chemistry exam.

Jose: I got a 97% on the test.

Maggie: Congratulations! I did well, too – I got a 95%! I wonder how Brayden did on the test.

Jose: I heard he got a 53% on it, but he had like three tests that day.

Maggie: Well, he’s not the smartest student in our grade. I’m not surprised he got a low score.

q.s: The process that Maggie used to draw a conclusion about Brayden’s intelligence most closely resembles of which the following research methodologies?

f.c:
Jose and Maggie are discussing the results of their recent chemistry exam.

Jose: I got a 97% on the test.

Maggie: Congratulations! I did well, too – I got a 95%! I wonder how Brayden did on the test.

Jose: I heard he got a 53% on it, but he had like three tests that day.

Maggie: Well, he’s not the smartest student in our grade. I’m not surprised he got a low score.

q.s: Which of the following best explains why the use of surveys to ask participants about implicit attitudes would be beneficial from an ethical perspective?

o.l: Surveys allow researchers to forgo informed consent before starting a study.
Surveys allow researchers to forgo debriefing participants after a study is complete.
Surveys prevent participants from consciously having to express undesirable emotions and cognitions.
Surveys prevent participants understanding the purpose of the research study they are participating in.

q.s: Claire is conducting research on attribution theory in the United States, which is considered an individualistic country, and in Indonesia, a more collectivistic country. The observation Claire will most likely see in her research is more

o.l: prevalence of self-fulfilling prophecies in the United States than in Indonesia
evidence of the self-serving bias in Indonesia than in the United States
evidence of the fundamental attribution error in the United States than in Indonesia
immediate external attributions in the United States than in Indonesia

q.s: Patrick believes his basketball coach doesn’t like him and subsequently focuses on all the times the coach criticizes his playing and ignores all the times the coach praises his performance. Patrick’s behavior is best explained by the concept of
A therapist who is an adherent of the humanistic personality theory would most likely focus on which of the following?

o.l: The underlying and consistent behavioral traits that differ across individuals
The influence of the beliefs about the self on behavior

q.s: Shanni loves to travel internationally, owns many unusual pieces of art from local artists, and enjoys attending concerts featuring an eclectic collection of musicians. According to trait personality researchers, Shanni’s personality is likely high on which of the following traits?

Bella takes a test to develop an inventory of different aspects of her personality. She hopes to better understand herself and the kind of person she is. The test is most in line with which of the following theories?

Paris tends to view personality as fairly stable and therefore her personality is more stable, whereas Lane tends to view personality as fairly changeable and therefore her personality is more changeable. These differences in attitudes and personality are most consistent with which of the following theories?
According to Lewin’s motivational conflict theory, approach-avoidance conflict occurs when a situation has which of the following aspects?

A researcher presented a group of children with a pile of random toys like those presented in the figure. The children were tasked with sorting the toys into three piles and were given 10 minutes. The researchers told the students that their piles had to “make sense,” requiring them to explain their reasons behind each pile of sorted toys. Which of the following might help the children sort the toys into three piles?

A group of researchers were trying to determine how self-esteem and self-efficacy were related to the development of a healthy self-concept. Participants in the research study completed a questionnaire, and the resulting data were graphed into a scatterplot.

Self-Concept

What type of relationship does the scatterplot indicate between self-efficacy and self-esteem?

Dr. Sybert is trying to determine how the Big Five personality traits of agreeableness and extraversion are related to one another. Dr. Sybert had a group of participants complete a survey in which they rated their levels of agreeableness and extraversion on a scale of 1 to 6, and the resulting data were graphed into a scatterplot.

Big Five Traits

Based on the data presented in the graph, which of the following describes the type of correlation between the two variables?

Dr. Jones was interested in how personality traits are related to everyday behaviors. Her data collected from participants were gathered and presented in a scatterplot. Which of the following statements is correct for the data?

o.l: The correlation between conscientiousness and how many days one makes their bed is negative.
The correlation between conscientiousness and how many days one makes their bed is positive.
The correlation between conscientiousness and how many days one makes their bed is statistically significant.
Conscientiousness causes individuals to make their bed more often.

q.s: According to the broaden-and-build theory of emotion, which of the following is the foundation for well-being missing from the diagram?

o.l: Experiencing a low level of the Big Five trait of agreeableness
A low level of the Big Five trait of emotional stability
Having an external locus of control

q.s: Researchers showed the six basic facial expressions, as seen in Figure 1, to isolated people in New Guinea in the early 1970’s. The fact that isolated people in New Guinea were able to correctly identify the emotions on faces that they had never seen before supports which of the following?

o.l: The expression of emotions is universal.
The expression of emotions is culture-specific.
The expression of emotions is too complex to measure universally.
The expression of emotions is taught to babies differently.

q.s: Which of the following describes the theory depicted in the figure?

Prevalence of children aged 3–17 years ever diagnosed with selected disabilities, by year: United States, 2019–2021

Which of the following categories of psychological disorders is best described by the data in the graph?

Mental Health Services Received in Past Year Among U.S. Adults with Serious Mental Illness (2021)

According to the data in the chart, what was the percentage of young adults aged 18–25 years with serious mental illness (SMI) who received mental health services in the past year?
Ever since Minnie witnessed a serious car crash, she continues to have vivid nightmares and reacts with panic at any sudden noise. Minnie's symptoms are most indicative of what disorder?
While pregnant, Marley was exposed to the flu virus. Based on current research, which psychological disorder is Marley’s child most likely to develop?

o.l: Depression, because prenatal flu virus exposure is positively correlated with increased risk of depression.
Specific phobia, because prenatal flu virus exposure is positively correlated with an increased risk of phobias.
Anorexia nervosa, because the flu virus can be extremely stressful to the developing fetus.
Schizophrenia, because flu virus exposure is positively correlated with an increased risk of developing schizophrenia.

q.s: Dr. Whitlock is conducting an experimental study on the effectiveness of antipsychotic medication. Which of the following will most likely be her dependent variable?

o.l: Type of medication, because this is the variable she is manipulating.
Frequency of auditory hallucinations, because this is the variable she is measuring.
Self-reported depression, because this is the variable she is manipulating.
Serotonin levels, because this is the variable she is measuring.

q.s:
Emotion regulation is the extent to which a person can manage their emotional experiences. Emotional eating occurs when someone eats not due to hunger, but to respond to an emotional state.

The graph shown depicts research results that show the relationship between eating behaviors and emotions. Which of the following perspectives would be most interested in this relationship?
Which of the following concepts is depicted in the figure?
This graph presents evidence for which of the following statements?

o.l: If an identical twin develops schizophrenia, their sibling will also have schizophrenia.
There is a genetic predisposition for developing schizophrenia.
Genes do not play a role in the development of schizophrenia.
Identical and fraternal twins have the same statistical risk of developing schizophrenia.

q.s:
Percentage of Children Diagnosed with ADHD

Which of the following is supported by the data in the provided map of ADHD diagnoses?

o.l: States in western United States do not believe ADHD is an actual disorder.
States with higher population have higher percentages of diagnosed ADHD in children.
Children in the Northwest of the United States are diagnosed at a higher rate than those of the Southeast.
Possible causes of ADHD may be related to environmental factors like geography.

q.s:
What Treatments Work for Anxiety

Based on the data presented in the graph, which of the following statements is accurate?

o.l: Traditional talk therapy appears to be the most effective treatment for anxiety conditions overall.
Medication was the most effective strategy in working with phobias.
Cognitive-behavioral therapy showed the greatest success in working with phobias and panic conditions.
Treatment is most effective for anxiety conditions when all three interventions are used.

q.s:
Two separate studies aimed to explore the link between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and later-life health and social outcomes. The study participants completed a questionnaire on various ACEs, such as abuse and household dysfunction. The data from the two separate studies are depicted in the graph.

Percent of ACEs reported in Two Separate Studies*

*Original ACE Study had 17,337 participants. 69.9% reported experiencing at least one ACE. Expanded ACE Study had 1,784 participants. 83.2% reported experiencing at least one ACE.

What was the impact of including community-level stressors in the expanded ACE study?

o.l: It decreased the prevalence of individuals who reported having at least one ACE.
It decreased the prevalence of individuals who reported having 4+ ACEs.
It decreased the prevalence of individuals who reported 0 ACEs.
The inclusion of community-level stressors in the expanded study had no impact on the reporting of ACEs.

q.s: Timothy, who was diagnosed with schizophrenia, remains motionless for hours, no matter how awkward the position his body is in. What symptom is Timothy most clearly exhibiting?

o.l: Catatonia, because catatonia is a condition in which a person's body remains in a rigid state.
Hallucinations, because he is probably seeing imaginary people telling him to remain still.
Delusions, because he probably is afraid that someone will attack him if he moves.
Flat affect, because he is experiencing a lack of emotions that causes him to remain so still.

q.s: Jimmy, who was diagnosed with schizophrenia, sees images of cats everywhere even when no cats are present. What symptom is Jimmy most clearly demonstrating?

o.l: Paranoia, because Jimmy thinks the cats are out to attack him.
Disorganized thinking, because seeing imaginary cats all over the place is a sign of disorganization.
Hallucinations, because Jimmy’s perception is incorrect.
Delusions, because Jimmy thinks that he is a cat.

q.s: Ever since she was a child, Henrietta has had an intense fear of clowns, even though she has never been hurt by one. She runs screaming whenever she sees one. Henrietta most likely has what psychological disorder?
Using psychological techniques such as free association to explore a client’s early relationships is characteristic of what type of treatment?
Which of the following scenarios best demonstrates a behavioral approach to therapy?

o.l: Elizabeth thinks she is never going to meet someone to date, so her therapist works with her to combat her irrational thoughts.
Jason has low self-esteem, so his therapist provides unconditional positive regard to build up his self-esteem.
Frank is angry at his father but directs the anger at his therapist, so his therapist helps him work through the transference.
Finn has been acting out at school, so his therapist employs a token economy to reward Finn when he behaves well.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios is an example of a therapist using rational-emotive behavior therapy?

o.l: Stanley thinks he is never going to get a job, so his therapist says that would be the worst thing that could ever happen to Stanley.
Maya is afraid of riding in elevators, so her therapist makes her ride on elevators to get over her fear.
Meyla is misbehaving in school, so her therapist makes a chart that allows Meyla to receive a star every time she is well behaved.
Jose is grounded for a month and keeps misbehaving, so his therapist explains to Jose's mother that it may be helpful to have Jose do chores to reduce the time he is grounded.

q.s: Dr. Obetz is conducting an experimental study on the effectiveness of antianxiety medication. Which of the following will most likely be her independent variable?

o.l: Age of first symptoms, because she will randomly divide her participants into groups, assigning them based on the age that symptoms first appeared.
Frequency of hallucinations, because she will measure the frequency of hallucinations that her participants have with each type of medication.
Type of medication, because she will randomly divide participants into groups and give the groups different types of medication.
Severity of anxiety, because she will measure the amount of self-reported anxiety that is present in her participants with each type of medication.

q.s: Dr. Xi conducted an experiment on the effectiveness of an antidepressant medication. Given her research design, if she finds that the drug is effective, which of the following will she be able to conclude?

o.l: Antidepressants are related to reduced depression, because she found a negative correlation between depression levels and the administration of antidepressant medication.
Antianxiety medication is related to reduced depression, because she found a negative correlation between depression levels and the administration of antianxiety medication.
Antidepressants decrease the severity of depression, and the experiment demonstrates cause-and-effect because she used random assignment.
Antidepressants decrease the severity of anxiety, and the experiment demonstrates cause-and-effect because she used random assignment.

q.s: Dr. Jones hypothesizes that antianxiety drugs cause a reduction in central nervous system activity. In order to test the hypothesis, what should her independent variable be?

o.l: Central versus peripheral nervous system activity
Taking Xanax versus taking a placebo
Patients with anxiety versus patients without anxiety

q.s: How did the researcher operationally define the dependent variable in this research?

o.l: Positive comments or no comments in the syllabus
Scores on the end-of-semester student course evaluations
The group of students receiving the positive comments
The group of students receiving no comments

f.c: At the start of a new semester, a researcher randomly assigns the students in their Social Psychology class to receive a syllabus that either (1) includes positive comments from students who took the class the previous semester, or (2) does not include any comments from students who took the class the previous semester. They look to see how this difference affected scores on the end-of-semester student evaluations of the class among current students, with 1 meaning “unfavorable evaluation” to 5 meaning “favorable evaluation.” The results appear in the graph.

q.s: Which of the following concepts best explains the results as depicted in the graph?

f.c: At the start of a new semester, a researcher randomly assigns the students in their Social Psychology class to receive a syllabus that either (1) includes positive comments from students who took the class the previous semester, or (2) does not include any comments from students who took the class the previous semester. They look to see how this difference affected scores on the end-of-semester student evaluations of the class among current students, with 1 meaning “unfavorable evaluation” to 5 meaning “favorable evaluation.” The results appear in the graph.

q.s:
After George completes his PhD in psychology, his former classmate Danielle congratulates him and tells him that he must be a very intelligent and conscientious student. When George asks why Danielle didn’t complete the degree, she tells him that she was too busy juggling her work and family responsibilities to have time for school.

Which psychological concept exemplifies Danielle’s explanation?

Dr. Drew is doing an experiment in which participants listen to a persuasive speech. They are either told the speaker freely chose to give as speech of their own making or the speaker was given a script and told to read it without the option to choose. If Dr. Drew uses the fundamental attribution error as a theoretical framework, what will their hypothesis be?

o.l: Participants will indicate that the speech reflects the speaker’s true attitude regardless of experimental condition.
Participants will indicate that the speech reflects the speaker’s true attitude only when told the speaker freely chose what to say.
Participants will indicate that the freedom or not to choose the speech affected the speaker’s ability to persuade them.
Participants will indicate that the speech did not reflect the speaker’s true attitude regardless of experimental condition.

q.s:
Dr. Alondra is conducting an experiment to examine the extent to which people make attributions for the heroic actions of others. She obtains 150 participants from her college and has them read one of two fictitious news stories. Each story describes a man who rescued a child from a burning building. However, the characteristics of the man were different for each story. Participants were then asked to rate the likelihood that the man in the story had certain personal attributes from a list provided.

What should Dr. Alondra do after obtaining her 150 participants?

Psychologists showed participants a list of words in a language they did not know. The words were repeated to participants. Group A heard the list 3 times. Group B heard the list 8 times, and Group C heard the list 25 times. Participants rated the degree to which words in the list likely referred to something good or bad. The results provide evidence for the mere exposure effect.

Which of the following is the most appropriate conclusion?

o.l: There is a positive correlation between the number of times an individual is exposed to novel words and increased positive associations.
Increased exposure to novel words causes increased positive associations.
Increased exposure to novel words leads to increased negative associations.
Individuals exposed to novel words fewer times were more likely to associate them with something bad.

q.s:
Jefferson High School is interested in a relationship between students’ beliefs about their own abilities and their grades in math classes. To investigate the relationship, the four calculus instructors give out a survey on the first day of class. Students place their name at the top of the survey. They answer five questions regarding whether successes and failures in their life are due to their own abilities or the product of chance. At the end of the term, student survey scores are compared to final grades.

Which of the following represents a flaw in this procedure?

o.l: The independent variable cannot be operationally defined.
Cause-and-effect conclusions cannot be drawn from correlational studies.
The social desirability bias is likely to confound any results.
It is unethical to use actual student grades as part of a research study.

q.s:
To study the self-fulfilling prophecy, a professor gave a group of students a survey at the beginning of a semester that asked them to predict how well they would do on the final exam. During the semester, the professor required that students keep track of the number of hours they spent studying for each weekly quiz. The professor then compared their predictions with their final exam scores.

Which of the following best describes the operational definition of self-fulfilling prophecy in this study?

o.l: The scores on each weekly quiz
The number of hours student spend studying during the semester
The predictions of the final exam scores

q.s:
While watching a children’s movie with her mother, Lily tells her mother that she can’t wait for the evil witch to be punished at the end because of how badly she treated the princess. Lily’s mother asks her how she knows the evil witch will be punished in the end of the movie and Lily replies, “Because that’s what happens to bad people.”

Which of the following concepts is demonstrated by Lily’s response?
Which of the following best explains the difference in the distributions on the graphs?

f.c: A social psychologist selects five high schools from a midwestern state. He then uses a sports team roster from each school to randomly select 10 players to participate in a study. Each selected player is first asked to list as many positive personality and athletic characteristics for the other players on her own team as they can. Then they are asked to list as many positive personality and athletic characteristics for the players on a rival team. Each player is given 15 minutes to complete each task. The distribution of scores is presented in the graphs.

q.s: What is the mode for the “own team” distribution?

f.c: A social psychologist selects five high schools from a midwestern state. He then uses a sports team roster from each school to randomly select 10 players to participate in a study. Each selected player is first asked to list as many positive personality and athletic characteristics for the other players on her own team as they can. Then they are asked to list as many positive personality and athletic characteristics for the players on a rival team. Each player is given 15 minutes to complete each task. The distribution of scores is presented in the graphs.

q.s: The results of the study are shared with the coaches of the teams. As the coaches talk about the results, many of them express that they are not surprised by the data presented. Which of the following explains the coaches’ lack of surprise?

f.c: A social psychologist selects five high schools from a midwestern state. He then uses a sports team roster from each school to randomly select 10 players to participate in a study. Each selected player is first asked to list as many positive personality and athletic characteristics for the other players on her own team as they can. Then they are asked to list as many positive personality and athletic characteristics for the players on a rival team. Each player is given 15 minutes to complete each task. The distribution of scores is presented in the graphs.

q.s:
Student Survey Totals Pre-Course Student Survey Totals Post-Course
Student agreement with the issues 62 65

Professor Patel gives an anonymous survey of 100 questions to each of his students on the first day of his course to measure student attitudes about social issues. The higher the scores on the survey, the more the students agree with the issues. During the term, students are given a reading assignment or video lecture about each issue at least twice, using studies sourced by reputable professional organizations. The data from these studies often contradicted the issues presented in the surveys. The surveys were given again at the end of the course to see if student attitudes about the social issues changed.

Which of the following best explains the data from the table?

o.l: Student attitudes did not change much despite getting reputable information about the issues.
Student attitudes became more extreme as the semester went on.
Cognitive dissonance is likely the reasons student responses remained consistent.
Students conformed to the views of the professor.

q.s:
Person ATOP Mean Score
1 4.3
2 4.4
3 1.6
4 3.8
5 5.0

Five students ranging in age from 19 to 24 took part in a survey at a nearby college. The students were asked to rate their overall attitudes toward older people (ATOP), on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 indicates a negative attitude and 5 indicates a favorable attitude. These results are presented in the table.

What is the range of the ATOP mean scores?

Participant Survey Before Charity Work Survey After Charity Work
A 1 3
B 3 3
C 2 4
D 2 5
E 4 5
F 1 2
G 3 4
H 3 5
I 2 4
J 5 5

Ten students participated in a survey about cognitive dissonance. They were asked about their views on homelessness. Then, they participated in some charity work for the unhoused people in their city. Afterwards, they took the same survey. The scores from the surveys are depicted in the table, with higher scores indicating positive views and low scores indicating negative views.

What is the mean of the post-survey group?

After Kelly’s friends all buy the same red-and-white striped sweatshirt, Kelly buys one as well, even though she doesn’t like the color red. Kelly’s buying behavior demonstrates which of the following concepts?

Haben has chosen to go to a college located a long distance away from her hometown. She feels it is best to go away to college to adequately prepare for life on her own one day away from her family. Haben is sure that all her friends agree with her and are following the same plan as she is.

What concept describes why Haben is so certain about her friends’ college plans?

Cheyenne will soon have a baby and is trying to decide whether to have the baby at home or in a hospital. It is common in Cheyenne’s family for the eldest womens’ opinions to be respected above all other factors. Her mother and her aunt inform Cheyenne that having a baby in the hospital is best because if something goes wrong during the birth, the staff can assist more easily with all the medical equipment that is available in a hospital. Before speaking with her mother and her aunt, Cheyenne originally felt that the hospital was the best place to have the baby. Now, after her discussion with her mother and her aunt, she feels even more convinced about her decision to have the baby in the hospital.

Which concept best explains Cheyenne’s desire to do what her aunt and mother suggest?

Dr. Bach is trying to determine whether people will conform to a group’s decisions about choosing a new laptop computer. She places each research participant into a pre-determined group that contains confederates. Each of the confederates were told to choose the same laptop from a list of options and share their decision with the rest of the group. Dr. Bach then documents the selection made by the participants.

What element of Dr. Bach’s research will necessitate the use of debriefing?

A researcher wanted to know if ads that featured celebrities were more persuasive. They set up a table at a local shopping mall that displayed the products they were trying to sell. For three hours, they stopped people as they were shopping and gave them a flier with information about the facts and qualities of the products. Then, for an additional three hours, they had a local celebrity stand next to the table and stop people as they were shopping to tell them how much he likes the products. They kept track of how many products were sold during each three-hour period.

Which of the following ethical guidelines did the researchers fail to follow?

o.l: Debriefing after the use of deception

q.s:
Researchers wanted to see if people who were arguing would get along if they were in a dangerous situation together. Randomly selected participants were asked to complete a “demographic survey.” Each participant was seated in a room with another person, a research confederate, who was also filling out the survey. The confederate engaged in conversation with the participant, and during the course of the conversation, was instructed to disagree with the participant. After the disagreement went on for a few minutes, researchers pumped smoke into the room through the air vents and timed how long it took before participants stopped arguing and tried to leave.

Which ethical consideration should the researchers follow at the conclusion of the study?

o.l: They should obtain approval from the IRB.

q.s:
Table 1

Standard Approach Donation Amount
Donation 1 $15
Donation 2 $0
Donation 3 $150
Donation 4 $98
Donation 5 $25
Donation 6 $0

Table 2

Foot-in-the-door Approach Donation amount
Donation 1 $43
Donation 2 $55
Donation 3 $30
Donation 4 $40
Donation 5 $55
Donation 6 $65

Based on the results in the tables, which of the following statements is accurate?

o.l: The mean and mode for Table 1 are higher than the mean and mode of Table 2.
The mean is the same for Table 1 and 2, but Table 1 has a higher standard deviation.
The range and median are the same in both tables.
The standard deviation is higher in Table 1, and the variance is higher in Table 2.

q.s:
Less than 10 Years’ Experience
Mean (Standard Deviation)

Less than 10 Years’ to Retirement
Mean (Standard Deviation)
Employee Satisfaction 5.5 (3.61) 6.2 (0.94)

An industrial-organizational psychologist surveyed employees at a tire factory to gain an understanding of employee satisfaction. The factory manager is interested in differences between employees with less than 10 years’ experience and those with less than 10 years to go before retirement. The survey asked participants to rate their work environment using a scale from 1(poor work environment) to 10 (excellent work environment).

Which of the following best describes how the I/O psychologist might interpret the difference in the standard deviations between the two groups?

o.l: There is very little variation in age for the less experienced group, while the ages of the more experienced group are mostly the same.
The scores of the less experienced group varied more widely from each other than the more experienced group.
The scores of the more experienced group were less alike than those from the less experienced group.
The more experienced group has higher employee satisfaction.

q.s:
Participant

Number of Errors
GROUP A

Number of Errors
GROUP B
A 0 4
B 1 3
C 0 3
D 2 1
E 0 3
F 0 3
G 1 5

A researcher presented participants with five simple math problems to solve. They were instructed to solve each problem and state their answer aloud to the researcher. In Group A, the participants were alone while solving the problems. In Group B, the participants were in the room with two confederates who gave the wrong answer to every problem.

Which of the following is the mode of the group with the confederates?
Which of the following theories of personality would best support the idea that our personality is primarily formed because of unconscious conflicts?
After a difficult end to a romantic relationship, Stuart claims he is looking forward to his newfound freedom. Which of the following defense mechanisms is Stuart most likely displaying?

As part of a survey, a researcher asked a group of students the following question: “How likely are you to punch a wall when your partner makes you angry?” Which of the following might the researcher need to consider as they interpret the responses to this question?

o.l: Responses do not need to be subject to peer review.
Responses need to be replicated before they can be considered valid.
Responses may be subject to the social desirability bias.
Responses from the experimental group will provide the most insight about defense mechanisms.

q.s: Psychologists who adhere to the psychodynamic approach to personality often use projective tests to assess personality. Which of the following accurately depicts a limitation of that research method?

o.l: There is often a lack of controlling for confounding variables in such tests which leads to subjective interpretations.
That type of test typically requires subjects to answer hundreds of questions which makes the test unreliable.
The results of those tests give subjects a score on each of the Big Five personality traits which is an invalid measure of personality.
Projective tests require subjects to answer true or false to several scenarios and would not provide a true measure of personality.

q.s:
A group of 10 graduate students conducted a study about the interpretation of ambiguous stimuli and diagnosis of disorders. Randomly selected and informed participants met with a licensed psychotherapist for a clinical evaluation. Participants were then shown an ambiguous image of a scene depicting either 2, 4, or 6 people and asked to explain what was going on in the picture. All sessions were videotaped and shown to each of the 10 members of the research team, who independently diagnosed the participants based on their interpretations of the image.

Which of the following describes the operational definition of the independent variable?

o.l: The number of people in each picture
The diagnosis of the participant by the researcher
The 10 members of the research team

q.s:
Dr. Friedrich is interested in whether the personality trait of self-efficacy is relatively stable or changes over the lifetime of humans. Dr. Friedrich gives 500 children a personality survey that measures self-efficacy. Children are given surveys every 5 years, starting when they are 10 years old and finishing when they are 40 years old.

Which research design is Dr. Friedrich using?

Dr. Molitor is interested in whether the Big Five trait of openness to experience decreases as people age. Dr. Molitor gives a personality assessment measuring the Big Five trait of openness to a group of 20-year-olds, 40-year-olds, and 60-year-olds on the same day. She then compiles the data to see if older people are less open to experience.

Which research design is Dr. Molitor using?

Dr. Segal has been studying 100 sets of identical twins that had been separated at birth. Before reuniting the identical twins, Dr. Segal gave each twin a personality inventory that measured the Big Five trait of extraversion. Dr. Segal found that, despite being raised in completely different environments, the twins had very similar extraversion scores.

What method of research is Dr. Segal using?
Which of the following scenarios best describes a person who is bored because they have a high need for sensation-seeking behaviors?

o.l: Ruth, who quits her job at a factory where she was filling boxes all day in order to work at an amusement park.
Wilson, who is preparing to hike the tallest mountain in his country for the third time this year.
Gorji, who is sailing on a ship that will take them to visit several exciting new locations he’s never seen.
Ryan, who prefers a calm night at home watching television rather than attending a sold-out concert with his friends.

q.s:
Ms. Templeton was interested in people’s preferences for athletic events and activities in high schools. She recruited 50 participants from 10 sporting events and 10 after-school activities. She presented each person with a list of choices. They were asked to select the activity or athletic event they preferred from the list. Subjects were then asked to rate the difficulty of their decisions on a scale of 1-5, with 5 being very difficult. She determined that those who rated their difficulty as a 4 or a 5 experienced an approach-approach conflict, because they found difficulty choosing between two preferred options.

Which of the following concepts relate to a possible flaw in her research design?

o.l: The methods she used are not replicable.
She did not operationally define “difficulty in decision-making.”
The results are not generalizable due to sampling bias.
The study did not involve the use of a control group.

q.s:
Mr. Anton, who is interested in arousal theory, wanted to measure the effect that stressful environments have on the quality of food prepared in a restaurant kitchen. On the same night of the week for three consecutive weeks, he asks the kitchen staff at his favorite restaurant to cook the same menu but under different environmental conditions. In week one, the staff work in a kitchen while soft soothing music is played. In week two, upbeat pop music is played. And in week three, experimental music that uses loud, banging trash cans as instruments is played. Mr. Anton has the diners, who cannot hear the music playing in the kitchen, rate the quality of the dishes for each night.

Which of the following correctly identifies the independent variable in this scenario?

In a study of extrinsic motivation and helping behaviors, participants were asked to report individually to a lab in the basement of the science building. On the door to the lab there was a brightly colored poster asking for a missing necklace to be returned. The researcher would use a random number generator to decide which poster each participant would see when they walked in. For the extrinsic motivation group, the poster included a monetary reward. For the control group, the poster did not include any monetary reward. In both conditions, the participant would find the necklace from the poster in the only chair at the desk in the lab. The number of times that the necklace was returned to the owner was measured.

Which of the following concepts was used in the study to control for the social desirability bias?

A high school is looking to determine if students are motivated to do well in school for internal or external reasons. Fifty students are randomly selected from the school and given a twenty-question survey. The questions are written as statements and students respond on a scale of 1-5 where 1 means “never me” and 5 means “always me.” Half of the questions are from an intrinsic perspective, and the other half from an extrinsic perspective.

Which of the following best describes the data collected for this study?

o.l: Observational, because they are watching the students respond to the questions.
Correlational, because results will be compared to data gathered from other schools.
Qualitative, because the researchers are using a structured interview with each participant.
Quantitative, because the survey questions involve a Likert scale.

q.s: Which of the following is the research method used in this study?

f.c: Dr. Cabello is studying how much pressure people need to perform at their best. She created a survey that asks volunteer participants from the college where she works how stressful they find different kinds of stimuli. The survey uses a scale starting at 1 which means they find the stimulus not stressful at all and ends at 5 which means they find the stimulus extremely stressful. She then collects their overall grade point average data and compares their survey ratings to their grade point averages.

q.s: Which of the following correctly describes the rating scale used in this study?

f.c: Dr. Cabello is studying how much pressure people need to perform at their best. She created a survey that asks volunteer participants from the college where she works how stressful they find different kinds of stimuli. The survey uses a scale starting at 1 which means they find the stimulus not stressful at all and ends at 5 which means they find the stimulus extremely stressful. She then collects their overall grade point average data and compares their survey ratings to their grade point averages.

q.s: Which of the following is the psychological concept that Dr. Cabello is exploring with this study?

f.c: Dr. Cabello is studying how much pressure people need to perform at their best. She created a survey that asks volunteer participants from the college where she works how stressful they find different kinds of stimuli. The survey uses a scale starting at 1 which means they find the stimulus not stressful at all and ends at 5 which means they find the stimulus extremely stressful. She then collects their overall grade point average data and compares their survey ratings to their grade point averages.

q.s: Dr. Fell has been studying dopamine release in the brain during thrill-seeking behaviors, such as skydiving. Dr. Fell has found that, as the number of skydiving experiences increases, the amount of dopamine released in the brain decreases. What is the operational definition of thrill-seeking behaviors that Dr. Fell is using?

Gabriel recently became a grandfather. During the delivery of the child, there was a small complication, and the family was noticeably upset. Gabriel was calm and showed little emotion as he did his best to reassure the family that everything would okay. However, a short time later while explaining events to his own mother, Gabriel became very upset, demonstrating much more emotion than he had at the time of the birth.

What principle of emotion is demonstrated by Gabriel in this scenario?

Peyton had never felt romantically attracted to her coworker Antoni before because they have very little in common and his sense of humor usually annoys her. However, after attending an exciting, energetic party with Antoni, where they danced and ate good food, Peyton began feeling strong positive emotions every time he was near her. She began to think it might be fun to go out with him.

What psychological principle can best explain the situation?

o.l: Peyton mislabeled the excitement she felt at the party as excitement for Antoni.
Peyton was repressing her attraction to Antoni before the party.
Peyton’s mere exposure to Antoni in a social setting changed her mind about him.
Peyton’s motivations to find a romantic partner at work are based on Lewin’s Conflict theory.

q.s:
Angelica is touring colleges to determine where she will continue her education. Most of the campuses offered a tour with college students showing the high school students around various locations on the campus, including dorms and academic buildings. However, the last campus she visited had fun activities that sparked positive emotions in Angelica, rather than offering a tour. She decided on this final school because it would be a place where she could continue to grow as a person as well as increase academics.

Which of the following might explain Angelica’s final choice?

Professor Abdi is interested in the ability for babies to make facial expressions within the first year of their lives. He believes that babies in all cultures develop facial expressions in the same sequential order. To test his hypothesis, Professor Abdi will expose babies ranging in age from 2 weeks to 12 months to various situations. He will observe their facial expressions for anger, disgust, sadness, happiness, surprise, and fear.

Which of the following ethical guidelines must Professor Abdi consider while conducting his research?

o.l: An operational definition of each facial expression

q.s: A researcher goes to a local public park and jumps out from behind a tree to scare people as they walk by. The researcher says she is investigating the expression of fear in natural environments. Which of the following describes an ethical issue with this research approach?

o.l: The researcher did not randomly assign the participants.
The researcher did not get informed consent.
The researcher did not operationally define the dependent variable.
The researcher should have used a confederate.

q.s:
Dr. Yankovic is interested in whether humans display more anger on their faces when they are alone or with others. Subjects were told that the purpose of the experiment was to evaluate different personality traits using a personality inventory. However, the true purpose of the study was to expose subjects to a frustrating situation in which the personality inventory they are filling out keeps restarting and their information does not save. Subjects’ faces are closely monitored in the alone condition and in the with others condition to see whether subjects display more anger when alone or with others.

Which ethical guideline does Dr. Yankovic need to follow at the conclusion of the study?

o.l: Reveal the names of the individual subjects
Make sure the sample of the subjects is representative of the population.

q.s:
Dr. Rodrigo studies how emotions are expressed in different nations. She conducted a study in which she surveyed people in the military in five different nations about how comfortable they felt expressing six different basic emotions: happiness, anger, disgust, sadness, surprise, and fear. In each of the nations, men were required to serve at least two years in the military when they turned 18, and women could volunteer to serve for two years when they turned 18. She randomly selected equal numbers of men and women from each nation to participate in the study.

Which of the following is a confounding variable in this study?
Which of the following explains why this research study is an experiment?

o.l: The researcher manipulated the independent variable.
The researcher manipulated the dependent variable.
The researcher used inferential statistics to draw their conclusions.
The researcher used a sample to generalize to a population.

f.c: At the start of a new semester, a researcher randomly assigns the students in their Social Psychology class to receive a syllabus that either (1) includes positive comments from students who took the class the previous semester, or (2) does not include any comments from students who took the class the previous semester. They look to see how this difference affected scores on the end-of-semester student evaluations of the class among current students, with 1 meaning “unfavorable evaluation” to 5 meaning “favorable evaluation.” The results appear in the graph.

q.s:
Dr. Singer is a university professor. He believes that students are overly stressed because they are involved in too many activities. He conducts a study with his students. He asks them to give up one activity that causes stress for two weeks. He gives them a short survey measuring their stress levels, and then after two weeks of reducing their activities, he gives them the same stress evaluation test and compares the two measures. Dr. Singer concludes that fewer stressors reduce stress levels.

What would limit the generalizability of Dr. Singer’s findings?

o.l: Dr. Singer did not clearly define his population.
Dr. Singer used a convenience sample.
Dr. Singer did not have a valid hypothesis.
Dr. Singer did not have a control group.

q.s: Researchers in this study examined the impact of adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) on child well-being. Which psychological theory is most directly connected to this research?

o.l: Piaget’s stage theory of cognitive development

f.c:
Researchers examined the impact of adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) on the well-being of young children using data from a representative survey measuring health in children. The findings indicated significant connections between the number of ACEs, such as financial struggles and parental stress, and the number of health and developmental issues in children. A higher number of these early childhood stressors increased the likelihood of problems. The study also indicated that children who expressed affection toward their parents managed these challenges more effectively.

Understanding the Impact of Early Challenges on Child Health and Development

q.s: Which of the following is an accurate interpretation of the results presented in the graph?

o.l: The relationship between the number of ACEs and the number of developmental issues in children is determined by qualitative measures.
There is a negative correlation between the number of ACEs and the number of health and developmental issues in children.
Higher numbers of ACEs lead to higher numbers of developmental issues in children.
There is a positive correlation between the number of ACEs and the number of health and developmental issues in children.

f.c:
Researchers examined the impact of adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) on the well-being of young children using data from a representative survey measuring health in children. o.l: ACEs affect childhood experiences, but do not have lasting effects into adulthood.
ACEs solely impact cognitive processes and have no direct correlation with social development.
ACEs can contribute to behavioral issues and altered mental processes.
Children raised with authoritative parents are more likely to experience higher levels of ACEs.

A higher number of these early childhood stressors increased the likelihood of problems. The study also indicated that children who expressed affection toward their parents managed these challenges more effectively.

q.s:
A group of researchers is interested in studying the impact of exercise on stress and sense of wellbeing. They asked people about their stress and wellbeing as well as how many hours they exercised each week. The number of hours exercised each week reported by the participants in the study are:

8, 7, 10, 4, 7, 3, 2, 0, 9, 3

What is the average number of hours exercised by the participants in the study?

Number of reported illnesses
Week 1 Week 2 Week 3
High stress group 13 18 28
Moderate stress group 7 10 15
Low stress group 4 4 5

Dr. Gooden studied the effects of stress over time on health outcomes using three groups of fifty participants. Which of the following is true based on the table?

o.l: The high stress group has been in the exhaustion stage of the general adaptation syndrome model for the longest time.
The low stress group has been in the exhaustion stage of the general adaptation syndrome model for the longest time.
The moderate stress group has been in homeostasis for the entire three weeks.
The number of illnesses reported in the high stress group indicate that they are in the alarm stage by week 3.

q.s:
Owners of a new restaurant needed to hire 10 new servers before opening day. They gave potential employees a test to identify their signature strengths and only hired people who scored high on the wisdom trait, even if the potential employee had years of experience working as a server.

Which of the following describes why this use of the signature strengths test might not be valid?

o.l: The restaurant owners need to conduct a study in order to determine that wisdom is the best trait for servers.
The signature strengths assessment was not designed to be used to identify who would make the best server.
The signature strengths assessment was not given in a standardized way.
The restaurant owners should have used the potential employee’s lowest score instead of their highest score.

q.s:
Researchers designed an assessment for measuring signature strengths in individuals using a self-report inventory. The evaluation includes 100 questions in which individuals read a statement and determine if it describes them. For each statement, individuals can choose very much like me, like me, neutral, unlike me, or very much unlike me.

What type of measurement device is being used in this scenario?

A university professor wanted to see if providing positive psychology training would affect students’ cognitions. The professor assessed the students’ cognitive perceptions in four specific areas. The results are listed in the table. Which statement accurately describes the variable with the largest spread of scores around the mean for the post-training set of scores?

o.l: The variable “depression” has the largest spread among the scores because standard deviation is 6.2.
The variable “anxiety” has the largest spread among the scores because the mean is 32.
The variable “hope” has the largest spread among the scores because the standard deviation is 8.3.
The variable “life satisfaction” has the largest spread among the scores because the mean is 24.

q.s: Clinicians must consider a variety of factors, such as biological, environmental, and cultural, before diagnosing someone with a mental illness. Which of the following is an example of a cultural factor?

o.l: Five years ago, Samantha was diagnosed with schizophrenia. Her twin sister, Savannah, is now exhibiting characteristics of the disorder.
Miremba was exposed to toxic levels of lead in early childhood. He now struggles to learn in elementary school.
Keldon is a high student who often demonstrates behaviors associated with severe depression. There are very few mental health providers in her community because few people seek their services.
Vera struggles with anorexia nervosa but her twin brother, Vernon, does not show any symptoms of the illness.

q.s:
In investigating the impact of social environment on the development of anxiety in children, Anthony places children in chaotic rooms with loud noises and scary situations after gaining their guardians permission. At the end of the day, he measures the children’s blood pressure then sends them home.

According to ethical guidelines, which of the following is Anthony forgetting?

Dr. Gunther wants to find out if he can cause phobias in children by exposing them to loud noises. He walks down the hall to a preschool classroom and suddenly starts blaring sounds of thunder and watches to see which children seem scared. Which of the following ethical procedures does Dr. Gunther fail to obtain?

Which research method is most likely utilized in a study exploring the biopsychosocial causes of bipolar disorder by extensively examining the personal history, symptoms, and treatment outcomes for the small group of individuals who first showed symptoms after age 60?
Why do psychologists find it challenging to conduct experiments on individuals diagnosed with personality disorders?

o.l: People with personality disorders would resist being randomly assigned to an experimental condition.
Experimental psychologists are not inclined to work with people who are socially challenging.
People with psychological disorders cannot be randomly assigned to groups.
People with personality disorders have a difficult time following instructions.

q.s:
Researchers are investigating the impact of stress-management therapy on individuals with schizophrenia who are already receiving pharmacological treatment. In the study, half of the participants were randomly assigned to have stress management therapy, and the other half continued with only their medication treatment. After six weeks, individuals in the experimental group demonstrated significant improvement in their negative symptoms compared to the control group.

Which of the following describes the ethical concern specific to this study and how it should be addressed?

o.l: Ensure participants' anonymity to protect their privacy
Implement a comprehensive debriefing session to explain the study's purpose as required by the IRB
Offer stress management therapy to the control group after the initial 6-week period to protect participants from harm
Provide participants in the control group with additional compensation for their time and involvement

q.s: What research design was most likely used in the study?

o.l: Experimental design with a control group and random assignment
Cross-sectional design comparing different groups at a single point in time
Longitudinal design following participants over an extended period
Descriptive research using the method of naturalistic observation

f.c:
Researchers interested in examining the effect of various treatments on reducing symptoms of cases of persistent depressive disorder compared treatment method outcomes for three groups. They measured the reduction in symptoms for three groups of 10 individuals with persistent depressive disorder over the course of 16 weeks. The results depicted in the graph indicate that no significant differences were found among the three groups.

Impact of Treatments on Persistent Depressive Disorder Symptoms

q.s: Dr. Feliz is interested in investigating the effectiveness of a new drug for the treatment of anxiety disorders. Ethical guidelines require that prior to starting the study he needs to do which of the following?

o.l: Set up an exam room for participants
Write a paper proving the effect of the drug

q.s:
Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology.

Using the sources provided, develop and justify an argument about the best way to increase one’s level of happiness.

A. Propose a specific and defensible claim based in psychological science that responds to the question.

f.c:
Question Instructions:

This question has three parts: part A, part B, and part C. Use the three sources provided to answer all parts of the question.

For part B and part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways: 

  • • Parenthetical Citation:

       For example: “. . . (Source 1)”

  • • Embedded Citation:

       For example: “According to Source 1, . . .”

 

Source 1

Introduction

In this study, researchers examined the impact of daily gratitude practices on reported happiness among persons with neuromuscular disease.

Participants

The sample consisted of 65 people (44 women, 21 men) with a neuromuscular disorder. Neuromuscular disorders affect the nerves that control voluntary muscles and the nerves that communicate sensory information back to the brain. The participants ranged in age from 22 to 77 years, with a mean age of 49 years. Participants were recruited through a mailing list compiled by the researcher’s institution.

Method

Participants were randomly assigned one of two conditions: a gratitude condition (33 participants) and a control condition (32 participants). Both groups completed daily ratings of their subjective well-being. However, participants in the gratitude condition were also asked to respond to the following prompt:

There are many things in our lives, both large and small, that we might be grateful about. Think back over the past day and write down up to five things in your life that you are grateful or thankful for.

Participants were provided with a packet of 21 daily experience rating forms and envelopes for mailing their forms directly back to the researchers. They were instructed to fill out the form as close to the end of the day as possible. They were told that their ratings were meant to summarize the day as a whole. The daily form took approximately 5 minutes to complete each evening. Participants were asked to mail in their forms once a week and were paid $20 if they completed all the forms.

The “daily experience rating forms” measured subjective well-being in three ways:

  • Participants were asked to rate how they felt about their life as a whole on a -3 to +3 scale, with -3 meaning terrible and +3 meaning delighted.

  • Participants rated their expectations for the upcoming week, also on a -3 to +3 scale, with -3 meaning pessimistic, expect the worst and +3 labeled optimistic, expect the best.

  • Participants indicated how connected they felt with others (where -3 = isolated and +3 = well-connected).

Results and Discussion

Participants in the gratitude condition reported more satisfaction with their lives as a whole, felt more optimism about the upcoming week, and felt more connected with others than did participants in the control condition. Mean ratings for each measure are reported in the table.

Comparisons of Groups by Measures of Subjective Well-Being

Dependent Variable Gratitude Control
Life as whole 1.54 0.80
Upcoming week 1.70 1.20
Connected with others 1.77 1.07

The differences between the groups were statistically significant for each of the three measures.

Emmons, R. A., & McCullough, M. E. (2003). Counting blessings versus burdens: An experimental investigation of gratitude and subjective well-being in daily life. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 84(2), 377–389. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.84.2.377 

Source 2

Introduction

In this study, subjective well-being was measured in a sample of several thousand middle-aged twin pairs. Comparing levels of similarity between identical and fraternal twins in the sample allowed researchers to investigate the intent to which genetic factors influence happiness.

Participants

Participants were 2,310 members of a large twin registry who were born between 1936 and 1955. The twins provide a representative sample of the population of Minnesota, which was predominantly White at the time (fewer than 2% of Minnesota births were to African or Native Americans during this period). Their socioeconomic levels were representative of Minnesota-born adults.

Method

A self-rating questionnaire was administered to all participants. One of the questionnaire items read, “Taking the good with the bad, how happy and contented are you on the average now, compared with other people?” The twins were asked to make their ratings on a 5-point scale: 1 = the lowest of the population, 2 = the lower, 3 = the middle, 4 = the upper, and 5 = the highest.

Results and Discussion

Most of the participants exhibited considerable contentment, and no substantial differences were found between male and female subjects. As shown in Graph 1, 86% of the twins rated themselves in the top 35% in overall contentment.

Graph 1: Contentment Self-Ratings

Researchers found that one twin’s score on a measure of subjective well-being was predictive of the second twin’s score, but only for identical twins. Fraternal twins’ scores did not correlate with each other. This was true both for twin pairs raised together and for twin pairs who had been raised apart.

Table : Correlations on contentment for middle-age twins reared together and reared apart

Type of Twin Pair Correlation Coefficient
Twins reared together
   Identical +0.44
   Fraternal +0.08
Twins reared apart
   Identical +0.52
   Fraternal -0.02

The reported well-being of one’s identical twin is a better predictor of one’s self-rated happiness than is one’s own educational attainment, income, or status. Based on the correlations indicated above in Table 1, researchers estimate the heritability of subjective well-being to be nearly 80%.

Lykken, D. & Tellegen, A. (1996). Happiness is a stochastic phenomenon. Psychological Science, 7, 186-89. https://www.jstor.org/stable/40062939 

Source 3

Introduction

This study investigated the impact of performing acts of kindness on reported happiness levels among employees in a corporate workplace environment.

Participants

Employees were recruited from a large corporation in Madrid, Spain. Of the approximately 1,200 employees, 88 (72.7% female) participated in the study. Participants’ ages ranged from 22 to 55, and they worked in a variety of departments across the company. They were given both a prize of university merchandise and a donation to a charitable organization based on enrollment in the study.

Method

All participants were told that they would be practicing a potentially happiness-boosting activity over a number of weeks. They were informed that a computer would randomly assign them to an activity, that it might change from week to week, and that some would not be assigned any activity for the duration of the study. Participants were instructed to keep their activities confidential and focus only on completing their assignments to the best of their abilities.

Participants were then randomly assigned to one of three groups: Givers (19 participants), Receivers (35 participants) and Controls (34 participants). No participants were aware of their group assignment. Thus, Receivers were not aware that Givers had been assigned to do acts of kindness on their behalf.

Givers were instructed to perform five acts of kindness in one day for recipients on a specific list. They were allowed to choose the specific kinds of activities they did, when they performed them, and whom they chose from their randomized lists of Receivers. Some examples were provided to help them select activities, such as “bringing someone a beverage” or “emailing a thank-you note.” This process was repeated each week for the four weeks of the study, and each Giver was provided a new list of Receivers to select from during each week. Neither Receivers nor Controls performed any other activity assignments throughout the study.

All participants logged into the study website every week for 4 weeks to complete surveys that measured happiness and life satisfaction, depression symptoms, and job satisfaction. In a follow-up measure, participants repeated these surveys one month after the acts of kindness assignments had been completed.

Results and Discussion

Results indicated that both Givers and Receivers benefited from the intervention. At the one-month follow-up, Givers showed statistically significant increases in life satisfaction and job satisfaction and decreases in depressive symptoms. Increases in happiness measures were also observed in Givers, though they were not statistically significant. Receivers showed increases in happiness that were statistically significant.

A full month after Givers finished practicing their acts of kindness, the long-term benefits remained, and they were strongest for Givers themselves. The study’s results indicate that acts of kindness produce improvements in well-being for both Givers and Receivers, though Givers benefit more. Results are depicted in the graphs.

Happiness Ratings Across 8 Weeks

Life Satisfaction Ratings Across 8 Weeks

Depressive Symptoms Ratings Across 8 Weeks

Job Satisfaction Ratings Across 8 Weeks

Chancellor, J., Margolis, S., Jacobs Bao, K., & Lyubomirsky, S. (2018). Everyday prosociality in the workplace: The reinforcing benefits of giving, getting, and glimpsing. Emotion, 18(4), 507-517. https://doi.org/10.1037/emo0000321

q.s:

Using the sources provided, develop and justify an argument about the age at which parents should first allow their children to be exposed to media screens.

A. Propose a specific and defensible claim based in psychological science that responds to the question.

f.c:
Question Instructions:

This question has three parts: part A, part B, and part C. Use the three sources provided to answer all parts of the question.

For part B and part C, you must cite the source that you used to answer the question. You can do this in two different ways: 

  • • Parenthetical Citation:

       For example: “. . . (Source 1)”

  • • Embedded Citation:

       For example: “According to Source 1, . . .”
