Source 1

Introduction

Electronic devices are used widely across many cultures. Media screens include televisions, computers, tablets, and smartphones. Parents and caregivers may wonder about the relationship between their children paying attention to media screens and the cognitive changes that are described in developmental theories. This research study examined when infants first experienced media screens, how often they were exposed to media screens, and their later cognitive development. The researchers also considered mothers’ education levels and verbal interactions with their infants.

Participants

The researchers tracked 274 mothers and their infant participants when the infants were at 6, 12, 18, 24, 36, and 48 months of age. The infants were healthy in terms of length of gestation, birth weight, growth patterns, and the presence of diseases or disorders.

Method

At each session, the researchers asked the mothers how much time their infants were exposed to media screens while awake during an average weekday. The mothers reported their own level of education and the age when their infants were first exposed to media screens. Research participants completed an assessment when the infants were 24 months, 36 months, and 48 months of age. The assessment measures infant motor skills, visual reception, comprehension of spoken words, and language formation.

Results and Discussion

On average, mothers reported that their infants’ first exposure to media screens occurred at one month of age. Screen exposure was primarily to televisions, followed by tablets and smartphones, and computers. The data showed that when mothers had more years of education, their infants were first exposed to media screens later than were infants whose mothers had fewer years of education. Mothers with more years of education also exposed their children to fewer media screens (correlation coefficient = -.20), and they verbally interacted more with their children during media screen exposure (correlation coefficient = .17). Participants who were exposed to 6.5 hours of screen time per day, which was considered a high level, scored lower for some motor skills and visual reception scales administered at 24 months (correlation coefficient = -.41), 36 months (correlation coefficient = -.26), and 48 months (correlation coefficient = -.28). The relationships between high levels of screen time and cognitive development were especially strong among participants who were first exposed to screen media at an early age or when mothers did not verbally interact with the participants during media screen exposure.

Supanitayanon, S., Trairatvorakul, P., & Chonchaiya, W. (2020). Screen media exposure in the first 2 years of life and preschool cognitive development: A longitudinal study. Pediatric Research, 88, 894-902. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41390-020-0831-8 

Source 2

Introduction

In the research study, participants completed mental imagery, working memory, and vocabulary tasks. Their parents reported on when the participants were first exposed to media screens, how often exposure occurs, and the kinds of screen devices used.

Participants

Two hundred sixty-six children between the ages of 3 and 10 years who attended pre- or primary school in Germany participated in this study. For the majority (56.4%), one or both parents had a university degree. Most of the participants spoke German at home, but 26.3% of them spoke a language other than German at home.

Method

Parents of the children completed surveys to provide information about their children’s screen time and use across different times of the day. Parents reported on different kinds of devices their children used and the age when children first began using devices.

The children completed three cognitive tasks: a mental imagery task, a working memory task, and a vocabulary task.

  • For the mental imagery task, the children were prompted to think about two objects and decide which of the two objects better fit into a category provided by the researchers (e.g., “Which is shinier, [a] trumpet or [a] violin?”). The researchers recorded the children’s responses on 34 trials and how quickly they responded on each trial, and the task was repeated at a later time

  • For the working memory task, the children were read nine strings of numbers that varied in length from two, three, or four digits. After each string, the children were asked to recall the string of numbers, but in the reverse order of how the researchers presented it.

  • For the vocabulary task, the children were shown 39 pictures of objects and were asked to name each one.

Results and Discussion

The researchers found the most common type of media screen exposure was to television. On average, the children were first exposed to screen media at almost 2 years of age. Working memory, vocabulary, and mental imagery were positively correlated to each other. On the mental imagery task, the researchers found a negative correlation between the amount of screen time at Time 1 and how accurate the children were on the task at Time 2.

Suggate, S. P., & Martzog, P. (2020). Screen-time influences children’s mental imagery performance. Developmental Science, 2020;23:e12978. https://doi.org/10.111/desc.12978 

Source 3

Introduction

The researchers studied pregnant women who lived in Brazil, assessing their infants’ cognitive development over time. The mothers also reported their own levels of education and how much time their children were exposed to media screens.

Participants

The researchers studied a randomly selected group of 470 women who were up to 24-weeks pregnant and lived in Brazil. The women gave informed consent to for their own and their children’s participation in the study, and the study was approved by an ethics committee to ensure the participants’ welfare and well-being.

Method

The mothers completed assessments at four points during pregnancy and after birth. When the children were at 18 months of age, they completed an assessment that measures cognitive, language, motor, socio-emotional, and behavioral components. Mothers reported their own level of education and how many hours their children were exposed to media screens during a typical day.

Results and Discussion

The children’s performance on the cognitive tasks was better when their mothers had more education. Their mean performance and standard deviation on the cognitive tasks as a function screen media exposure are:

Media Screen Exposure Mean of the Cognitive Tasks Standard Deviation of the Cognitive Tasks
No more than one hour each day 97 . 8 13.2
More than one hour, but less than two hours daily 95.3 13.7
Two or more hours 94.6 15.2

The differences in these means are statistically significant.

Gastaud, L. M., Trettim, J. P., Scholl, C. C., Rubin, B. B., Coelho, F. T., Krause, G. B., Ferreira, N. M., de Matos, M. B., Pinheiro, R. T., & de Avila Quevedo, L. (2023). Screen time: Implications for early childhood cognitive development. Early Human Development, 183, 1-5. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.earlhumdev.2023.105792

q.s:
Using the source provided, respond to the following questions.

A. Identify the research method used in the study.

f.c:
Question Instructions:

Your response to the question should be provided in six parts: A, B, C, D, E, and F. Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology in your response.

Source

Introduction

In the 1950s and 1960s, Stanley Milgram, a psychologist at Yale University, led a series of studies that tested whether people would obey the commands of a researcher in a lab. The study presented is a replication of one of Milgram’s original studies.

Participants

Individuals who responded to advertisements and flyers went through a series of screening procedures to eliminate people who had taken more than two psychology courses in college; been diagnosed with, or had therapy for, a psychological disorder; abused alcohol or drugs; had medical conditions affected by stress; or experienced severe trauma. The final sample had 29 men and 41 women. The participants ranged in age from 20 to 81 (mean age = 42.9 years, standard deviation = 15.67, median age = 41). Participant education and race/ethnicity demographics are presented in the table.

Education and Ethnicity Number of Participants Percentage of Participants
Education    
High school or less 12 17.1
Some college 16 22.9
Bachelor’s degree 28 40.0
Master’s degree 14 20.0
Ethnicity    
White 38 54.3
 Asian 19 26.7
Latino/a/Hispanic 9 12.9
African American 3 4.3
Did not state 1 1.4

A committee of professionals reviewed the study to ensure the appropriateness of the study before researchers began.
 

Method

Participants were randomly assigned to one of two conditions: the “base” condition and the “modeled refusal” condition. The participants agreed to be in the study and knew they could withdraw at any time and keep the $50 they were paid to participate.

In the base condition, the participant was paired with a “learner,” who was a research confederate. The participant read 25 different word-pairs (e.g., strong–arm) that the “learner” had to recall. If the “learner” gave an incorrect answer, the participant administered an electric shock using a “shock generator” that had switches ranging from 15 to 450 volts in 15-volt increments. The shock was fake, but the participant did not know this. The. The participant moved up one switch on the shock generator for each incorrect answer.

While the participants watched, the researcher strapped the “learners” into a chair with electrodes. The participant then went to another room for the remainder of the study. The “learners” gave correct and incorrect responses according to a predetermined schedule. After participants pressed the 75-volt switch, they heard a small grunt from the “learner.” The grunts got louder after each successive shock. When a participant pressed the 150-volt switch, the “learner” yelled, “Ugh. Get me out of here. I told you I had heart trouble. My heart’s starting to bother me now. I refuse to go on. Let me out.”

If the participant expressed reluctance or hesitation at any time, the researcher gave one of four directions, in this order: “Please continue”; “The research requires that you continue”; “It is absolutely essential that you continue”; and “You have no other choice, you must continue.” The researcher assessed whether the participants continued to administer shocks after receiving each direction. The base condition ended when the participant refused to continue or agreed to continue at the shock level just past 150 volts.

In the modeled refusal condition, the procedures were the same as the base condition except for an additional confederate who was paired with each participant. The men were paired with a White man in his 50s. Women were paired with a White woman in her late 20s. The researcher pretended to randomly choose the participant to be Teacher 2 and the additional confederate to be Teacher 1. Teacher 1 administered shocks to the “learner” according to the procedures as the participant watched. At the 90-volt shock level, Teacher 1 said to the researcher, “I don’t know about this.” The researcher responded with “Please continue.” Teacher 1 paused and then said, “I don’t think I can do this,” and pushed their chair from the table. The researcher then asked Teacher 2 (the participant) to continue the test, picking up where Teacher 1 left off.

As with the base condition, if the participant (Teacher 2) expressed reluctance or hesitation, the researcher gave one of the four directions as described. The researcher assessed whether the participants continued to administer shocks after receiving each direction. The modeled refusal condition also ended when the participant refused to continue or agreed to continue at the shock level just past 150 volts.

When the study was over, the researcher explained informed participants of the true purpose of the study after the study was complete, specifically that the “learner” was not receiving electric shocks. The “learner” entered the lab room at that point to assure the participant that they were fine.

Results and Discussion

Number (and Percentages) of Participants Who Stopped and Who Continued

Behavior Base Condition Modeled Refusal Condition Milgram’s Original Study
Stopped at 150 volts or earlier 12 (30%) 11 (36.7%) 7 (17.5%)
Continued after 150 volts 28 (70%) 19 (63.3%) 33 (82.5%)

Numbers (and Percentages) of Participants Who Stopped and Who Continued, By Gender

Condition and Behavior Men Women
Base condition    
  Stopped at 150 volts or earlier 6 (33.3%) 6 (27.3%)
  Continued after 150 volts 12 (66.7%) 16 (72.7%)
Modeled Refusal Condition    
  Stopped at 150 volts or earlier 5 (45.5%) 6 (31.6%)
  Continued after 150 volts 6 (54.5%) 13 (68.4%)
Burger, J.M. (2009). Replicating Milgram: Would people still obey today? American Psychologist, 64(1), 1-11.

q.s: Bellah grew up in a family that taught her that life can be hard, but a positive attitude about stress is always a better choice. As Bellah was moving away from home and starting college, she experienced some difficulties with adjusting to her new environment and schedule. Which of the following best describes why Bellah would describe her difficulties as eustress instead of distress?

o.l: Bellah’s genetic heritage would make her more predisposed to interpreting stress as eustress instead of distressed.
Bellah’s family taught her norms about stress that lead to her have positive expectations about stress as a young adult.
Bellah’s in a developmental stage that causes her to view stress with a positive attitude.
Bellah is experiencing delusional thinking about stress.

q.s:
Kendall learned in AP Psychology class about the tend-and-befriend theory, in which some people react to stress by tending to their own needs and/or the needs of others and seeking connection with others. Upon hearing that this theory seems mostly to describe the behavior of women instead of men, Kendall remarked to the class that he knew that would be the case all along.

Which of the following cognitive biases is Kendall demonstrating?
Which of the following best describes a situation where an individual’s perceptions influence their experience of stress?

o.l: Rutger experiences the physical and emotional symptoms associated with generalized anxiety disorder.
Jamie interprets experiences like getting stuck in traffic or her phone battery getting low as bothersome daily hassles.
Bane learned that women experience stress differently than men.
Micah copes with stress by focusing on how to manage their emotional reactions.

q.s:
Stress vs. Anxiety

Stress Both Stress and Anxiety Anxiety
• Goes away once the situation is resolved. • Can be positive or negative. For example, it may inspire you to meet a deadline, or it may cause you to lose sleep. Both stress and anxiety can affect your mind and body. You may experience symptoms such as: • Excessive worry • Uneasiness • Tension • Headaches or body pain • High blood pressure • Loss of sleep • Usually involves a persistent feeling of apprehension or dread that doesn't go away and that interferes with how you live your life. • Is constant, even if there is no immediate threat.

According to the information from the table, which statement accurately reflects the relationship between stress and anxiety?

o.l: Stress primarily results in physical symptoms like headaches and body pain, while anxiety solely causes cognitive symptoms such as excessive worry and uneasiness.
Stress can lead to physical symptoms such as high blood pressure, but the same is not true for anxiety.
Anxiety is usually resolved once the triggering stressor is eliminated, unlike stress, which can persist even after the stressor is removed.
Stress and anxiety have similar physical and cognitive symptoms but represent distinct psychological experiences.

q.s:
Dr. Taneesha is interested in water intake as an indication of healthy behaviors. She randomly selected ten individuals at a mall and asked, “On average, how many glasses of water do you drink each day?” The data set her interviews produced are as follows: 6, 5, 2, 0, 0, 3, 0, 8, 4, 1.

What is the mode of the data set?

The raw scores presented are the results of a fitness test for first year college students:

20, 42, 37, 46, 24, 42, 34, 26, 42, 27

What is the mean of the distribution of the raw scores presented?

A researcher is interested in the relationship between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and well-being as adults. She surveyed a group of 10 randomly selected adults about whether they had experienced adverse childhood experiences from a list. The participants were also asked to take a survey measuring their overall well-being. The data for the two surveys are presented in the table.

Participant ID Number of Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) Score on the Well-Being Scale (higher scores indicate higher well-being)
A 2 8
B 5 4
C 8 3
D 1 9
E 0 8
F 6 5
G 9 4
H 5 6
I 5 8
J 7 2

What is the mode of the number of adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) for this study?
Which of the following may explain why some people experience growth after a traumatic experience?

o.l: Some people are genetically predisposed to interpret stress as eustress instead of distress.
Some cultures may encourage people to interpret stress as a challenge rather than an obstacle.
Some people have evolved to interpret trauma as opportunities for growth.
Some people will comply with authority figures who demand they view trauma as a growth opportunity.

q.s:
During his Psychology of Well-Being course in college, Jacob learns about research that suggests regularly expressing gratitude toward others can increase subjective well-being. Based on this life experience, Jacob believes the outcome of this research is obvious, and everyone would intuitively recognize the value of gratitude.

Which cognitive bias does Jacob’s thinking represent?

Dr. Tonya surveyed 100 people, measured their height in inches, and asked whether they practiced gratitude. After analyzing the data, she claims that height causes people to be less grateful. Which of the following is a limitation of the study?

o.l: The dependent variable was not manipulated.
The independent variable was not manipulated.
The results are correlational, not causational.
The laboratory setting of the situation does not reflect the “real world.”

q.s:
A team of psychologists created two well-being training programs for the U.S. military to help soldiers with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Soldiers were given two surveys before and after the well-being training programs were implemented that measured a variety of variables, including demographics, feelings of gratitude, and thoughts of suicide.

What variable relationships would researchers examine to determine if these well-being training programs were successful?

o.l: A positive correlation between gratitude and rates of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
How much rates of PTSD and suicide declined among those in the military.
Soldiers in well-being training were less likely to be promoted to higher ranks.
Self-harm rates would increase only for those with PTSD.

q.s: A classmate reading Dr. Kebede’s study disregards the results and states “this really isn’t even an experiment.” Which of the following supports the fact that Dr. Kebede’s study is an experiment?

o.l: There are two variables in the study; the gratitude and the thankfulness.
The study would be published in a peer-reviewed journal.
Dr. Kebede included random assignment to groups in the study.
The study was conducted over three months.

f.c:
Dr. Kebede believes that as people express gratitude more frequently, their subjective well-being will increase. To test this, Dr. Kebede conducts a study in which participants are randomly assigned to one of two groups. In both groups, participants are asked to record their sense of well-being by keeping a weekly journal and responding to the prompt: “All things considered, how satisfied are you with your life as a whole these days?”

In the first group, the participants were required to set a goal to express gratitude and thankfulness through daily affirmations or to others throughout the day. The participants in the second group are not tasked with expressing gratitude but are still asked to keep the weekly journal. After three months, Dr. Kebede collects the journals and reads the responses.

q.s: In this study, what is the independent variable?

o.l: The participant response to the journal prompt
The wording of the journal prompt

f.c:
Dr. Kebede believes that as people express gratitude more frequently, their subjective well-being will increase. To test this, Dr. Kebede conducts a study in which participants are randomly assigned to one of two groups. In both groups, participants are asked to record their sense of well-being by keeping a weekly journal and responding to the prompt: “All things considered, how satisfied are you with your life as a whole these days?”

In the first group, the participants were required to set a goal to express gratitude and thankfulness through daily affirmations or to others throughout the day. The participants in the second group are not tasked with expressing gratitude but are still asked to keep the weekly journal. After three months, Dr. Kebede collects the journals and reads the responses.

q.s: Dr. Kebede read through all of the journal responses submitted by the participants in both groups and concluded that expressing gratitude does indeed increase subjective well-being. Which of the following cognitive biases is most likely to affect Dr. Kebede’s interpretation of the journals?

f.c:
Dr. Kebede believes that as people express gratitude more frequently, their subjective well-being will increase. To test this, Dr. Kebede conducts a study in which participants are randomly assigned to one of two groups. In both groups, participants are asked to record their sense of well-being by keeping a weekly journal and responding to the prompt: “All things considered, how satisfied are you with your life as a whole these days?”

In the first group, the participants were required to set a goal to express gratitude and thankfulness through daily affirmations or to others throughout the day. The participants in the second group are not tasked with expressing gratitude but are still asked to keep the weekly journal. After three months, Dr. Kebede collects the journals and reads the responses.

q.s:
Dr. Ake developed a measure that asked people about how much they agreed with several statements about their subjective well-being. The participants had to choose a number between 1 and 5, with 1 meaning they strongly disagreed and 5 meaning they strongly agreed. Those who chose the number 3 were indicating that they were neutral about the statement.

Which of the following identifies the type of measurement tool Dr. Ake used?

Liu is a Chinese exchange student studying in the United States. She is feeling lonely and may have depression. She goes to a psychologist to report her symptoms. The major symptom Liu reports to the psychologist is that she has been feeling much back pain lately, a common symptom of depression in China. Because the psychologist does not see this as a symptom of depression, he refers her to a physical therapist.

Which of the following may influence the decision of the psychiatrist?

Several different employers were sent resumes of potential employees. The resumes were sent to the employers in pairs. Both candidates were equally qualified, but in each pair, one applicant described mental health problems as an explanation for the reason they left their previous job. The results showed that applicants reporting mental health problems had a 27% lower probability of getting an interview.

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the results of this study?

o.l: Employers overuse the availability heuristic in the hiring process.
There is cultural stigma around mental health problems that make employers less likely to hire those afflicted.
Ageism persists in the workplace and often leads to discriminatory hiring practices.
Employers tend to make decisions based on the central route to persuasion, and the information provided was more aligned to the peripheral route to persuasion.

q.s: When describing how psychological problems evolve, which of the following is a strength of the biopsychosocial model?

o.l: The model emphasizes the belief that psychological problems are caused by genetics.
The model supports the humanistic view that disorders stem from a lack of unconditional positive regard.
The model adheres to the behaviorist view that psychological problems result exclusively from classical and operant conditioning.
The model considers, in addition to other factors, the role that cultural norms and expectations play in the development of psychological problems.

q.s: Dr. Brennan is interested in investigating the negative and positive consequences of diagnosing his female patients with bipolar disorder. To ensure that ethical procedures are followed, what must Dr. Brennan do prior to beginning the research study?

o.l: Ensure that a random sample of subjects is selected
Receive informed consent from each of the participants
Assign subjects randomly to control and experimental groups

q.s: Dr. Neal is conducting research on the impact of genetics on anxiety disorders. Which of the following reflects appropriate attention to ethical procedures?

o.l: Dr. Neal publishes the results of the research and although names of the subjects are included in the article, the address and phone number are not printed.

Dr. Neal meets with each of the subjects individually after the conclusion of the study to share and explain the results, answer questions, and make certain the subjects feel positive about participation in the study.

If Dr. Neal tells the subjects that he is researching genetic physical properties such as hair and eye color to not make subjects anxious about being included in an anxiety study, he would not have to debrief them.
Dr. Neal tries to minimize the paperwork and hassle for each participant by not requiring informed consent prior to the beginning of the study.

q.s:
A psychologist is devising a research study to test the diathesis-stress model. She gathers a list of interested subjects who have one or more members of their family who have been diagnosed with schizophrenia. She randomly assigns the subjects to one of two groups and identifies them with a code number to maintain confidentiality. The experimental group will be subjected to a series of stress-inducing situations while the control group will be allowed to read books, engage in quiet conversation, and relax. The psychologist then proposes to follow the subjects for six years.

Which of the following is most likely of concern for an IRB to consider whether the psychologist followed appropriate ethical procedures?

o.l: By proposing to follow the subjects for six years, the psychologist is violating their privacy and confidentiality.
By gathering a list of participants that share a family diagnosis of schizophrenia, the psychologist is disregarding the research procedure of random sampling.
By subjecting participants in the experimental group to stress-inducing situations, this study may not protect participants from harm.
By only taking interested subjects into the experiment, the sample may reflect a bias that confound the results.

q.s: Dr. Jamal is designing research to study narcissistic personality disorder. Which of the following should Dr. Jamal make certain to do to adhere to ethical research guidelines?

o.l: Read the existing research to make sure no other researcher has conducted this type of study.
Discuss the study with other researchers in the field.
Obtain informed consent from the participants prior to conducting the study.
Locate and reserve lab space, hire assistants and order any necessary equipment.

q.s:
Dr. Mizrahi is designing a study to test whether antidepressants are more effective than placebos. Using electronic medical records, Dr. Mizrahi gathers a random sample of his patients who display a set of symptoms typically associated with major depressive disorder. He randomly assigns participants to receive an antidepressant medication or a placebo as a substitute for their daily multivitamin. Neither the participants nor Dr. Mizrahi know who is in which group.

Which of the following should be of concern when trying to evaluate whether Dr. Mizrahi adhered to established ethical research guidelines?

o.l: Dr. Mizrahi did not get informed consent from his patients.
Since a double-blind procedure was used, it is of ethical concern that Dr. Mizrahi does not know which group is getting the placebo.
Although there is debate about the use of deception in placebo studies, it is an ethical concern that deception was used in this case.
By limiting his sample to only diagnosed patients, Dr. Mizrahi will be unable to generalize the results of the study.

q.s: How might a psychologist using the sociocultural perspective differ from a psychologist of the biological perspective in explaining the causes of the symptoms listed in the infographic above?

o.l: A sociocultural psychologist would look to environmental factors while a biological psychologist would consider genetics and chemical imbalances in the brain.

A sociocultural psychologist would look to unconscious thoughts and experiences developed during childhood while a biological psychologist would look to physical characteristics such as eye color, height and weight.
A sociocultural psychologist would investigate where individuals showing symptoms fall on the introversion/extroversion scale, while a biological psychologist would use projective tests.

A sociocultural psychologist would evaluate which maladaptive thoughts, beliefs, attitudes, or emotions are present in the individual and the biological psychologist would focus on maladaptive learned associations between stimuli.

f.c:

NOTE: Anhedonia is the inability to enjoy oneself. Avolition is lack of motivation.

q.s: If a researcher wanted to do an experiment to examine if a biological treatment was successful for addressing the positive symptoms, which of the following might be an important ethical consideration?

o.l: The control group would lead the debriefing after the study.
Individuals in the study would be randomly assigned to the control group.
The control group would receive the biological treatment.
The participants might not be able to give consent.

f.c:
Signs & Symptoms

NOTE: Anhedonia is the inability to enjoy oneself. Avolition is lack of motivation.

q.s: Dr. Castro is interested in investigating the effectiveness of behavioral therapy on the fear of spiders. Without telling the participants, she puts each of them in a room filled with cages of spiders. Which ethical guideline did Dr. Castro violate?
Which of the following ethical principles for therapists is most like the research ethical principle of “do no harm”?

Sports psychologists are studying the use of rational-emotive behavior therapy on the understanding and promotion of mental health in athletes. Once they have received informed consent, the researchers split the athletes into two groups. The experimental group was shown a series of videos in which athletes were injured and then were given rational-emotive behavior therapy to discuss what they viewed. The control group did not watch any videos and received conventional positive thinking training. Which of the following would most likely be of most concern for the IRB reviewing this study?

o.l: The researchers should have made the participants in the control group watch the injury videos.
The researchers are likely exposing the participants to harm by showing videos of injuries.
The researchers deceived the participants by not telling the control group about the videos.
The researchers should have randomly assigned participants to groups.

Which of the following concepts does this conversation illustrate?

f.c:
Four-year-old Ethan and his mother have the following conversation:

MOTHER: Ethan, do you have a brother?
ETHAN: Yes.
MOTHER: What’s his name?
ETHAN: My brother’s name is Anthony.

ETHAN: No.

q.s: Betty was just diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. Which of the following effects is she most likely to experience?

o.l: The neurons in her body will not be able to reach threshold, leading to fatigue.
Depolarization in her neurons will not occur, causing sensory impairment.
Neurotransmitters will remain in the synapse for an extended period, causing memory loss.
Neural messages will travel slowly down the axon, leading to motor impairment.

q.s: Which of the following best describes the type of measurement instrument that Dr. Maryam is using?

f.c: Dr. Maryam is investigating the ability of patients to recover brain function after a stroke. Dr. Maryam asks patients who had a stroke and volunteered for this study a series of specific open-ended questions and records their responses.

q.s: Dr. Sperry records a video of Jim, a participant in split-brain research, and then plays it in class to teach students about hemispheric differences. Which of the following procedures should Dr. Sperry use to show the video in class?

o.l: Obtain Jim’s permission to use the video.
Debrief Jim after the research session.
Demonstrate the educational value of the video to Jim.

q.s: Which of the following principles underlies Simon’s strategy?

f.c: When Simon opens a new coffee shop, he offers to give each customer a free cup of coffee on their birthday. He hopes this will make people more likely to buy coffee at his shop in the future.

q.s: Markum reads online articles to assess the advantages and disadvantages of several universities and uses this information to decide where to attend. Which of the following brain regions is Markum primarily using as he decides which university to attend?
Which of the following principles best explains the assumption of Justine’s new classmates?

f.c: Justine transferred to a new school where she does not know anyone. She does not talk to others and sits by herself at lunch. Her classmates assume she is arrogant and rude.

q.s:
Using the source provided, respond to all parts of the question.

 
 

Your response to the question should be provided in six parts: A, B, C, D, E, and F. Write the response to each part of the question in complete sentences. Use appropriate psychological terminology in your response.

A. Identify the research method used in the study.

f.c:
Introduction

Researchers performed a study to determine if cell phone calls that interrupt in-person interactions between a mother and her child affect how well the child learns vocabulary words.

Participants

This study comprised 38 pairs of participants. Each pair comprised a mother and her two-year-old child. The average age of the mothers was 35.26 years (age range = 29.53 to 47.10 years; 19 mothers did not report their age). All the two-year-old children were developing along standard physical, social, and emotional timelines. The average age of the children was 27.05 months (2.25 years), and an equal number of boys and girls participated. All mother-child pairs lived in suburban communities surrounding the same major East Coast United States city; 90.9% of families self-identified as white while the remaining 9.10% self-identified as Hispanic, Pacific Islander, African American, or multiethnic.1 Mothers agreed to be in the study and knew they could withdraw from participation at any time. Researchers ensured that the individual participants could not be identified from the data collected.

Method

At the beginning of the study, mothers and their children were placed in separate rooms. The children played in a supervised, child-friendly room. Meanwhile, in a separate room, the researchers trained the mothers regarding the meaning of two completely new words: blicking (meaning a type of bouncing) and frepping (meaning a type of shaking). The researchers made up these words and their meanings for the purpose of this study. To demonstrate blicking to their child, each mother was provided an 18-inch gender-neutral2 doll. To demonstrate frepping to their child, each mother could shake a 6-inch rattle. 

After providing each mother with a phone, which had been set to vibrate mode, the researchers trained each mother on how to answer the phone. The researchers told each mother to expect occasional phone calls during the study. During each call, the researchers provided one of three directions to the mother: 1) begin teaching the new word (teaching phase), 2) move to the next word (transition phase), or 3) engage in a conversation with the researcher as if talking with a friend (interruption phase). 

To initiate the teaching phase, the researchers called each mother and told her to teach the designated word to her child. Half of the mothers were told to teach blicking first while the other half were told to teach frepping first. The researchers interrupted half of the mothers while the mothers taught their first word and then interrupted the second half of the mothers while the mothers taught their second word. For the uninterrupted teaching phase, each mother received a transition call from a researcher that instructed her to start teaching the identified word. The mother then had 60 seconds to teach the word to her child. 

Figure 1 and Figure 2 depict the research design for the teaching phase, the transition phase, and the interruption phase. 

Figure 1: Teaching Sequence in Interruption-First Condition

  • The teaching time for Word 1 and Word 2 and interruption call times are shown as follows:
    • Word 1 (30 seconds)
    • Interruption Call (30 seconds)
    • Word 1 (30 seconds)
    • Transition Call (5–7 seconds)
    • Word 2 (60 seconds)

 

Figure 2: Teaching Sequence in Interruption-Second Condition

  • The teaching time for Word 1 and Word 2 and interruption call times are shown as follows:
    • Word 1 (60 seconds)
    • Transition Call (5–7 seconds)
    • Word 2 (30 seconds)
    • Interruption Call (30 seconds)
    • Word 2 (30 seconds)

For each interrupted teaching phase, the mother received a call after 30 seconds of teaching her child. During the interrupted teaching phase, the researchers and the mother talked about morning coffee routines for about 30 seconds. After about 30 seconds, the researchers instructed the mother to continue teaching her child the assigned word. Each mother had an additional 30 seconds to teach the word.

The researchers counted how many times the mothers used the words blicking or frepping during the instruction sessions.

After receiving instruction on blicking and frepping, each child sat in their mother’s lap and watched a video. The video began with an attention-getting image in the center of the screen (an image of a laughing baby) followed by the instruction to “Find [blicking or frepping].” The video then transitioned to a scene in which a puppet demonstrated the appropriate action for each word (bouncing for blicking and shaking for frepping) or demonstrated an unrelated action (twisting side to side or putting a hand on a box while standing up). Researchers measured how long the children paid attention to the action in the video to determine whether the children learned blicking or frepping. The mothers closed their eyes during the video to avoid accidentally cueing the children to pay attention to the correct action in the video. Researchers informed participants of the true purpose of the study after the study was complete.

Results and Discussion

On average, the mothers repeated the word approximately 24 times in the interrupted teaching phase and approximately 20 times in the uninterrupted teaching phase. The difference was not statistically significant. 

The children paid attention to the word they learned in the uninterrupted session for an average of 0.63 seconds and in the interrupted session for an average of 0.50 seconds. The difference in means was statistically significant, suggesting that in-person interruptions between parent and child can affect how well young children learn vocabulary words.

Reed. J., Hirsh-Pasek, K., & Golinkoff, R.M. (2017). Learning on hold: Cell phones sidetrack parent-child interactions. Developmental Psychology, 53(8): 1438–1436.

q.s: Which of the following concepts has most likely shaped Hiroshi’s opinion of Harold?

f.c: Hiroshi is Harold’s manager at work. Harold brags to Hiroshi that he scored very high on an intelligence test, so Hiroshi forms a very positive opinion of him. As a result, Hiroshi attributes any mistakes that Harold makes to accidents and praises him more than other workers.

q.s: Which of the following hypotheses would a psychologist interested in the forgetting curve most likely investigate?

o.l: Students will remember more information if they engage in elaborative rehearsal than if they engage in maintenance rehearsal.
Students will remember information they learned at the start and end of the semester better than information they learned in the middle of the semester.
Students will remember lecture information 15 minutes after the lecture ends better than students will remember that information 60 minutes after the lecture ends.
Students will remember more information if they are in the same environmental space than if they are in the same mood.

q.s: Which of the following concepts relates to Rowan’s schema in this scenario?

f.c:
When Rowan was six years old, his father took him to see a tennis match. Rowan enjoyed learning the rules of the game and watching the players hit the ball back and forth across the net with their tennis racquets. 

Five months later, Rowan’s aunt took him to a park to play pickleball, a game similar to tennis. He had a great afternoon learning to hit the ball back and forth with the pickleball paddle instead of a tennis racquet. That night, Rowan told his parents that he had a great time playing “tennis” with his aunt.

q.s: Which of the following concepts is most likely responsible for Declan’s change in opinion?

f.c: When Declan first meets his civics teacher, he thinks she is too loud and demanding. Over the following weeks, he grows to like that she is funny and sets high standards.

q.s: Which of the following responses from Dr. Xiang’s colleague would be the most appropriate?

o.l: Dr. Xiang cannot generalize her findings to the larger population because she used a single case study.
Dr. Xiang cannot make causal inferences because she conducted a naturalistic observation.
Dr. Xiang can generalize her findings to the larger population because she had a representative sample.
Dr. Xiang can make causal inferences because she conducted a longitudinal study.

f.c:
Dr. Xiang examined a 21-year-old patient who had fallen and hit their head. After a brain scan was conducted, Dr. Xiang discovered that the patient was missing their cerebellum. Dr. Xiang extensively interviewed the patient and their family and learned that the patient had a long history of balance and coordination problems. 

Based on this patient, Dr. Xiang tells her colleague that anyone who is missing their cerebellum will always experience balance and coordination problems.

q.s: Which of the following terms best corresponds to what Markum’s instructor is trying to help them feel?

f.c: Markum is taking a class on positive psychology. His instructor encourages class members to recognize, reflect on, and appreciate the moments in their lives when they have had positive feelings or have been influenced in ways that had positive outcomes.

q.s: Which of the following processes accounts for this change?

f.c: Moriah is in favor of community programs that encourage recycling. She joins an online social media group that supports recycling, and the members frequently discuss the importance of recycling. After Moriah is in the group for several months, her views have become even more favorable toward recycling than they were when she joined the group. Moriah also notes that the views of the rest of the group have become more strongly favorable toward recycling as well.

q.s: Keenan’s thinking is most clearly an example of which of the following concepts?

f.c: In his psychology class, Keenan was learning about the various ways people respond to and cope with stressful life events. While he believed that both men and women dealt with stress in the same way, his teacher explained that women are much more likely than men to reach out to friends to both give and receive support. Upon learning this, Keenan told a classmate this finding was totally predictable and obvious because women are typically more nurturing than men.

q.s: A doctor is assessing a patient with a sensory disorder. In the first assessment, she asks the patient to touch his nose with his eyes closed. In the next assessment, she asks the patient to walk a short distance with his eyes closed. Which of the following senses is the doctor most likely evaluating?

David tells his roommate Wilbert to buy nine items at the grocery store: milk, bananas, cereal, pickles, cheese, oranges, sausage, chips, and shampoo. Which of the following items is Wilbert most likely to forget when he goes to the store?
According to the psychodynamic perspective, which of the following processes best explains why people use defense mechanisms?
After accidentally touching a hot pan with his hand, Benedict immediately withdraws his hand without thinking. Which of the following processes best describes this example of a spinal reflex arc?

o.l: The sensation of heat is sent to Benedict’s brain for processing. The brain then sends a message to the peripheral nervous system, causing him to remove his hand from the hot pan.
Benedict’s peripheral nervous system immediately detects the heat, processes the response, and causes Benedict to remove his hand from the hot pan. The central nervous system is not involved.
Benedict’s peripheral and central nervous systems work independently in this situation, with the peripheral nervous system moving his hand and the central nervous system perceiving the heat.
Sensory neurons in Benedict’s peripheral nervous system detect the heat and send a rapid signal to an interneuron in the spinal cord, which then directs a motor neuron to move his hand.

q.s: Which of the following concepts was at work?

f.c: Josie was given a password by her teacher. To remember the password, she repeated it in her mind multiple times until she typed it into her login screen a few moments later.

q.s: Which of the following statements best describes the differences between internal locus of control and external locus of control for health and well-being?

o.l: Individuals with an internal locus of control tend to be less depressed than individuals who have an external locus of control.
Individuals with an external locus of control thrive when they work independently compared to individuals who have an internal locus of control.
Individuals with an external locus of control live longer than those with an internal locus of control.
Individuals with an internal locus of control are more likely than individuals who have an external locus of control to experience learned helplessness.

q.s: After years of watching their mother drive a car, Rowan knows how to start the car when sitting in the driver’s seat for the first time. Which of the following types of learning best explains how Rowan acquired this new behavior?
Which of the following statements most accurately describes why this study is an experiment?

o.l: The researchers operationally defined the variables.
The participants were randomly assigned to one of two groups.
The sample was representative of the population being observed.

f.c:
Researchers at an advertising agency conducted a study to determine whether classical conditioning principles could influence consumers' preferences for a particular product. They randomly assigned 100 college students from a nearby university to one of two groups. 

Both groups watched a commercial for the same brand of shoes. One group watched a commercial that did not feature a celebrity endorsement, while the second group watched a commercial that featured a celebrity endorsement from a physically attractive celebrity. The participants were exposed to these ads multiple times a day for two weeks. 

At the end of the two weeks, the participants were asked to rate, on a scale of 1 to 10, how likely they were to purchase the brand of shoes advertised in the commercial they watched.

q.s: Which of the following best describes the experimental group in this research design?

o.l: All 100 participants in the study were part of the experimental group.
The group that watched a commercial for the shoes that did not include a celebrity endorsement was the experimental group.
The group that watched a commercial for the shoes featuring a physically attractive celebrity was the experimental group.
This research did not involve an experimental group because there was no independent variable.

f.c:
Researchers at an advertising agency conducted a study to determine whether classical conditioning principles could influence consumers' preferences for a particular product. They randomly assigned 100 college students from a nearby university to one of two groups. 

Both groups watched a commercial for the same brand of shoes. One group watched a commercial that did not feature a celebrity endorsement, while the second group watched a commercial that featured a celebrity endorsement from a physically attractive celebrity. The participants were exposed to these ads multiple times a day for two weeks. 

At the end of the two weeks, the participants were asked to rate, on a scale of 1 to 10, how likely they were to purchase the brand of shoes advertised in the commercial they watched.

q.s: Which of the following psychological perspectives is linked most closely to the research presented in the study?

f.c:
Researchers at an advertising agency conducted a study to determine whether classical conditioning principles could influence consumers' preferences for a particular product. They randomly assigned 100 college students from a nearby university to one of two groups. 

Both groups watched a commercial for the same brand of shoes. One group watched a commercial that did not feature a celebrity endorsement, while the second group watched a commercial that featured a celebrity endorsement from a physically attractive celebrity. The participants were exposed to these ads multiple times a day for two weeks. 

At the end of the two weeks, the participants were asked to rate, on a scale of 1 to 10, how likely they were to purchase the brand of shoes advertised in the commercial they watched.

q.s: Which of the following is true about the research study?

o.l: The type of dance learned is a confounding variable.
The study relied on a convenience sample.

The number of mistakes made during the routine was counted.

q.s: Which of the following is the median for these reported study scores?

f.c: Dr. Britt is interested in pain perception while participants are practicing meditation. She asked participants to report their pain on a scale from 1 to 10, where a higher number indicates more pain. The scores for Dr. Britt’s study were 1, 10, 4, 3, 3, 4, 6, 7, 3, and 9.

q.s: Which of the following concepts best explains this research finding?

f.c:
Researchers were interested in studying cultural differences in emotional expression. The researchers conducted a study in which all American and Japanese participants watched films of surgery both alone and in the presence of a researcher.  

When both American and Japanese participants were alone, they showed the same facial expressions, namely disgust and fear. However, when in the presence of the researcher, the American participants continued to show their negative emotions, while the Japanese participants masked their negative emotions with a smile.

q.s: Which of the following statements best explains why using an experimental research design is inappropriate in studying human development?

o.l: Experiments cannot establish cause-and-effect relationships over time.
Direct, long-term manipulation of a child’s environment during an experiment is unethical.
Experiments with young children are always unethical.
Identifying which genetic traits are interacting with the environment is impossible using an experiment.

q.s: Which of the following processes is most likely occurring?

o.l: The drug acts as a reuptake inhibitor.
The drug acts as an antagonist.
The drug no longer works effectively because the body has developed a tolerance to it.
The drug only works because of the placebo effect.

f.c: Some psychoactive drugs increase neurotransmitter availability along the reward center pathway by trapping neurotransmitters in the synapse, the gap between neurons. This process creates a sense of well-being.

q.s: Which of the following accurately depicts why this change in focus occurs at different distances?

o.l: The accommodation processes of the lenses in Valerie’s eyes
Sensory interaction between vision and audition

f.c: Valerie’s eyes focus on her notebook when she is taking notes in class, and the image of her writing appears clear and distinct. When she looks up at the instructor standing in the distance, her eyes focus on her instructor.

q.s: Which of the following scenarios is an example of the gambler’s fallacy?

o.l: Anita’s friend refused her request to donate $200 to a charity, but then her friend agreed to donate $20 to the charity.
Marie was so focused on picking a card from the cards laid out on a table that she did not notice when the magician exchanged places with his assistant.
After his favorite team lost three games in a row, Doug was certain that they would win the next one, so he bought an expensive ticket to attend the next game.
After spending over two hours negotiating at the car dealership, Sean decided that he should purchase a car, even though he was not getting his target purchase price.

q.s: Lynne was laid off from her job due to difficulties in completing tasks, planning ahead, and following company rules. She is most likely low in which of the following Big Five personality traits?
What principle of perception is being used in this advertisement?

f.c: A coffee association wants to increase sales of coffee in one region of the United States. To do so, it puts up billboards on major highways in that region with the following message.

q.s: What would be the most appropriate way to operationally define the effectiveness of this advertisement technique?

o.l: Sales of coffee in restaurants near the billboard
The length of time people look at the billboard
The number of billboards in the region that contain the message
Sales of billboards in the region

f.c: A coffee association wants to increase sales of coffee in one region of the United States. To do so, it puts up billboards on major highways in that region with the following message.

q.s: Which of the following sets of perceptual concepts is being used in this advertisement?

f.c: A coffee association wants to increase sales of coffee in one region of the United States. To do so, it puts up billboards on major highways in that region with the following message.
